Title: Itinerary for Three Days in Budapest, Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hungary, a central European country in the Carpathian Basin, is theorized to be named after the Huns that invaded the territory in the fifth century. Since then, it has experienced a whirlwind of change and history. From 1867 to 1918 it was part of one of the largest and most influential empires in Europe — the Austro-Hungarian Empire. It later existed as a monarchy with no king, an Axis Power in World War II, a Soviet communist regime throughout the Cold War, and eventually a democracy under the European Union.
Budapest, the capital, is arguably one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. Known as the “Paris of the East’, it is filled with incredible architecture, amazing food, and a unique culture. It was once considered two separate cities until their unification in 1873. “Buda”, situated on the west bank of the Danube, is hilly, residential, and home to the Buda Castle. “Pest”, on the other side of the river, is flat, commercial, and the site of the Parliament Building. They are connected by a series of bridges, including the iconic Széchenyi Chain Bridge, the city’s first permanent structure to span the Danube.
The city has numerous things to do and see over the course of three days. Keep in mind that this guide is for groups that love to walk everywhere and remain always on the go. Feel free to alter based on your interests and abilities.
The nation’s official language is Hungarian or “Magyar”, referring to the ancestors of modern Hungarians. It is one of the world’s five hardest languages to learn and dissimilar to any other European language. Thankfully most locals in the touristic areas of the city speak English so it’s easy to get around.
WiFi is available and strong at most hotels and establishments.
Budapest is extremely hot in the summer (averaging 80°F but higher during frequent heat waves) and chilly in the winter (around 40°F with infrequent snow). The best time to visit is when temperatures are relatively mild from September through November and April through May.
Budapest, like most European cities, is very safe. The primary thing to watch out for are pickpockets — especially in crowded, touristy areas.
The best way to get from the airport — the Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport (BUD) — to downtown is by using Uber. It’s affordable, easy, and takes roughly thirty minutes. Welcome Pickups also offers reliable transfers. As for taxis, wait in the designated taxi line outside arrivals to avoid scams. This allows you to inform the attendant of your destination and receive a price quote before even entering a vehicle. Avoid cabs downtown as they tend to rip off foreigners.
Once in the city, I typically like to walk most places. However, some areas are spread out or require climbing scores of steps (specifically in sloping Buda) so if that’s intimidating, purchase a metro pass for the day to use an unlimited number of times. It’s also worth noting that many metro stations do not have a ticket booth so one must walk to another nearby station or digitally buy on the BudapestGo app. Do NOT get onboard without having paid. Trust me as I learned the hard way. The city hires metro employees to check for tickets on all public transports and getting caught without one results in a massive fine. The charge I received close to a decade ago was €50 so I can only imagine what it is now! Be sure to also validate the ticket, whether a day pass or an individual purchase, upon entering the transport. If the employees catch you without the validation, even if the ticket is in your hand, you risk getting fined.
Restaurant recommendations are listed below -
Tap water is completely safe to drink. Fountains are located all over the city to allow for easy bottle refills.
The country’s main currency is the Hungarian Forint (HUF, ft). Although it’s part of the European Union, Hungary cannot use the Euro because it has not met all financial and economic EU requirements to be able to adopt the coin. Credit cards are accepted in most establishments, including smaller market stalls. Regardless, carry some cash to play it safe.
As for prices — I hate to say it but the secret of Budapest is OUT! I first visited in 2017 and everything was cheap — far cheaper than other Eastern European cities. Thanks to Instagram and word of mouth, tourism has skyrocketed and with it, the prices. It’s by no means near the level of cities like Paris, London, and Stockholm; but it’s much more expensive than it used to be. Stick to the rule of thumb that the closer one is to the Danube River, the higher the prices will be.
Note: Most of this outline highlights costs in USD. This is a conversion to make it easier for some readers. Costs vary and everything is charged in the local currency when in person.
Tipping is not mandatory but with the influx of western tourism, many service industry employees now expect at least a little something. Round up to the nearest dollar to tip 10% with exceptional service.
The best location to stay is in the 5th district on the Pest side as it’s culturally charming and the closest to main attractions. Others may opt to stay in the 1st district, also known as the Castle District, on the Buda side due to its beauty and upscale nature.
Hungary uses the same outlet type as those in continental Europe; the type F plug.
It’s time to explore this amazing city. Start with breakfast at Honey in the center of Pest then prepare to walk off the hearty feast. I always recommend doing a free walking tour upon arriving in a new city. Budapest is so large and full of history that it offers numerous tour options including separate tours of both Buda and Pest as well as a Jewish Quarter Tour and a Communism Tour. Now, I understand that four walking tours is a lot — so pick one or two and go from there. If looking to learn the basics of the city, start with the Pest Tour and complete the Buda Tour the following day.
The Pest Tour highlights the liveliness of its side of the Danube. It passes by the beautiful Parliament Building, St. Stephen’s Basilica, and the pedestrian-only area of Vörösmarty Square. Learn fun facts about famous Hungarians. For example — did you know the inventors of the rubix cube, ballpoint pen, and holograms were all from Hungary? The excursion also showcases the city’s harrowing side, including the newly built Shoe Memorial which is a tribute to the Jewish residents ruthlessly executed by militiamen in WWII.
After, grab lunch then walk twenty minutes to the House of Terror Museum to dive more into the nation’s dark history. Housed in the former Nazi headquarters (lovingly once referred to as the “House of Loyalty”), the museum exhibits the reign of terror inflicted on the civilian population during both the Second World War and communism era. It is estimated that the Hungarian party captured and mistreated one person from every third family during this terror regime, oftentimes housing them in this building against their will. It’s a stop that can’t be missed and deserves at least ninety minutes.
Visitors have the option to purchase an audio guide as most of the exhibits are in Hungarian. However, the audio is about the same price as the ticket itself so it’s a bit expensive to get both. Instead, use the complimentary English print outs located in each exhibit that depict the same information.
Note: The museum is closed on Mondays. In addition, all bags must be left in the guarded storage area during the duration of the visit.
To return to the main area of Pest, walk along the gorgeous tree lined Andrassy Boulevard. Enjoy an early dinner at the delicious Hungarian restaurant located in the Jewish Quarter, Gettó Gulyás (reservations highly recommended), before grabbing drinks at the famous Szimpla Kert next door. This is one of many bohemian ruin pubs scattered across the city, named for the fact that they are set in abandoned warehouses and factories. Szimpla Kert in particular has numerous rooms and floors with various mismatched pieces of furniture, frequent live music, and a bustling vibe that comes to life in the evenings. It’s a must-do while in the Paris of the East.
Begin the day with a stroll through the Great Market Hall, the largest and oldest market in the city — and one that is best visited in the morning when it’s liveliest. Browse through three floors of fresh produce, meats, and trinkets. The top floor offers delicious but absurdly expensive food for takeaway. I purchased freshly made lángos — fried dough topped with meats and cheeses — that I didn’t realize was around $20 USD until it was too late! Consider grabbing breakfast elsewhere to avoid these high prices. Regardless, the market itself is a must-see, even if avoiding making a purchase.
Next, hop on the metro for thirty minutes or grab a fifteen minute Uber to the beautiful Margitsziget Island. The 250 acre island is located directly between Buda and Pest and named after Saint Margaret, a nun who lived in a medieval convent on the land. It is filled with walking paths, gardens, and small cafes, among many things. Walk or rent bikes and pedal cars to explore the 1.5 mile long area at a faster pace.
It’s time to explore Buda. Remember that this side of the city is extremely hilly so stairs and steep roads are ubiquitous. Walking from Margitsziget takes about fifty minutes and involves at least 100 steps; so if this isn’t your forte, take public transportation or Uber. Another option is to trek along the water on the Buda side then use the funicular near the Chain Bridge to avoid the climb. Regardless of how you arrive, you’ll likely be starving after the trek. We didn’t find many restaurants on our walk over, so we caved and ate at the pricey yet tasty and historic Halászbástya Étterem on the Fisherman’s Bastion. This iconic landmark, named after the fisherman’s guild in the Middle Ages tasked with guarding this area, provides exceptional panoramic views. Dining on its terraces is worth the splurge. We were lucky and got a spot without a reservation; but I’d recommend booking ahead of time if this is important to you.
Later join a special paid walking tour of the Buda Castle District and the Hospital in the Rock, an underground cave system used as a hospital and nuclear bunker during World War II and the Cold War. It is now a museum. The district portion includes a stop by the Matthias Church where Hungarian Kings were crowned, the Sándor Palace where the president of Hungary resides, and the Ruszwurm, the oldest confectionery in the country. Learn that this area is older than Pest as the royalty and rich settled early on in the hills of Buda for protection and defense against invaders. The next portion, the tour of the museum, runs about one hour. Utilizing realistic wax figures, it recreates lifelike scenes to showcase the purposes of the bomb shelter and medical complex. Bring a jacket as it gets cold underground.
Note: I highly recommend the museum. This combined tour occurs every day at 2pm except on Sundays and Mondays when it does not operate. However, if the Hospital in the Rock doesn’t interest you, take a free walking tour of the district instead.
After the tour, grab a drink (reservations required) at the White Raven Skybar & Lounge, the rooftop bar with amazing views at the Hilton Budapest in the Buda Castle District. Take the funicular down or walk across the Chain Bridge to return to Pest to hop aboard an evening cruise down the Danube for an exceptional panorama of the city lit up at night. If still up for another cocktail after disembarking, stop by one of the numerous “boat bars” along the water. Spoon is my favorite.
Spend the final day choosing between several different options. Interested in doing something different? Take a day trip to Bratislava, Slovakia; which is small enough that it really only merits one quick day. Want to stay in Budapest? Join the Jewish or Communism walking tours to learn more about the harrowing eras of the country. Yearning to have a spa day? Visit the famous Széchenyi Thermal Bath to see why Budapest is known as the “City of Spas”. Choose your own adventure.
Note: Truthfully, I wasn’t impressed by the baths upon entering and turned around before purchasing a ticket as the pools were overwhelmingly crowded. Perhaps I would have actually visited if it were earlier in the day and therefore less populated.
Finally, enjoy a cocktail in the separate bar area of Twentysix Budapest then have dinner at the Hungarian classic, VakVarjú. Reservations are highly recommended for both establishments.
Spending more time in Eastern Europe? Check out my guides on Bucharest, Romania, Belgrade, Serbia and Slovenia.
--

Title: (Hungary) Budapest: The City That Feels Like a Postcard
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Why Everyone Falls in Love With Budapest (Even If They Don’t Expect To)
Look, I didn’t expect to fall head over heels for Budapest. I really didn’t. It wasn’t even at the top of my travel list. But there I was — one lazy evening by the Danube, sipping cheap Hungarian wine, watching the city lights sparkle like someone accidentally scattered diamonds across the river — and I got it. I finally got why people who visit Budapest never shut up about it.
Budapest sneaks up on you like that. It’s not flashy like Paris or crowded like Rome. It’s got this raw, quiet charm — equal parts old-world nostalgia and youthful, rebellious energy. A little rough around the edges, but that’s part of the magic.
So if you’re even thinking about a trip to Europe, let me tell you why Budapest deserves to be on your list. And yeah, I’ll throw in some practical info about transport, prices, and how not to get ripped off (because we’ve all been there).
It’s hard to explain this without sounding like a walking travel brochure, but Budapest is absurdly beautiful. The kind of beautiful that makes you stop mid-walk to take it all in.
The city is split in two by the Danube River. On one side, you’ve got Buda — the hilly, quiet, castle-filled side that looks straight out of a fairy tale. On the other, Pest — flat, lively, buzzing with cafes, ruin bars, and late-night energy.
Crossing the iconic Chain Bridge, especially at night, is basically a rite of passage. The Parliament building glows like a golden crown, the castle up on the hill looks down like a protective big brother, and everything feels cinematic. It’s the kind of place where even your terrible iPhone photos look frame-worthy.
If you’re like me, you judge a city by how fun it is to get lost in. Budapest? 10/10 on the lost-and-loving-it scale.
Just walk. Seriously. Around every corner, you’ll stumble onto something — a hidden courtyard, a tiny cafe pouring strong coffee, street art popping off crumbling walls.
The Jewish Quarter is full of life, history, and those famous ruin bars (more on that later). Andrássy Avenue feels like the Champs-Élysées’ cooler, less expensive cousin. And then there’s Fisherman’s Bastion, which looks like it was plucked straight from a Disney movie.
Bonus? It’s all surprisingly affordable, so you won’t feel guilty grabbing an extra coffee or beer while you explore.
Hungarian food might not win any points for being health-conscious, but if you love rich, hearty, comforting meals? You’re in for a treat.
Goulash soup — rich broth, tender beef, paprika for days. It warms you up from the inside, especially if you’re here in winter.
Lángos — deep-fried dough topped with sour cream and cheese. Yes, your arteries might protest, but your tastebuds will send thank-you notes.
And of course, the sweet stuff. You can’t leave without trying Kürtőskalács, or chimney cake — crispy on the outside, soft and sugary inside, often filled with Nutella or ice cream because, well, Europe.
Pro tip? Skip the tourist trap restaurants near major attractions. Duck into side streets or head to the markets (like Great Market Hall) for authentic, affordable eats.
You haven’t really done Budapest until you’ve been to a ruin bar. These are old, abandoned buildings — once apartments or factories — transformed into quirky, graffiti-covered, fairy-light-strewn pubs.
The most famous? Szimpla Kert. Yeah, it’s touristy. But also? Totally worth it.
Think mismatched furniture, old bicycles hanging from ceilings, vintage TVs turned into fish tanks. It’s weird. It’s wonderful. It’s Budapest at its best — unpolished, unexpected, unforgettable.
After all that walking, eating, and drinking, you’ll need to soak those tired legs. Enter: Budapest’s famous thermal baths.
The Széchenyi Baths are the most iconic — huge outdoor pools surrounded by yellow Neo-Baroque buildings. Sitting in naturally warm, mineral-rich waters while the steam rises and snow falls? Unreal. It feels like a scene from some aristocratic European fantasy.
If you want something quieter, check out Gellért Baths — same thermal goodness, but a bit less crowded and arguably even more beautiful inside.
Budapest is surprisingly accessible. Flights from major European cities are often dirt cheap thanks to budget airlines like Ryanair or Wizz Air. I paid about €60 round trip from Berlin, but prices vary.
From the airport (Liszt Ferenc International), it’s super easy to get into the city:
Once you’re in the city? The metro, trams, and buses are reliable and affordable. Single tickets are around €1.30, but day passes save money if you’re hopping around a lot.
Budapest is one of the best-value cities in Europe for what you get. Here’s a rough idea:
Food, drinks, attractions — it all feels refreshingly affordable compared to Western Europe.
Here’s the thing: Budapest isn’t loud about how beautiful it is. It doesn’t shove its history or architecture or nightlife in your face. But it lingers.
It’s the way the old trams rattle by as the sun sets. It’s the quiet courtyards filled with ivy and cracked tiles. It’s the unexpected friendliness of locals when you ask for directions. It’s the weird mix of melancholy and hope that seems stitched into the city’s DNA.
You leave Budapest feeling like you’ve discovered a secret. Like you stumbled onto something special most people overlook. And trust me, once you’ve felt that, you’ll want to come back.
Absolutely. Whether you’re a budget backpacker, a romantic couple, a solo explorer, or someone who just wants to eat, soak, and wander — you’ll find your version of Budapest.
And who knows? Maybe you’ll sit by the Danube at sunset, just like I did, and realize you’ve fallen for this quiet, unexpected, unforgettable city too.
--
--
Global logistics expert with experience living in multiple countries. Sharing insights on international trade, diverse cultures, and travel adventures

Title: Budapest: Three Days, Two Sides, One Unforgettable City
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

--
4
Listen
Share
Budapest is just a one-hour flight from Frankfurt, yet somehow it had always managed to stay on my “someday” travel list – until recently. After hearing so many glowing reviews from my friends who went there, I decided it was finally time to visit the Hungarian capital. And I wanted it to be special.
I knew Budapest had a rich and complicated past. It’s a city that’s lived through the fall of Habsburg Empire, two world wars, decades of Soviet control, and then independence, only to later become one of the more controversial members of the European Union. Its president, Viktor Orbán, is seen by some as the EU’s troublemaker, and by others as a national hero standing up for Hungary’s interests against Brussels bureaucracy.
My husband Jacob’s birthday was on October 10th, so I surprised him with a three-day trip to Budapest. It turned out to be the perfect gift – for both of us.
After landing at BUD airport, I quickly withdrew some local forints from an ATM, bought a 3-day public transportation pass, and we hopped on a bus to the city center.
Ironically, the only time we needed cash was to use the city’s public toilets. Everything else – restaurants, cafés, museums, even parking garages – happily accepted card payments.
We stayed in Pest, the flat and lively part of the city, located on the eastern side of the Danube. Our apartment was in a grand building from the early 20th century, built when Hungary was part of the powerful Austro-Hungarian Empire. The building had a certain faded opulence, and when we entered through its massive doors, we stepped into a spacious inner courtyard that felt like a quiet oasis in contrast to the bustling streets just outside.
The stillness of the courtyard, the gentle echo of footsteps on stone, the soft light filtering through iron balconies – something about it got to me. I know it sounds a little silly, but I went back to the apartment and changed my dress to fit the mood. For a moment, I imagined myself as a high-society lady from another century. A bit of harmless fantasy – but one that made me feel strangely at home.
From our place, we were just a 10-minute walk to the majestic Hungarian Parliament building. The views from Pest across to the hills of Buda and Óbuda were breathtaking, especially as the golden-hour light swept across the rooftops and bridges.
Despite my concern that Budapest might be dimly lit at night due to the ongoing energy crisis in Europe since 2022, I was delighted to see that the city had not sacrificed its evening magic. The Chain Bridge, Parliament, and surrounding churches and streets were all warmly illuminated. It gave the city a cozy, welcoming glow, especially as we walked along the Danube that first chilly October evening.
Crossing the Chain Bridge to Buda felt like traveling back in time. While the apartment had sparked my 1920s fantasy, the streets of Buda pulled me firmly back into 2023, with their calm atmosphere, historical depth, and incredible views over the river. It was such a contrast to Pest’s high energy. Pest is where you go for fun and food, and people-watching; Buda is where you slow down and breathe.
That first night in Budapest, I remember standing on the bridge with Jacob, the cold wind tugging at my coat, the lights dancing on the water, and thinking: Why did I wait so long to come here?
Budapest made a strong first impression – so strong that I already knew one visit wouldn’t be enough.

Title: A Hungarian Tale: Discovering the Charm of Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There’s something truly magical about Budapest, a city where history and modernity dance together under the soft glow of the Danube. My journey through this enchanting capital was a mix of awe-inspiring sights, heartwarming moments, and a few unexpected adventures.
I kicked off my trip with a visit to the House of Terror, a museum that leaves you both haunted and humbled. It’s a stark reminder of Hungary’s turbulent past, with exhibits that make you pause and reflect on the resilience of the human spirit.
But it wasn’t all somber. The next stop was the Budapest Castle and Fisherman’s Bastion, a place so beautiful I had to see it twice — once by day and again under the cover of night. Imagine standing there, the lights of the city twinkling below, with the majestic Parliament building standing proudly in the distance. It was as if the entire city was laid out like a masterpiece, just for me. The serenity of the Bastion made it my favorite spot, offering a panoramic view that felt like a scene straight out of a fairy tale.
Speaking of cinematic moments, strolling across the Chain Bridge at night brought back memories of a Bollywood movie called Raabta. As I hummed the tune from the film, I couldn’t help but feel like the leading character in my own story, the city playing the perfect backdrop.
Of course, no trip is complete without a little adventure — or misadventure, in my case. While exploring the city, we were caught on a tram without a valid ticket. Picture this: we were confidently cruising along with our group ticket, only to discover it had somehow vanished. Despite our best efforts to explain, the tram inspectors weren’t having any of it, and we ended up paying a hefty fine. As international students, this was a blow to our budget, but we didn’t let it spoil our day. Instead, we laughed it off and headed straight to the House of Parliament to soak in more of the city’s rich history.
Another highlight was the Gellért Hill, where I found myself surrounded by breathtaking views and a sense of calm that’s hard to describe. The city seemed to whisper its secrets as I wandered through, feeling more at peace with each step.
The Museum of Ethnography and House of Music was a treat for the senses, offering a deeper understanding of Hungary’s cultural roots. Each exhibit was a doorway into the soul of the nation, and I found myself completely immersed in the stories they told.
The Central Market Hall was an absolute feast — not just for the eyes, but for the taste buds too. Cheaper than Italy and bursting with flavors, it was a paradise for food lovers. Even as a vegetarian, I found plenty to indulge in, proving that good food knows no borders.
The Ferris Wheel of Budapest gave off serious London vibes, and while we decided to skip the ride due to the price, the view from below was worth every moment. We wrapped up our day with a visit to Heroes’ Square and Vajdahunyad Castle, each place steeped in history and brimming with stories waiting to be discovered.
And let’s not forget the poignant Shoes on the Danube Bank memorial, a tribute to the lives lost during one of history’s darkest times. It’s a simple yet powerful reminder of the city’s resilience and the importance of remembering our past.
On our last night, we decided to dive into Budapest’s legendary nightlife. I’m talking about the Ruin Bars — and if you haven’t heard of them, you’re in for a treat. These bars are unlike anything I’ve ever experienced. Picture this: abandoned buildings transformed into eclectic spaces filled with mismatched furniture, vibrant art, and a vibe that’s both laid-back and buzzing with energy. The one we visited, Szimpla Kert, felt like stepping into a different world, where every corner had something new to discover. Whether it was the quirky décor, the lively crowd, or the amazing music, the ruin bars truly captured the spirit of Budapest — blending the old with the new in the most unexpected ways.
Despite a few hiccups, my Budapest adventure was a whirlwind of beauty, history, and unforgettable experiences. The city’s mix of old-world charm and vibrant energy left me feeling both invigorated and at peace. Whether it was the stunning architecture, the delicious food, or the warm company of new friends, Budapest cast a spell on me that I’ll carry with me for a long time.

Title: Why Budapest is an underrated European travel destination
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Near the end of June, I met my fiancée in Budapest for a two-week summer vacation. When I first told my father about my summer travel plans, he lovingly mocked me, lamenting that there was nothing interesting about the capital of Hungary that made it a worthwhile site to visit.
He’s not alone in his thoughts as most people don’t think of visiting Budapest compared to other European cities. A simple Google search turns up Rome, Paris and Barcelona as some of the top European cities to visit, but Budapest never makes the list.
When tourists do travel to Budapest, often the Hungarian capital serves as a starting point or end point for river cruises — but never a destination on its own.
However, after having spent two weeks of the summer travelling throughout Budapest, I can attest that it is vastly underrated as a potential travel hotspot on its own.
From an array of culinary classics to stunning views, there is so much to do, see and experience in Hungary’s capital. But this isn’t intended to be a travel guide. Well, sort of — there might be some pearls of travelling wisdom and Hungarian hotspots sprinkled…

--

Title: Budapest 2023: The Old Town of Buda
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
14
Share
In my first two posts about Budapest, I wrote about how young and vibrant the city is and what a great choice it is for a food lover, especially if you are a vegetarian like me.
All of it was reserved for the Pest part of the city and now the time has come for me to share my Buda travel experience.
The Hungarian capital used to be three separate cities, which joined together to form Budapest in 1873. The three former cities were originally known as Buda, Pest, and Óbuda.
The distance between Buda and Pest is only 844 meters, separated by the Danube, which is the second-longest river in Europe after the Volga in Russia.
But the two parts of the city are completely different in all the respects I can imagine.
Pest, located on the east bank of the river, is where all of the action happens — the place to be touristy, hang out and have fun.
Buda, situated on the west side of the Danube, is very conservative and quiet. It is the place to go for a leisurely sightseeing experience. It is also a perfect place to go on a first date to get to know each other or have your fashion pictures taken on a nice sunny day. The background is stunning.
East versus West. Is it not what the modern history of Europe is all about? We have seen how the EU, which was established with the Maastricht Treaty in 1992 and was consisting at first only of the 12 West European countries, expanded gradually to the East. Hungary…

Title: Where to Stay in Budapest: The Best Neighborhoods For Your Visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Posted: 10/29/2023 | October 29th, 2023
Budapest is one of the most fun — and most underrated — cities in Europe. While it’s become more popular in recent years, it still sees only a fraction of tourists compared to London or Paris (about 80% fewer, to be exact).
Popular with backpackers who come to enjoy the lively nightlife, it is also bursting with incredible historic sights, lots of cheap eats, and a plethora of relaxing thermal baths. There’s a ton to see and do, and it’s super affordable compared to Western Europe.
Since it actually comprises three cities (Buda, Pest, and Obuda), picking the right area to stay in is important. While Budapest isn’t massive, you’ll waste a lot of time in transit if you don’t pick the right area for your plans.
To help you save time and money, here’s my list of the best neighborhoods, so you know exactly where to stay in Budapest. These are the areas I stay in myself, because they are close to all the action, so you never have to travel far to get around.
Located on the Buda side of town, this popular district is home to Buda Castle, Fisherman’s Bastion, and the towering Gellért Hill, which offers stunning views over the city. The famous Rudas and Gellért Baths (popular thermal spas) are also here. It’s a gorgeous area to stay in and leans upscale, with plenty of luxe accommodations and many fancy eateries. The photogenic Széchenyi Chain Bridge, which connects to District V, is nearby too.
Best places to stay in the Castle District:
This is the heart of the city, so if it’s your first time or you only have a few nights, stay here. You’ll be within walking distance of many of the top sights, including the massive Parliament building as well as St. Stephen’s Basilica. The photogenic chain bridge is nearby too, as is the massive Central Market. Just keep in mind that this district isn’t the cheapest. But if you want to splurge (a little or a lot), then it won’t disappoint!
Best places to stay in Parliament & Belváros:
This budget-friendly area, located on the Pest side of town, is home to the most popular thermal bath, Széchenyi. There are many other tourist sites too, such as the Terror Museum and the Opera House. Andrássy Avenue, a UNESCO site meant to imitate the famous Champs-Élysées in Paris, is also here.
While there is plenty to see and do, the neighborhood is not crammed with hotels like other areas. That means you get a good mix of convenience (you can still walk downtown) while also experiencing a bit more of the local pace of life.
Best places to stay in Terézváros:
The Dohány Street Synagogue is a must-see stop for anyone who visits Budapest. However, the main draw in this district is the nightlife. Specifically, the ruin bars.
Once underground party venues hidden away in abandoned buildings, they are now a massive part of the city’s thriving nightlife. The bars are unique and eclectic, unlike any other bar you’ve been to — a must for first-time visitors. The most popular (and coolest) bar, Szimpla Kert, and the massive Instant-Fogas Complex (a ruin bar and club) are both in this district.
The popular Karaván outdoor food market (right near Szimpla) is also here, offering a wide variety of amazing eats. And if you’re vegan, some of the best veg restaurants in town are nearby.
Best places to stay in the Jewish Quarter:
***
While there are lots of other districts to stay in Budapest, these are the neighborhoods most travelers spend all their time in — including myself. If you’re here to see the main sights, enjoy the nightlife, learn about the city’s past, and feast on its incredible cuisine, these are the best neighborhoods to focus on. They won’t disappoint!
My detailed 200+ page guidebook is made for budget travelers like you! It cuts out the fluff found in other guides and gets straight to the practical information you need to travel while in Europe. It has suggested itineraries, budgets, ways to save money, on and off the beaten path things to see and do, non-touristy restaurants, markets, bars, safety tips, and much more! Click here to learn more and get your copy today.
Book Your Flight Use Skyscanner to find a cheap flight. They are my favorite search engine because they search websites and airlines around the globe, so you always know no stone is left unturned.
Book Your Accommodation You can book your hostel with Hostelworld as they have the biggest inventory and best deals. If you want to stay somewhere other than a hostel, use Booking.com as they consistently return the cheapest rates for guesthouses and cheap hotels.
If you’re looking for more places to stay, here is a complete list of my favorite hostels in Budapest!
Don’t Forget Travel Insurance Travel insurance protects you against illness, injury, theft, and cancellations. It’s comprehensive protection in case anything goes wrong. I never go on a trip without it as I’ve had to use it many times in the past. My favorite companies that offer the best service and value are:
Looking for the Best Companies to Save Money With? Check out my resource page for the best companies to use when you travel. I list all the ones I use to save money when I’m on the road. They save you money when you travel too.

Some even go as far as to say it’s their favourite European city. Budapest has a special charm that I can’t quite put my finger on. It has beautiful architecture, but so does every other European city I’ve visited. Is it because it’s a melting pot of cultures? Tourists from every country flock here for any number of reasons.
Buda (the hilly part on one side of the Danube) and Pest (the flat side where most of the city lies) together make the famous, much talked about, city of Budapest. And if you’re in the know, the pronunciation is more like Budapesht.
Is it because I’m crook* that I’m not appreciating all of its charms? Or have I simply been spoiled by Poland? Or a little of each? I decided I’d get out of my sickbed and do a little reccie of my neighbourhood. Perhaps, even pop into the church to check out any stained glass? St Stephen’s Basilica is maybe 100 metres away. When I was here in 2011 with my sister, niece and daughters, we walked into the church for…

Title: Budapest: Best City in Eastern Europe?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

Member-only story
--
Share
Why Budapest is second to none in Eastern Europe
Recently, I returned to the one and only magical Hungarian capital of Budapest, exactly a year after my first visit when I was road tripping the Balkans!
Budapest is renowned to be one of the most impressive and picturesque cities in Europe, and it’s also famous for its never sleeping nightlife scene and tasty Hungarian food on offer.
It is thus a popular hotspot for many different kinds of tourists: casual city getaway tourists, architecture and history geeks, nature lovers, party goers and nightlife enthusiasts as well as foodies.
Obviously many cities in Europe also offer all the above and thus attract the same type and number of visitors each year.
But on a personal note, especially when it comes to Eastern Europe, Budapest is quite definitely second to none, and let me explain to you why!
First of all, Budapest is just as pretty, impressive and utterly gorgeous and astonishing as a city as its famous neighbour Vienna, Austria’s capital which is renowned to be Europe’s most liveable city.

Title: BUDAPEST
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
13
Listen
Share
The beautiful city, glorious past and rich present
Budapest is the capital of Hungary and one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. It lies on the Danube River that divides it into two sections: Buda and Pest. Both sides are wonderful. The city has a very interesting history, very vibrant culture, an up-and-coming economy, and a favorite destination of travelers around the world.
Short History of Budapest
Ancient in a very sense, as long as the history can have been, Budapest comes since Romans first inhabited the place where they built towns around “Aquincum”, while after that land got populated by various different tribes such as Huns and Slavs and other related groups of people-Avars. In the ninth century, the Hungarian tribes set foot in the place as well, giving an emerging strong Hungarian kingdom rise at the same time, growing in power over periods from one century to the others.
From the 1500s till more than 150 years later, the city remained under the Ottoman Empire, thereby leaving Turkish baths and such influences. Following that, Austria ruled Hungary for so long that this city became part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. Then, there was a burst of urbanization in this city with most of the famous buildings surrounding it.
However, in the 20th century, obstacles came to Budapest. During World War II, much destruction had occurred in Budapest and after that Soviet occupation continued until 1989. After 1989, Hungary became free, and modernisation began in Budapest.Culture of Budapest
Budapest is rich in culture and creativity. Old and new styles can be seen together. From Gothic to Baroque to Art Nouveau, the style of architecture varies. Some of the world’s most popular landmarks include the Hungarian Parliament building, Buda Castle, and Fisherman’s Bastion.
Hungarians love music, dance, and theater. They enjoy classical music and folk dance. There are several theaters, concert halls, and art galleries in Budapest. Traditional Hungarian folk music is unique and beautiful, and you can hear it at cultural events and festivals.
There are also the food aspects so profoundly tied up in Hungarian culture, for instance, the dishes which are goulash-a stew, rich and meaty and containing potatoes and paprika-and chimney cakes, sweetmeats shaped like spiral pastries.
Budapest is the central economic hub of Hungary. Since the collapse of communism in 1989, the city has been witnessing rapid growth and has, over the years, come to become a significant finance hub in Central Europe. Significant industries of Budapest include finance, tourism, technology, and manufacturing.
Now many international companies have their offices in Budapest, employing more people and attracting additional investment. In addition, the highly educated workforce and general business environment of the city are also among its strengths. Recently, the technology sectors have risen significantly, and many startups have made their base in Budapest.
Budapest Tourism
Millions of people visit the city every year to see historic sites, beautiful buildings, and unique attractions. The most popular destinations in Budapest are:Thermal BathsBudapest thermal baths attract millions of visitors due to the natural hot springs under the city. Local favorites Széchenyi and Gellért Baths attract visitors from all over.The Danube RiverFor starters, the Danube has both nice views of Buda and Pest, particularly by night when the buildings all become lit up.
Ruin BarsIn Jewish Quarters, there exist known ruin bars — those small-time bars that people begin opening in old buildings but that have been abandoned by mankind. Each bar features quite distinct furniture and colors along with decorations, and then finally becomes unique.
Museums and ArtBudapest has many museums showing Hungarian art, history, and culture. The best include the Museum of Fine Arts and the Hungarian National Gallery.
FestivalsThere are numerous festivals held throughout the year in Budapest, including the Sziget Festival, Europe’s biggest music festival, and the Budapest Wine Festival.
Conclusion
Budapest is rich in history and full of the culture of life. Budapest has great architecture, fine food, a good economy, and lots of interesting things to do. You want to relax in a thermal bath, explore old buildings, or enjoy local music and food; Budapest has got it all.

Title: budapest by belgrade
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Listen
Share
arrive in istanbul airport early morning get your bearings need to snag wifi to download mapsme for turkey forgot to tackle that one in sri lanka before takeoff the wifi here takes some hoops jump them get cash exchange figure out transport to hostel neighborhood get through passport control.
part of this on the move/keeping the senses sharp has to do with handling what is often initial aversion. i arrived in istanbul the way i have in a handful of other cities: tired, a tad confused, feeling an outsider, accompanied by a little guy on my shoulder asking me why i’m doing this.
you could be home eating a cheeseburger. you could wake up in your own bed. you could be on a beach in thailand. you could be in the laotian mountains where your ten dollar bills lasted all day. etc.
you get over that hill and at sunset you find you aren’t thinking those thoughts — you haven’t been during this whole walk come to think of it. where did they go? the next morning the neighborhood is a little more yours, on account of the walk you took last night. a few more of the signs make sense. by lunch time your heart is where your feet are, and now you are traveling again. world/oyster.
—
fuckin earthquakes. istanbul the second area, bangkok the first, i’m visiting after a pretty dramatic earthquake event. whistling past the graveyard. nobody died but it was big and a decent amount of people got hurt jumping out of buildings. these people are traumatized by earthquakes. in 1999 a quake killed 18,000 in northwest turkey. a real doozy in the southeast in 2023 claimed over 50,000 lives. i saw people during my visit sleeping in tents in parks, the most recent shakeup reminding them all too clearly that the plates of the earth under istanbul are locked. it’s a “powder keg”, as one professor put it. some day the building stress will burst.
—
i hopped off a bus one day before my destination because i thought i might die if i didn’t get some bread i was hungry particularly for bread with some of the chunk of butter i had in my backpack for just such an occasion and without having a clue that i was close to something cool i turned a corner and stumbled across a massive, beautiful wall that’s part of the aqueduct of valens, a 4th century roman structure. and that is kind of wild, being from somewhere where nothing is old, to stumble upon such a thing in the middle of a city.
—
there’s a passage in orhan pamuk’s red haired woman, that i can’t find because i no longer have the book, about seeing old men in istanbul passing their days on cafe patios. this is a signature feature of this part of the world to me, as little time as i have spent in it. i found the men in athens charming for it. on a morning walk many people are clearly in motion to get somewhere: tourists to a site, young people to work. fellas in their 60’s or more are just sitting on stools in their black jackets smoking smegs and having espresso. shooting the shit with their dudes. it’s 50 and sunny and breezy. why not. i join them and it’s nice.
—
i had been told the neighborhood of kadikoy was an essential visit in istanbul. i asked the man working the hostel if there’s anything i should do there.
“you should not have a plan this go to kadikoy. just sometimes is better no plan. walk around.”
music to my ears my friend. a great afternoon spent.
—
a hostel owner said when he opened his spot in sultanahmet in the early 90’s there were only a few of them around. not many tourists came then, but he did have some cool stories about caravans of hippies that used to meet there before driving to nepal every year. now sultanahmet is densely packed with tourist accommodations. he gave me a couple cups of cay as we chatted before i checked out. on a day committed to sightseeing touristy type stuff i drank maybe eight cups of cay. they are served in very small portions. you are meant to consume many tasty little cups.
“‘you drink cay all day.’‘yes of course life is short.’”
—
polis brigades — i just happened to be staying in the neighborhood of ferikoy when and where, according to the bbc, “50,000 police officers deployed to the city as authorities attempt(ed) to crack down on May Day protests…Public transport was shut down to stop people reaching Taksim Square, where demonstrations have been banned since 2013.”
in some sense people protest on may day every year in the name of labor rights, but this year the government is a little more on edge. mainly because president erdogan’s government arrested the mayor of istanbul on trumped up corruption charges. apparently corrupt assholes who have manipulated power for a quarter century don’t like it when popular mayors voice dissent and it happens to be dissent that the masses agree with. some 400 protestors were arrested.
all i wanted to do was get a bus to a ferry location so i could go to the princes islands. blockages on the streets made this difficult. my bag was checked to walk across one road. impossible to get a taxi. i just walked to the ferry but since that was downhill and not exactly short i was really hoping after the day trip the shenanigans would be in enough of the past that i could taxi back up it, but that was also not possible.
i feel quite often, in life and not just traveling, like the very confused old man i saw at the cordoned off kabatas bus stop. he had a bag of groceries. i watched him on and off for a couple minutes while he glanced around and then ahead again at the shut off access. he appeared stupefied. i imagine him leaving home with a story playing in his head about how he would get home from the river and the way he would get home from the river was a bus station that operated with incredible reliability. all the sudden standing, wondering why the world is not doing what he had thought it would. perplexed.
a good hike and pleasant company on the island. raki with a view.
—
at aga hamami men have been getting scrubbed down by men here in non-gay fashion simce 1454. turkish bath style. azim with tender loving care gave life to my muscles sore from miles and miles of concrete walking.
after the bubble rub he told me to sit up and was pouring bowls of water over me. baptism-esque. he said “ready” and without even thinking of what the question might mean i said yes — in for a penny in for a pound — and he dumped a bowl of cold water down the front of my shorts, smiled at me, and said “good morning”.
it’s substantially more comfortable to do meandering travel days when it’s not 95 degrees. my entire belongings weigh quite little and i don’t mind carrying them around a city at 55 degrees. i can bounce around istanbul cafes and parks and bars for the whole day with my bag on my back before making the night bus. show up in the morning in sofia, bulgaria find a coffee shop read a bit sightsee a little and check into the hostel in the afternoon. in southeast asia i would have been, well, smellier, with that strategy.
at 8:11 on a saturday in sofia no coffee shops are open. i stopped into one that two people were seated outside of, having coffee. the door was open. the emplyees looked at me and said “we are not open yet.” a place literally called coffee lab wasn’t open either. how do these people do it. i do not know. sometime around 9 i stumbled upon a fix for my addiction.
—
if i drive 7 hours from my home people will be dressed and talk very like where i left. this idea is foreign in europe. languages, or at minimum accents, change quickly. it’s almost as if our culture was too young before modernity made interconnectedness the norm for things to silo off much.
in a crowded istanbul beer hall full of my peers i noted only one person that was not covered head to toe in neutral colors. in sofia they wear colors, some of them haphazardly combined. some clothes remind you of that store the buckle. this is not a compliment. it’s painting with a broad brush but let’s just say the bulgarians of sofia are not as pretty as the turks of istanbul. then again, bulgaria is not a pretty sounding word, and there’s that adage about how people will become their names.
—
i arrived sick which is not so much fun. sick is when it’s really nice to be at home. on your couch. it’s not a joy to be in the public. you feel like you’re gross to them and you don’t want to see them either. i saw a doctor for fifty bucks and he helped me out a bit.
—
“I don’t mean a casual desire for travel, not a tourist’s curiosity for sites and landmarks and languages and new faces, but a precise and uncomplicated conviction that the world was available to me.” — i think this is also from that pamuk book but now i can’t figure it out. and i feel that way often now. out here.
—
i happened to be sitting in a sofia coffee shop when i read in the return by hisham matar a passage about an italian architect who consulted on works on the st. alexander nevsky cathedral in sofia. serendipitous. i walked over because that’s a nice little low energy activity for someone under the weather and i like sitting in houses of worship.
i have been doing this in buildings belonging to a number of faiths on a couple different continents lately. the instinct of most secular americans is to start off with one’s problems of the metaphysical claims of various religions— but if you can just get over yourself enough and just sit there they are often a quite nice place to be.
—
when people at home ask me what people are “like” somewhere i often say something like people are nice everywhere and a smile is universal. a smile is not, in fact, universal. i felt very much like i was in eastern europe once i got to sofia. a number of smiles met stone walls. people aren’t mean. they just aren’t all opening up to you and that’s fine. i lived with an estonian couple once who was not unkind but who took a long time to warm up to me and actually have a conversation, considering there was only me and one other person they interacted with daily. us living in a secluded farmhouse.
—
both the cashier at the mini mart who struck up a conversation with me that began with the powers of the bacteria in bulgarian yogurt and had a dabble in the minnesota timberwolves and the bulgarian-post-punk-looking hostel worker said a day trip to plovdiv, the oldest continuously inhabited city in europe, was a “must”. these are the types of people you listen to, and they were right.
another border another random selection of me for bag searching. the jacked border patrol guy presents as “i listen to serbian jordan peterson”. not a compliment. he looked personally insulted when he asked what i was doing in serbia and i said just traveling. i had to strongly fight the urge to tell him to look at all the fucking stamps from the last couple months in the passport he kept waving up and down and staring at my picture in.
—
david’s wife died seven years ago, his kids are now both at university, and he recently retired, so now he does things like bicycle the entire length of the danube and share an evening of large red wine decanters and mugs of beer with generally disheveled thirty something backpackers from sauk centre, minnesota.
—
the belgrade fortress makes clear why the city has been fought over some 115 times in its history. destroyed and rebuilt 40–45 times. it’s prime location, resting on top of a hill right where the sava and danube rivers connect.
i am left to wonder what that does to a people. how one could possibly argue it wouldn’t lead to some ingrained difference in constitution for its population. how many of these people have family stories? how many have personal stories? i remember shooting pool in thailand with a shellshocked kid — i call him kid because of who i am now but he was a man, early 20’s — who just got done with his military service in israel and when i asked what his position was he said combat soldier and he had ghosts in his eyes. hard to imagine what he’s seen or how it could be left behind.
—
on hostel courtesy. if you’re leaving at 5am then yes you should prepack the night before so to not be fumbling around while people are mid-snooze.
smiles not universal. i was told the 74 and the 72 go to the national park outside of town but the city bus driver on the 74 says no when i ask if he is going to the national park and he closes the door behind me anyways. then i ask him if the 72 goes there and he just shrugs a “who could know” shrug. cool.
spent the first part of the day walking to a city park and the danube beach instead. stopped at a museum in the afternoon and spent a good five or six hours bouncing around old town reading in bars and on cafe patios alone. found a fernet. having an actual bar instead of only tables is a feature of american culture that makes being alone much easier. and easier to meet people. it’s casual to strike up a conversation with the bartender or a fellow bar sitter. it takes a lot more intrusion to approach a table — hey can we be frens!?!?
—
in eastern europe the local population is wholesome park participants. people spend time in parks. it’s nice. i have lived in msp for eight years and not once has someone asked me to meet them in a park to hang out. have a picnic.
very, very committed to statues as a culture. some of the angels appear to be tormented by their task. role, maybe. at eternity it maybe ceases being a task.
—
“perhaps these people are especially devout. look at them in church filling it up on any old day.” i thought that to myself. i then realized it is sunday and not yet noon. time and days have lost themselves two months in to backpacking. eat when i’m hungry. sleep when i fall into it. i drink coffee at absolutely any hour. bus when i’m ready to go.
—
in minneapolis we have the warehouse district which is meant to describe a neighborhood with repurposed old buildings for modern, hip use. the official warehouse district website uses descriptives like “rich culture”, “eclectic”, and “dynamic urban atmosphere”. but the interior of most of those establishments carries the aesthetic taste of white bread with miracle whip. the warehouse district is where culture goes to die. sanitized into submission.
in budapest there is a trend for the last quarter century of ruin bars. they embrace the decay of the buildings, house mismatched furniture, and the decor is like a dive bar regular went to a thrift store on a pound of coke and then collaged the walls. the ruin bars are fantastic. i have described tom’s burnt down cafe on madeline island as mad max meets jimmy buffet concert, and if tom’s was just dropped in the middle of a city it would qualify as a ruin bar. that is the closest thing i can think of to this.
—
i take it as a personal offense that they serve weak ass coffee in budapest in hipster coffee shops. like americano as hot bean water even when you pay for an extra shot.
something about budapest was eating at me after a couple days. not just the weak coffees. maybe just a me thing. who knows. the buildings and museums are undeniably striking. it is a remarkable city. i stayed in one of the cutest hostels i’ve ever seen. sunsets at the river are quite an experience. but something. maybe the crowds, who seem less like travelers than people who are obviously on vacation. an important distinction. maybe feeling like a mark. always paying for the view and not the product. i am glad i went. i was ready to leave. next, croatia.
you can watch the sun set in all sorts of ways. can gaze at the horizon it’s dropping off. can look to the horizon opposite and see the shade darken incrementally. you can stare at the leaves on a tree when they go from lime to mint to night. can watch a line move up the wall of a building until it’s gone and then when it’s gone it really is gone. it is. wrecks me every time. i saw a young girl maybe 12 taking a picture of a flower with a camera not a phone but a camera and that made me feel better.
--
--
find a ninth path. this is water. zorbatheminnesotan@gmail.com

Title: Your 2 Minute Guide to a Week in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Guac is an award-winning travel publication run by an interdisciplinary group of students at Cornell University. This organization is a registered student organization of Cornell University.

--
Listen
Share
By: Mia Arruda
What to do with a week in Budapest? Gaining attention for its Ruin Bars, beautiful architecture, and accessible transportation, Budapest is a great addition to your travel bucket list. Whether cramming in visits to multiple historic sites into one day or taking long breaks to relax at world famous bathhouses, the city has many opportunities for any traveler and a week is the perfect amount of time to explore it all.
The first thing to note when traveling to Budapest is that the city is a combination of three previously independent cities: Buda, Pest, and Obuda. Buda and Pest are divided by the famous Danube River, a peaceful landmark to walk alongside that also serves as a pathway to other cities via day trips by boat. Exploring both sides of the Danube is absolutely essential.
On the Buda side, sightsee at castle hill with its many museums and go back in time to Hungarian history. Take your time in the Hungarian National Gallery and Matthias Church taking in artwork and make sure to grab a pastry at Ruszwurm Confectionery, one of Budapest’s oldest bakeries. Walk around below the castle to see a more calm side of Budapest and don’t be afraid to explore!
On the Pest side, make sure to walk around the Parliament building which grandly overlooks the Danube. The opera house is also a great place to take a tour and listen to a musical sample, but be sure to book the tour in English in advance, especially in high tourist season (or, settle for the tour in Spanish, French, Italian, or German). Wander the galleries at the Museum of Fine Art and Kunsthalle, and take a look at Hero’s Square for even more history and art. If you’re looking for nightlife, Budapest’s Ruin Bars certainly won’t disappoint with their bustling maze-like interiors and colorful light displays.
The city is incredibly well connected; tourists can easily take buses, trains, and trolleys to get to just about any destination. Don’t miss out on taking the oldest electric metro system to a bathhouse and relaxing at one of Budapest’s many natural hot springs. There are options for everyone on both sides of the city to enjoy the warm water as ‘Budapesti’ (Budapest natives) have been doing for centuries.
Budapest, with its tumultuous history, is notably a city to learn a lot from when you visit. Signs of the Austro-Hungarian empire are everywhere-–from the massive parliament building to over the top gilded cafes. The Soviet occupation of Hungary is also still present, and its four decades of history loom over the city, which was largely devastated after WWII.
If you’re lucky to get the chance to visit Budapest, take your time to explore the city completely rather than quickly jumping around tourist attractions. You won’t regret learning from locals and getting a full experience of the city.
Safe travels!
About the Author: Mia Arruda is a freshman from California majoring in Landscape Architecture. One of her favorite travel destinations is Santa Cruz, California because of its beautiful Northern California beaches and relaxed atmosphere.
--
--
Guac is an award-winning travel publication run by an interdisciplinary group of students at Cornell University. This organization is a registered student organization of Cornell University.
Welcome! We hope to bring and deliver the diverse beauty of our world to the palms of our readers. Registered Student Organization at Cornell University

Title: Budapest, Hungary🇭🇺
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Our stay in Budapest was awesome. We explored a lot of the city in the first several days, soaking in the history and enjoying the hot sunny weather, and then unfortunately the rain set in and we had a couple of lazy days to end our stay.
We opted to stay in an Air BnB for this destination which was a cozy little apartment in the centre of the city, close to tons of restaurants, stores, and attractions, as well as metro and tram stations. Air BnBs book up fast and so we had booked this a month or more prior, however, our dates did change and so we ended up switching to a different accommodation for our last three days which was just a few hundred meters down the road. As I’ve mentioned before, I love Air BnBs for stays longer than a few days purely because of kitchen access. It is so nice to have the flexibility of making dinner, snacks, a coffee in the morning, rather than always looking for a place to go which also adds up financially.
One of my favourite things to do in any European city is participating in a walking tour. I love doing them in our first couple of days as I find it helps orient you to the city, and you often get some helpful tips and recommendations from your tour guide. Every European city we’ve been to offers several free walking tours, and they’ve all be awesome. The guides are generally locals, often have postsecondary education in history or a related field, and are really passionate and knowledgeable about what they do. I find these by doing a simple Google search for “free walking tours in X city”, but I have found that “freetour.com” is a really good one which aggregates tours offered by different companies, shows reviews, allows you to filter for language, and has a very easy to use app.
In Budapest we did three tours, all through the tour company “Generation Tours”, and they were fabulous. The first was a general tour of the city where we learned some basic Hungarian, the importance of validating your public transit ticket before getting on to avoid very steep fines, and walked by/learned about many large sites such as Liberty Square, Parliament, St. Stephen’s Basilica. We also walked by “Shoes on the Danube Bank”, a Holocaust memorial from 2005, comprised of metal shoes lined up at the edge where many Jewish people were shot and bodies pushed into the river. The shoes are sculpted after real shoes from concentration camps. The shoes were left behind as they were valuable and a needed resource for soldiers during the war. I didn’t take pictures as it didn’t feel right to do so, but this is a really touching memorial and you can see photos with a quick google search.
Our second tour was of Buda Castle. It took us through the history of the city, the changing of hands, through the castle district including the famous Fisherman’s Bastion with views over the city, and ending at the castle itself. You can certainly explore this area on your own, it’s easy to get to, but I do think you get so much more out of your time there with a guide to help provide background and point out details.
The last tour we did here was of the Jewish Quarter which toured us to a few beautiful synagogues and through the Jewish area, discussed Hungary’s role throughout WWII, and shared stories of important individuals who helped save many Jewish people during those dark years. A lot of walking, a lot of information, but a great way to learn about the country’s culture and history.
We spent one of our days taking advantage of the warm sunny weather and exploring City Park. This is a huge area right on the metro line with large green spaces, playgrounds, and little cafes. It was lovely to wander through and sit and enjoy an iced coffee. We also explored Vajdahunyad Vara, an 1896 castle with gorgeous architecture.
At the far end of the park is Budapest Zoo and Botanical Garden which we spent a couple hours wandering through. I don’t always like supporting zoos, and they tend to be less exciting after seeing many of the animals in the wild on our South African Safaris and Asian monkey encounters… but nonetheless it was a really nice way to spend some time outdoors, the gardens/foliage in the area was beautiful. Outside of the zoo is also the famous Szechenyi Thermal Bath but we did not go in partly because we didn’t realize this is where it was so we didn’t have bathing suits with us, but also because we had planned to attend a different thermal bath instead.
We spent a rainy afternoon exploring the House of Terror, a museum in the building that once used as the headquarters during the fascist and communist regimes. It is an incredibly well-done museum with interesting displays and lots of background history, information shared in different formats such as historic footage and recent interviews with subtitles and audio translations, artifacts such as newspaper clippings and soldiers uniforms, and laminated information sheets at the entrance of each room. The basement is a cellar where prisoners were tortured, held, and killed. It is an eerie excursion, and one certainly worth doing.
There is certainly no shortage of restaurants in Budapest, although I will say that compared to some of our previous destinations, there is not as much variety. Hungarian food is flavourful and rich, often heavy on the meat and carbs, light on the vegetables, especially raw ones (similar to our next two stops as well). We of course tried all of the classics including goulash (a rich beef soup often served with bread on the side to soak up that delicious broth), chicken paprikash often served over dumplings that remind me of gnocchi in texture but have very little flavour themselves, and schnitzel. From our experiences, Hungarians do soup/stew very well — packed with flavor, they warm you from the inside out. Somehow we managed to go the week without sampling langos which is a circle of fried dough often topped with sour cream and cheese… sounds delish and I’m not sure how we missed that. Doner kebabs/shawarmas are also common and never fail to be a delicious, quick, cheap lunch. And there are bakeries that produce really tasty freshly baked bread, as well as a variety of pastries, my favourite being whole grain croissants filled with baked plums… a recommendation from my mom which quickly became my go-to when enjoying a cappuccino and sitting on a patio people watching. I’m not a huge beer person, but we of course sampled the local selections as well.
When you search most affordable places to travel, Hungary and Prague are always on the list. This is partly why we chose to visit these places and spend a week+ on them, especially given it is near the end of our travels and we anticipated budget being more important. Compared to many places in Europe, Budapest and Prague were certainly affordable, however, like many places in Europe and worldwide, they have been heavily impacted by Covid and inflation. When comparing menus from 1–2 years ago to their current menu on their Google page, we quickly saw a pattern of prices going up by 50%, sometimes doubling, sometimes even tripling. And so while these places were not outrageously expensive, they were more expensive than we had expected, especially with regard to food and alcohol. Public transit, as well as taxis/rideshare apps, remain quite inexpensive, and attraction tickets were pretty standard.
One of our tour guides told us that the thermal baths are a wonderful thing to do while visiting Budapest, however that there are many of them and some are very overpriced and overrun with tourists, taking away much of the charm and authenticity. He recommended Palatinus Strand Baths on Margaret Island as the best one to visit, as it is popular with locals, very reasonably priced, and beautiful. As I had wanted to see Margaret Island already we planned to follow his recommendation. Unfortunately, that entire plan got rained out. We also planned to do a cruise down the Danube river (either during the day or for sunset with some prosecco), but this was also rained out. Sure, you can do these things in the rain, and some of the baths are indoors, but ultimately we decided that if we were going to do them we wanted to really enjoy them, and being cold and wet would put too much of a damper (literally) on things, making us feel not as great about spending the money on them. We had planned to do these things in the second half of our week there, and we hoped the weather would clear… I guess it’s just a reason to go back! Not that we needed another reason because we really loved Budapest. The amount of history is incomparable to Canada, the buildings are stunning, the prices are reasonable, there are beautiful green spaces, and the atmosphere in the city is lively and draws you in. I’ll wrap up this post by sharing photos of just some of the street art that you see all over the city:
--
--
A Canadian couple on a five month trip around the world sharing our adventures as we go

Title: Discovering The History Of Budapest- Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

No Matter What People Tell You, Words And Ideas Can Change The World.

Member-only story
--
Share
Before visiting Budapest, I had no idea that this was one of the 25 most visited cities in Europe or that this city was the most central point in Europe. I knew very little or nothing about the Hungarian people or Budapest. All the places I visited and my experiences formed my vision of the Hungarian people and Budapest city.
This article is dedicated to all the places that I consider a must-see on a visit to Budapest, but it is also an article dedicated to the history of the Hungarian people and Budapest.
Today we know the capital Budapest by this name, but the truth is that Buda and Pest are two different areas, which like their name, they were not always unified. The Chain Bridge connected the two halves of the city in 1849. However, it was not until 1873 that Budapest's name became one; Pest is the generally flat eastern portion of the city of Budapest, covering about two-thirds of Budapest is separated from Buda by the Danube River. Buda, in turn, is located in the western part and is composed mainly of hills and forests.

Title: Now I’ve Been to Budapest and Bucharest, I’ll Never Get Them Confused Again
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This publication is dedicated to learning about the world around us. The topics covered here range from travel and geography to languages and cultures.

Member-only story
--
7
Share
When I was studying Geography, Budapest and Bucharest were both capitals of countries and Belgrade was the capital of Yugoslavia. I’d often have to think carefully to decide that Budapest was the capital of Hungary and Bucharest was the capital of Romania. After spending time in both, I wondered how such similar-sounding cities could be so different.
I love Budapest. I’ve never met anyone who doesn’t. For me, the fact that it has thermal baths is enough of a drawcard. It doesn’t need anything else. But the beautiful bridges, the beautiful river, the beautiful buildings, the beautiful railway stations, the beautiful dogs: everything is beautiful.
Just look at the difference in accommodation!

Title: Budapest: City of Culinary Delight and So Much More
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
12
Share
Before I traveled to Budapest I never thought that I would enjoy their food that much. My first impression of the city was very favorable, but after spending there two more days I felt like I was falling in love with the city.
And one of the reasons why is its food.
If you read just about any travel guide about visiting Hungary, you will find that when visiting Budapest one absolutely must try Gulash soup. Pretty much the same way the guides insist on you visiting October Fest when in Germany.
Unless you absolutely can not imagine your life without a stew of meat and vegetables, you can skip Gulash in Budapest the same way you can skip drinking overpriced beer in München while watching drunken American tourists puking all over the place during the October Fest.
You would enjoy your German beer so much better sipping it in one of the German Biergarten on a sunny day.
Madal Cafe
Madal is a specialty cafe in Budapest that received its name after the peace philosopher Sri Chinmoy, whose childhood nickname was “Madal”. They have roasted coffee every week in their specialty micro roastery near Budapest since 2014.
Sri Chinmoy is a spiritual teacher who was both a philosopher and an excellent sprinter, winning the ashram championship for 16 consecutive years. In the cafe itself, they put a stature of Sri, which I found unique and interesting.

Today I’ll be your guide on a journey through culture and cuisine!
Buda-Best stole my heart and became a safe place for healing scars. Whenever I face a difficult period in my life, my curing place wipes my tears, when I escape I run to you. Your elegant streets bring harmony to my soul, give me solutions when I question what my future steps should be, and help me overcome what is better left in the past. You can almost feel the history and breathe the love of its stories. Anyone can be skeptical about the country but never of its capital.
“You can’t buy happiness, but you can buy a plane ticket to Budapest. And that’s pretty much the same thing.”
I spent a lot of my childhood and teenage years in Budapest. I always told my little brother, with whom I visited a million times, that when he grows up I want him to take a backpack and go out into the wide world to find his happiness… but that he shouldn’t forget his home.
My home town is located only 100 km from Budapest. I was living between two cultures, Slovak and Hungarian. I believe everyone has a certain bond to a country of their origin, but I have to admit that Bratislava is not as magnificent as Budapest. It’s just…
