Title: Budapest, Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Travel better! Follow the globetrotting adventures of Jacob & Emily Cass.

--
Listen
Share
Budapest was such an awesome city! Although not at the very top, it comes a very close second! It is very open and spread out, yet it still had its nooks and crannies to get lost in. The city reminded us of Brooklyn in NY, it had a trendy/hipster feel with a lot of young people. The nightlife was outrageous, with tons of restaurants to eat at and bars to socialize in, for all sorts of tastes. There were parks to lay around in or many shopping streets to keep you busy. There is something for everyone in Budapest… except a beach which is why Barcelona is still our favorite city visited so far.
Budapest has 23 districts and they are usually indicated by Roman numerals. The more central districts, like downtown, have lower numbers while the outer districts have higher numbers. The best districts to stay in are district V and VI as within these 2 districts you can find a lot of the major landmarks & attractions, along with the widest selection of restaurants, cafes, pubs and bars. Most, if not all, are walkable. We barely used the Metro system but it was very easy to navigate when necessary.
There were countless accommodation options in Budapest especially a huge range of hostels. Booking the day before still allowed us over 40+ hostels to choose from. We ended up staying at 11th Hour Hostel and Cinema which was located right in the middle of downtown. Some other popular hostels in a great location are Wombats, Big Fish, Downtown Oasis, Maverick City Lodge.
Szechenyi Baths and Pool — One of the largest spa complexes of its kind in Europe. The entry ticket is (5000 HUF/ 16 €) which includes the usage of a change room, locker, multiple different pools, saunas, steam rooms and fitness centre. We spent a couple of hours here relaxing in the pools & sweating it up in the saunas. Note: bring your own towel & lunch as there isn’t a large selection of food!
Conquer Budapest Walking tour visiting St Stephen Basilica, Matthias Church, Danube Promenade, Chain Bridge, National Opera House, Castle District (Royal Palace, Matthias Church, Fisherman Bastion). Our guide for this was one of our favourites of our Europe trip so far and we’ve done a lot of ‘free walking tours’. The tour was never boring even though we are slowly but surely getting tired of churches and history, he kept it interesting and fun for the whole 3 hours. The Fisherman Bastion is shown below.
Central Market Hall- A 3 story hall combing shopping and eating. Fresh fruit and vegetable stalls, meats, cheeses, souvenirs, shopping and most importantly a selection of food stalls with portions bigger than you can ever imagine. Classic Hungarian dishes are sold here but come hungry and forget trying to count calories.
Vaci Utca — Vaci Utca is one of the main shopping streets in Budapest and also a very popular tourist drag. The street is lined with cute cafes, great shops and a tonne of Thai massage parlours which we indulged in (do shop around).
Margaret Island — A 2.5km long central island laying in between “buda” and “pest”. A very well kept island with ample to do during the summer months. It’s a beautiful spot to spend an afternoon during the spring/summer. The island has a pool, water park, wildlife park & athletic centre. We strolled here from downtown Budapest or you can take the number 26 bus which is the only vehicle allowed on the island.
Gellert Hill — Panoramic views over Budapest. You can climb the Gellért Hill starting at the Elisabeth Bridge near the Gellért Monument, or you can take the steeper route starting at the Gellért Hotel. You can also take a bus or get there by taxi.
Eating in Budapest was a welcomed treat after indulging in so much pasta and pizza in Italy. Hungary had their typical cuisine but also every other type, so there was never too much repeating. It was cheap, the portions were often of a good size and there were countless restaurants to choose from.
Street food is also very common and convenient in Budapest. At Karavan you can find numerous food trucks in this little outdoor area. Perfect for a quick dinner or a late night snack after spending time at the famous ruin bar, Szimpla Kert.
Below is a list of the typical Hungarian dishes you should try if you are to visit the city! And before you finish, don’t be alarmed when we mention that we did eat all of them.. a few times.
You can easily sample all of these on your own throughout the city but if you enjoy food tours then we suggest signing up for one of the many tours Taste Hungary has to offer.
Hungarians typically eat their biggest meal during lunch so many restaurants offer a “Tourist Menu” which involves a three-course meal for less than $6 (100 HUF), this is often cheaper than ordering just one dish. However, when we weren’t eating a 3-course meal, you could find us at some of our other favourite restaurants:
Bors Gasztrobar — Always a line, freshly made baguette sandwiches, homemade soups & cheap cheap!Drum Cafe — Cheap, classic Hungarian food.Fruccola — Healthy, fresh, create your own salads/sandwiches.Magyar — Classic 3 course restaurant with generous portions. Close to the Grand Central Market but surprisingly not a tourist trap as we had first thought.
Just like restaurants, the nightlife options are endless and generally are within walking distance. We weren’t in Budapest over the weekend but each night had something going on.
Some of you may be aware of what a “Ruin Bar” is, some not… well Budapest is famous for these types of bars. It is simply a bar/pub, inside or next to an old building. The buildings have usually been abandoned and turned into bars by decorating them with many different types of objects, such as paper statues, foreign licence plates, unique lanterns and seats made from cushions, old cars, duck tape, you name it. If you use your imagination you can usually get a picture for what they look like. None of the interior makes sense and generally doesn’t have a theme except looking like ‘designed junk’. If the walls aren’t covered with pictures and objects then they are painted.
Some of the most popular Ruin bars in Budapest are Szimpla Kert, Grandio, Instant, Yellow Zebra Bikes & Bar and Anker’T. If you have to go to only one, make it Szimpla Kert! So much fun and so unique. It’s open during the day, so you can get a better look at the interior. Grandio is a hostel as well as a bar so don’t stay here if you’re wanting to sleep!
Gozsdu Courtyard is another popular area in downtown. Although they aren’t ruin bars, the courtyard/long street has a variety of beer gardens and restaurants and is both popular with locals and tourists. Check out Spiler, one of the biggest restaurants in the area with a solid menu both for food and drinks. The lamb burger was super tasty & recommended.
We were really sad to leave Budapest but until next time…..
Married days survived: 175
[envira-gallery id=”2546"]

Title: A Run-in with Thieves in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
--
26
Share
We exited Szimpla Kert and stepped out into the dark, rustic alleys of Budapest. The fragrant fall air of late October brought hints of change, and this once-ruined city at night gave the impression we were traveling in another world.
While walking the streets in that state of traveler’s bliss, we joked about the twists of fate that had brought the two of us to this place, still buzzing on the beers we had shared in a vintage bathtub in the maze that was the ruin bar we had just left.
As we passed through the alley, a figure moving against the crowd was nonchalantly listing out choice substances to no one in particular, not-so-subtly soliciting interest.
The indulgences of the night had lulled me to let my guard down, and so I thought nothing of her flagging the guy down in the crowded street, and inquiring about the availability of some grass. There were two of us, and just this one man, so what risk was there?
As they conducted a transaction in hushed words, I felt no cause for alarm. My friend was confident in these kinds of situations and…
--
--

Title: Taking the Waters in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

No Matter What People Tell You, Words And Ideas Can Change The World.

Member-only story
--
1
Share
Budapest is renown for its spas — even the zoo has one, with many animals having their own thermal baths (and, apparently, a very high reproductive rate). On a glorious spring day I stood outside the belle epoch Széchenyi Baths, the phrases ‘taking the waters’ and ‘frequented by royalty’ running through my mind. Even the entrance to the baths was a work of wonder.
Inside was all high ceilings and chandeliers. An authoritarian attendant ushered me into a small change room, returning later to lock my clothes away. I shared my change room with half a dozen others — this was no place for false modesty.
And so, to the waters. Outside were two enormous baths (one at 30 degrees C, the other at 34) with a lap pool between them. Inside were another 15 or so baths, each catering to different needs.
--
--
1
No Matter What People Tell You, Words And Ideas Can Change The World.
At 10 I discovered travel, books and philosophy. Now I pass my days with a camera in one hand, a notebook in the other, looking for the perfect coffee.

Title: Great Runs in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Ultimate Guide to the Best Places to Run in the World's Major Cities and Destinations. www.greatruns.com @greatruns by Mark Lowenstein

--
Listen
Share
Our complete running guide to Budapest is now on the Great Runs site. Below is a quick summary.
Budapest, Hungary is a wonderful city for traveling, with wonderfully preserved architecture, great restaurants and bars, and a good transport infrastructure. It is the capital of Hungary and the country’s largest city, with a population of 3.3 million. There are lots of great places to go running in Budapest.
The best places to run in Budapest are all centrally located. The highlight is Margaret Island, a recreational mecca with several km of trails with great river and city views. There is also excellent running along the Danube, on both sides, although one should look carefully at our guide to learn the best sections. There are also some great parks for running: City Park (Varosliget), Bikás Park, and Orczy Park. And for some hills, head to Gellért Hill in Buda and run up to the Citudella (fort), or enjoy the more expansive Normafa park, a few km west of the city. One thing that’s unique about running in Budapest is that there are many places with rubberized running tracks, which are dedicated paths for runners. The longest is 5.3 km on Margaret Island. Many of these tracks also feature an open air fitness park, with machines for exercising.
Our full guide to running in Budapest is on the Great Runs site. Click on the links to each of these routes for full description and maps.

Title: Three Days in Budapest to Close out 2024: Plans Are Overrated, Fun Is in the Moment
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
December 29, 2024
When you first step into a new city, the vibe tells you a lot. Specially, when you go in without much research, like we did for this one. So, stepping into Budapest after the loud and lively Vienna felt like entering a quieter, more mysterious world. As we climbed up the escalator from the train station, the crisp cold air hit our faces, and the glowing Liberty Bridge appeared in the distance arching over Danube. It was a quiet welcome, and something about it felt right. Calm and inviting — that was our first taste of Budapest.
The walk to our hotel was an easy 10 minutes. Although, in -2°C, dragging suitcases, while our fingers and nose slowly froze, we couldn’t help but admire the streets. That moment, in a way, set the tone for the rest of the trip: embracing the unexpected and finding joy in the little things. My North Face jacket and Alaska-grade boots were doing their job, but Dev, who’s always “too cool for layers,” was clearly questioning his decisions. The streets were quiet, dimly lit, and peaceful — a stark contrast to where we had come from. Tired but content, something about the city felt quietly intriguing.
December 30, 2024
Day 1: When Things Don’t Go as Planned
The next morning, we woke up later than usual. Laundry was the first task of the day — a necessity for anyone packing light on long trips. We tried this for the first time last year during our trip to France and Spain, and it was a game changer. We found a laundromat nearby and got our oat milk lattes while waiting for the cycles to finish. It was a slow start, but it felt good to take our time. Given our type A personalities of always being on the go — Dev, especially — and me being a mix of high-energy and sometimes slowing down, we’ve both been trying to deliberately pace ourselves. This trip somehow made it easier, as if the city’s vibe gently nudged us to slow down and be present. It even tied into my New Year’s resolution. How? I am not going to spoil it for you! You’ll find out towards the end.
Then came breakfast — or rather, the search for it. Most places were closed for the holidays, and Google’s “open now” wasn’t exactly reliable. Isn’t it funny how we still trust Google blindly, even after so many travel time fails? No? Just us? Anyway, we ended up wandering aimlessly for what felt like forever, hangry. Finally, we stumbled upon Napfényes Restaurant and Confectionery, a vegan Hungarian spot. We had vegan versions of authentic Hungarian food, including vegan goulash. The desserts were the real winners: a sponge cake that reminded me of tiramisu and soy yogurt “cottage cheese” balls. We devoured it! When sharing dessert somehow we eat faster! No? Again, Just us?! 😲
We enjoyed a long brunch and by the time we were done it was already noon, so with no specific plans for the day, we decided to just walk along the Danube. The river stretched out, with the Buda Castle standing tall in the backdrop— it was mesmerizing.
While I posed at multiple locations by the river and Dev happily played photographer, a guy proposed to his girlfriend right next to us. I was so in the moment that I missed their moment and realized it when I saw people congratulating them. (You’ll see the exact moment I finally saw it in the picture below) I was so bummed that I missed it, but it also made us feel so warm and happy to see the happy couple! Also, I didn’t forget the usual:
Me: “You never proposed to me like that.”
Dev: “I’ve been on my knees ever since.”
Dude’s got lines!
The foggy walk along the river was really romantic, which explains the proposal as well. It’s an amazing spot to propose — if that’s something you’re considering. Notice the bench, that’s where you can pretend to take a picture from behind while the other person faces the river. Perfect moment to get on your knees. Good luck!
I took this picture of Dev on that same spot before the proposal happened.
As we moved along, we saw a street vendor mulling wine on the side of the road. Unlike the machine-made ones in Vienna, this one was simmering on a stove. We grabbed some, and Dev downed his so fast he claimed, “Fefde jal gaye” (burnt my insides). But it warmed us up perfectly for the evening.
Continuing our walk, we came across the Jewish Memorial — iron shoes lined up along the riverbank. These shoes commemorate the Jews tragically executed during World War II at this very spot. It’s a haunting and humbling reminder of history’s darker moments.
Hungarian Parliament
From there, we turned right and saw it — the Hungarian Parliament — a jaw-dropping masterpiece of architecture. It’s one of the most stunning buildings we’ve ever seen! I had heard it’s even better from the inside, but we didn’t have tickets, and it was sold out due to holidays on that day. So we happily admired the exteriors of this exquisite detailed gothic and renaissance gem! Of course, this meant photos galore. Dev quipped, “Seriously, itni photos li hain ki Parliament Sharma gaya!” (We clicked so many pictures that the Parliament itself got shy!)
After all that, we decided to take a coffee break but we realized we were completely coffee-d out! So, I ordered water — because, fun fact, Europe and dehydration seem to go hand in hand for me. Unless I’m super intentional about drinking water, I always end up forgetting to hydrate. Quick tip: Make sure you sip a lot of water while traveling! Over Dev’s chai latte with oat milk, water, some vegan Lindt chocolate, and some more geeking out over architecture history, we enjoyed the lit up view of the parliament. Dev after over 10 years of being married to an architect is pretty caught up with his architectural history!
Honestly, these little pauses are becoming some of our favorite moments. ❤️
Evening Adventures: Ruin Bars and New Friends
After that, wondering what to do next, we decided to explore a street nearby called Andrassy Ut. After walking that street, we found a small vegan restaurant tucked in a basement. At first glance, we were hesitant, but the cozy, homely vibe inside won us over. The place was run by a mother-daughter duo, with the mother cooking in an open kitchen and the daughter managing everything else. I tried vegan cottage cheese pasta, while Dev had a burger. They were out of their vegan Hungarian goulash, much to my disappointment. After enjoying our meal, we left chatting and laughing, only to realize ten minutes later that our handbag was missing! Dev sprinted back to the restaurant and thankfully , we retrieved it without issue and after some deliberation decided to head to the Jewish Ruin Bars, a must-visit in Budapest. These bars, created in abandoned Jewish factories post-World War II, are now vibrant spots of nightlife. There, we ran into an Indian couple living in the UK and had such a great time talking that we completely lost track of time. By 11 PM — a late night for us — we realized how much fun we’d had and how unexpectedly we ended up celebrating what felt like an early New Year’s Eve with newfound friends. Moments like these truly make travel special!
December 31, 2024
Day 2: Lost and Found on Gellért Hill
We started our day nice and slow, waking up around 10 AM. After getting ready, we headed to Buda for the first time, curious to see what it was all about. Our main stop? The St. Gerard Sagredo Statue on Gellért Hill. Now, this place has quite a story — turns out St. Gerard was a priest who was thrown off the hill for his beliefs. Pretty tragic, but hey, now he’s got this massive statue and a hill named after him. Goes to show, if you stay true to yourself, you can leave a lasting mark on the world. The views from up there? Totally worth the climb. The winding roads to get there — foggy and lined with leafless dark trees — felt straight out of a movie.
From the statue, I got it into my head that we needed to explore more of the hill. I wanted to see the Liberty Statue, Hungary’s version of the Statue of Liberty, perched somewhere higher up in the mountain. So, off we went, walking past fancy mansions and more winding roads. We somehow found ourselves passing the Saudi Arabia Embassy and even saw a mansion that had once belonged to a wealthy family but was sold due to tragedy and is now a museum, I think. It felt like a little adventure in our quest to find the Liberty Statue. Maybe it was the fog, or maybe it was the construction happening around the castle at the top, but we didn’t find the statue.
Eventually, what we did find, was a cozy café called Füge Shop and Café. We sat down, sipped hot coffee, and just chilled for a bit!
As the evening rolled in, we crossed the bridge from Buda back to Pest for our boat tour on the Danube. If you want to see Budapest in all its glory, this is the way to do it. The Parliament and Buda Castle lit up at night? Stunning. If I may get poetic — the Parliament glowed like a golden crown against the night sky, its reflection shimmering in the Danube — a sight to remember. Nothing could stop us from stepping out of the heated seating area onto the deck for better views, and wow, it was worth it. A flock of shadowy black birds danced against the Parliament’s glowing backdrop, the chill of the air felt nice, and the Danube looked majestic as ever. It was one of those quiet, perfect moments for Dev and me, just soaking it all in. Oh, and let’s not forget the Spanish group of revelers who at that moment asked me to take their group shot. I obliged, and my iPhone .5 shot skills made them so happy! It was all happening.
After the hour-long tour, we walked back to our hotel for a quiet New Year’s Eve. Leftovers, packaged dal from Costco (warmed up by the hotel staff, pro move, right? Which the hotel manager noticed and told us, Hungarian tradition says if you eat lentils on new years eve you will have immense wealth the next year, well, we’ll take that!) some snacks, a complimentary bottle of wine from the hotel, video calls with family, some Bollywood party music, a little dancing, and just enjoying each other’s company.
New Years Day — Jan 01, 2025
Day 3: Vampires, Witches, and Spooky Stories
Waking up on the first of January, the first thing that popped into my head was my New Year’s resolution: spend less time on social media. Over the past year, I’d realized I’d developed a bit of an addiction to scrolling. Sure, I love sharing travel pictures for many reasons, but it started to feel counterproductive. (We’ll save that discussion for another day!) So, before I slept on New Year’s Eve, I boldly deleted my Instagram app.
Fast forward to the next morning — I woke up feeling good but immediately wanted to reinstall the app. Classic, right? But guess what? The universe was on my side because I couldn’t log back in! Logging in from Budapest locked me out, and I didn’t remember my password. Taking this as a sign from the stars, I decided to roll with it.
I shared this with Dev over breakfast, and he confessed he could also do with less Reddit and LinkedIn time. Boom — joint New Year’s resolution made! Feeling all kinds of inspired, we got ready and stepped out into a cloudy, rainy Budapest winter.
Eating out on New Year’s Day is tricky. Most places are closed, and the ones that are open are usually packed. Our first stop was a café, but the only vegan option was, literally, a freezing spirulina beach bowl. So we moved on. Eventually, we stumbled upon a fancy Michelin-starred restaurant. It wasn’t entirely vegan, but hey, it sounded like a New Year’s treat. And it was super fancy — the server unfolded my napkin and placed it on my lap. Not the most comfortable I’ve been in a moment!
I ordered a delicious spinach salad with tofu, while Dev went for an acai bowl and fries (the only other vegan options). Oh, and the breads were vegan and delicious. The food was top-notch, and we felt fancy AF starting our year like this. Again, not planned at all!
Next up was Buda Castle, sitting pretty on a hill. Armed with layers of clothing and our enthusiasm, we started the climb — stairs and all. The view from the top was stunning, but man, it was freezing!
Once we reached the castle, we saw massive lines for the museum and ticket counters. After a quick debate, we decided to skip the museum. Why? Because we wanted to be more intentional with our time. Instead of rushing through, we chose to go back to our hotel, relax, and recharge for our evening plans. So unlike us, right? I think it’s all about fighting the FOMO!
Back at the hotel, we couldn’t distract ourselves with our phones (thanks to the new resolution), so we turned on the TV. To our delight, there was an orchestra performance playing — it felt oddly perfect for the day. We snacked on leftovers, took a quick nap, and felt recharged for the evening.
Our evening began with street food (yes, pav bhaji in Budapest!) before heading out for our walking tour. We took a quick stroll around the winter market and the giant Ferris wheel, which had completely baffled me earlier. The blue glow it cast on the sky behind the buildings had left me wondering where it was coming from — until I finally saw the Ferris wheel and it all made sense.
Eastern Europe has a rich history of eerie tales, and this walking tour was a deep dive into them. We learned about Vlad the Impaler, the Romanian ruler who gruesomely killed his enemies. Vlad was later captured by a Hungarian emperor and imprisoned under Buda Castle. This gruesome history inspired the vampire legends we know today, including Dracula!
The craziest part? As our tour guide was dramatically recounting this story, a bystander — Romanian, of course — who was not at all happy about the story, interrupted to say Vlad wasn’t that bad. Who’s to say? Maybe we’ll have to visit Romania to find out. New trip idea alert?
Then there was the story of the Crying Widow, a woman who allegedly ran a hospital in her basement but used the blood of young girls to maintain her beauty. Oh, and another witch apparently ate children straight out of their graves. 😱. By the end of the tour, we were thoroughly spooked — especially since we had to walk down the castle hill alone.
We grabbed a cab back to the hotel that was 5 minute drive away. Not because it was late at night and we were spooked, duh!, only because we had an early start the next day. 😅
That night, we packed up and got ready for our early morning train to Bratislava.
Final Thoughts
Budapest wasn’t what we expected, because we didn’t really know what to expect. It was better. From wandering aimlessly to stumbling upon cozy cafés, and from Gothic architecture debates to spooky vampire tales, every unplanned moment added a layer to our journey. It reminded us that sometimes, letting go of plans is the best way to truly experience a place. The unplanned moments — getting lost, discovering hidden gems, and letting go of rigid plans — made it unforgettable. Sometimes, the best travel stories aren’t the ones you plan. They’re the ones that find you.

Packing or Clothing suggestion for winter in eastern Europe
Winter in Eastern Europe can get seriously chilly, so staying warm is key! Here’s what you’ll need to stay cozy and enjoy your trip:
Pack smart, stay warm, and enjoy every chilly and snowy moment!

Title: BELOVED BUDAPEST
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Four continents, five cities, one goal: to bring together common experiences of journalism students through digital storytelling.

--
Listen
Share
https://vimeo.com/163987664
I created a video about Budapest, Hungary’s capital, for the “Connecting cities” project. I took these photos while I was with the Erasmus program there, and I wanted to share with you my once in a lifetime experience! Enjoy! #connectingCities
Last year I was given the opportunity to participate in the Erasmus program. The city I was chosen to go was Budapest. As a student there I made a lot of friends, with most of them coming from other countries and cultures. As you can imagine, I broadened my horizons, I shifted my perspective about a variety of things and, as a result, I changed a lot about my way of thinking. My stay abroad was for one academic semester (about 6 months), where I was a student at Karoli Gaspar University! In particular, Erasmus is actually an exchange program between European Universities, in which students from European countries connect, collaborate and share their feelings and ideas with each other, while studying in a foreign country. In this way, students become more open-minded and self-confident.
Now, its time for me to show you some of the main attractions that Budapest is famous for, including what I felt and what I thought while being there. Also, I will try to make a comparison of these attractions to the Greek culture and natural heritage, trying to find out the similarities between these two ostensibly different countries, Hungary and Greece.
To begin with, one of the most famous attractions in Budapest, and Hungary in general, is the Danube river. While gazing the Danube river and its calm waves, I surely admired the serenity and the beauty of Hungary’s nature. It is such a nice place, where there are a lot of small kiosks, coffee shops and restaurants, in which you can enjoy this breathtaking landscape and view. It is definitely a place where even your deepest thoughts can be unfolded. Once, while I was drinking my cup of hot chocolate during a boat cruise through the river, it felt like I was in a sailing boat into the Aegean sea. Instantly, the lyrics of Randy Newman’s song came across my mind… ‘’I am looking at the river but I am thinking of the sea’’. Many feelings passed through me and along with this, the sense of nostalgia of the sea and my country made me feel that I am into the Aegean again.
It is said that one of the best known attractions of Budapest is “The Fisherman’s Bastion”, which was built in the 19th century. The Bastion is a castle named after the guild of fishermen that was responsible for defending the stretch of the city walls in the Middle Ages. At this time, it is a city viewing terrace, with a lot of stairs and walking paths, and serves the best panoramic view in Budapest! It is a spot that many tourists visit, in order to take amazing photos of the view and, of course, themselves, for remembering their holidays! Needless to say, the architectural style and placement of the castle makes you feel like you are a part of a fairy tale, by taking you back in time, especially in the wintertime.
When I started finding out more about the city, I discovered that, not only the close to Danube side of Budapest is amazing, but also the other districts both Buda and Pest. For example, there is an enormous square called ‘’Heroes square’’ in which huge buildings and monuments are exhibited. I recall that a guide was telling us once the detailed history of the square, and we were all amazed about how similar the Greek and Hungarian architecture was. For instance, the Museum’s of Fine Arts designers were inspired by the ancient temples of Greece, and that’s why the front of the building is classical with massive Corinthian columns. Apart from that, its exhibitions contain pieces of art from Ancient Greece and Rome, which is something that made me feel really proud.
In my opinion, Budapest is definitely a suitable place for traveling, but only someone who lives there can ascertain how the everyday life and behavior of its local citizens is. As a student there, sometimes I had reservations about some specific things, such as not being accompanied while walking home. But that’s an apprehension I would have in any city that I am not familiar with. In general, Budapest is considered an overcrowded city and people there are kind-hearten and open-minded, such as many Greeks are.
If you go to the city center of Budapest during the Christmas time, you will find small wooden houses selling traditional Hungarian, sweets, food and art, and everything smells cinnamon and coconut. Its typically called the “Christmas Market” and you will surely have a blast while being there!
While spending 6 months there, I tried to taste all kinds of different traditional Hungarian food. My main conclusion was that their recipes were similar with the Greek ones, but Hungarians use more spices and bigger amounts of garlic and onion. As an example to the above, both Hungary and Greece have a traditional recipe for stuffed peppers. In Greece this recipe is called ‘’Gemista’’, and apart from peppers, stuffed tomatoes and other vegetables may also be included. In Hungary, its called ‘’Töltött paprika’’ and, by default, there are only stuffed peppers included. In Greece, “Gemista” is stuffed with minced meat, rice, garlic, tomato sauce, onions and oil olive while in Hungary, it is stuffed with pork, rice, onion, garlic, paprika and tomato sauce. So, you can imagine how similar these recipes are to each other, despite the small differences that may occur.
Additionally, I need to write about the baroque style that characterizes Budapest. While walking around the city, the roads and the buildings make you feel like you are starring in a mystery movie! Most of European countries are conducted with this architectural style, which is why they are considered to be so “unique” and “special” compared to other countries. In Budapest, you will notice these buildings of Baroque architecture mainly in the castle district, but also in the Szechenyi Thermal baths, the Royal palace and St. Anna’s Church. This style makes the city an absolute architectural paradise!
Now days, there is a situation which many countries are facing, mainly due to the financial crisis that hit the European Union. Unfortunately, in both Budapest and Athens, are a lot of homeless people and their number is constantly being increased. Most of them are living in subway stations, underpasses, parks and areas with high criminality rates. A high percentage of them are drug addicts and alcoholics. The problem in both Budapest and Athens is that there aren’t enough shelters that can provide a descent place to live to those who can’t afford it. So, inevitably, they end up living in the streets. For example, as a solution to this unfortunate situation, the City Hall of Athens is planning to open an overnight shelter for the capital’s homeless, but this kind of plan needs a lot of effort and time to be invested in order to be successful soon enough.In conclusion, we realize that these two cities, Budapest and Athens, have come to deal with poverty due to all the problems caused by the financial crisis. As a case in point, the high level of unemployment was a fatal factor for the loss of many homes, which led to the increased number of homeless people all around the county.
If you are a new Erasmus student, don’t worry, you will quickly make a lot new friends from a bunch of different countries! Erasmus students are very friendly and open to new friendships and experiences. I remember the very first course where we got to meet each other. That course was the Hungarian language one, and my first thought about it was that the difficulty was pretty much the same as the Greek one. All the Erasmus students were joking about the difficulty of the language, and how we could cope with it. We couldn’t even pronounce the words in the right way! It’s really hard to speak Hungarian fluently…
Fortunately, 6 months are enough to find out a lot of hints about living in Budapest, and of course to get along with them too. I have to admit that I am really glad about choosing Budapest as my Erasmus destination. I gained a lot of experiences, felt a lot of emotions and I had the chance to bond with so many people from around the world! I strongly believe that if it wasn’t for Budapest, I wouldn’t be able to understand how much my country relates or differentiates with another one, or how identical or opposite it can be in various aspects! I would definitely not change a thing!
--
--
Four continents, five cities, one goal: to bring together common experiences of journalism students through digital storytelling.
Panteion University . Department of Communication, Media and Culture

Budapest is one of the most beautiful, vibrant, and dynamic cities in the country of Hungary. It is the combination of two regions i.e., Buda — A hilly area, and Pest — A flat area, divided by the Danube River in centre.
The Hungarian capital has extremely exceptional sights on both banks of the Danube, a history of over 2000 years, vivid culture, and appetizing delicacies.
Everything you MUST know about the experiences here is as below:
This is one of the most architecturally spectacular and sacred buildings in the city located in the Pest region.
The St. Stephen Square in front of the basilica will give you a whole different feeling during the winters and summers as it comprises of Christmas market and terraces with parasols respectively.
The Basilica consists of a beautifully ornamented interior with statues, mosaics, murals, paintings, and stained glass which will surely amaze you about its history.

Title: Budapest, Bread, and Hope
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
26
Share
“Is it Paris or is it communist Russia? Who knows?!” Colin Hanks
These days, thanks to lower wages and a lower cost of living — and studio heads’ need for more money — there’s a lot of Hollywood production in Hungary. On any given night, some celebrity or muckety-muck can be found sipping palinka at the Four Seasons Hotel bar or wandering along the Danube. I’m here because my husband is working on a television show, our apartment’s Apple TV still has Eddie Redmayne’s login info and I know what Colin Hanks said about Budapest because my friend ran into him here, he was nice, they chatted, he described this place perfectly.
The comparison to Paris is obvious: classic pre-war buildings on either side of a glorious river spanned by majestic bridges. Communism lingers in the depressing grey concrete buildings shoved between old elegant ones and the unsmiling faces seen on the street.
But when I heard this quote, my first thought wasn’t architecture or national character, it was bread. Budapest’s bread and pastries are — for real — better than bread and pastries in Paris.
I swear. But just in case my taste buds or memory had gone awry, I went to Paris to test my hypothesis. Any excuse to mow down more flour, sugar and butter than any…
--

Title: Week 5, Part 2: Welcome to Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Will: We arrived in Budapest extremely hungry (see what I did there?). After disembarking from another lovely Flixbus trip, it was time to find our next home away from home.
Our Air BnB is in a popular area of the city called Oktogon. It’s a lively section of town full of restaurants, bars, shops, hotels, and grocery stores. We had no issues checking into our Air Bnb, and after a brief respite, it was time for dinner. Using our trusty dusty Happy Cow app we found a Mediterranean restaurant cheffing up some amazing salad bowls. Tucked in the Jewish Quarter, the owners welcomed us with big smiles and loaded us up with some felafel balls atop a bed of quinoa, salad greens, beats, and hummus. Post dinner we considered joining the masses in having a few drinks, but the travel day wore us out more than we anticipated. No need to rush it — we’ll be here all month!
Sunday was a settling-in type of day, and we had a mission.
Acquainting yourself with a brand-new city is fun in many ways; we’re learning to see its joy instead of overwhelming ourselves. Google Maps has become our best friend, and finding the most informative local blogs online has become a refined skill.
It might not seem like a real skill, but there are plenty of opportunities to be led astray when relying on the internet.
Carolina: As I'm writing this 22 days after "moving" to Budapest, I forget exactly the order of happenings for this day. But, as Will mentioned, we had some missions for Sunday.
For groceries, we gravitated towards Spar since that's the grocery chain we grew accustomed to in Zagreb. However, the Spar location near us wasn't the greatest — the quality of the veggies and variety was subpar, same could be said for their selection of vegan proteins, coffee, milk, and pasta. In the coming days we discovered that just across the street, there was a small local grocery chain (G Roby) that had everything we needed and more.
For the gym, we decided to tour a few spots. First, Nr1 Fitness — a 24/7 gym inside of what seemed to be an office building. As we walked in, we encountered a receptionist who, in broken English, told us that the gym was independent of the offices so she didn't have access to it. We decided to go check it out anyway behind the glass doors. As we did, two gym members came into the building and as they unlocked the doors to the gym, we slipped in with them.
The gym was small but not busy. It was a bit warm but it had everything we were looking for — "It will be a good sweat session, kind of like hot yoga" we told each other.
We then walked to 4% Fitness Corner — which is exactly what you would expect from a Budapest gym. House music booming through the speakers, cage-like room dividers, and muscle tees everywhere. It was only $10 extra than the other gym but there was more space, more machines, and the AC worked.
After touring the gyms, we decided to grab lunch and weigh our options. We walked to Kozmosz, an underground restaurant that serves vegan versions of traditional Hungarian dishes. Over chocolate-covered layered cake and coffee, we re-read the reviews for Nr1 and 4% and found out that many people had a hard time canceling their membership with Nr1, asking for a cancelation, still being charged, and not being able to get their money back. Now that's a problem we don't want to have. As we had discovered from our tours, 4% accepted cash payments. Additionally, there were no complaints of scammy business practices.
On the following day, we showed up at 4% and paid a month's worth of cash membership. And just like that, we had a gym.
Will: But what about when you’re suffering from screen fatigue? What is a way to explore a city without a phone? Caro and I have found going for a run works brilliantly.
Carolina: Going on casual runs has to be one of my favorite ways to explore somewhere. I say "casual" because the main objective of these runs isn't to hit a specific distance or keep at a certain pace. The objective is to go somewhere you've never been and see new things. To take the the byway just to see what it leads to. In these runs, it's more than okay to stop to take in the scenery, as the objective isn't to run.
That's how we decided to spend our first Sunday evening in Budapest. We ran up the street that connects Oktogon to the Budapest City Park — Andrássy út. Passing by gorgeous buildings such as HAB (Hungarian Art and Business), and the Alice Hotel. To reach the park, we ran around Hero's Square where we got a gorgeous view of the sunset (see picture below).
At the park, we ran aimlessly, allowing ourselves to get lost in the network of trails and pathways that cut through the park. At some point, we found ourselves at a Wine & Food festival (typical) in the shadows of the Vajdahunyad Castle. We also explored the park's extensive recreational sports infrastructures, and of course, the Széchenyi Thermal Bath.
On our way back, passing through the Hero's Square once again, we came across a Star Wars meet-up, over 200 people holding blue and red lightsabers. It was truly a sight to be seen.
Arriving back at Oktogon, we were lured into a local Pizza chain by the smell of baked dough, tomato sauce, and cheese. To my content, they had a veggie pizza option with no cheese. So we wrapped up another wholesome day with 2 slices of cheese-less pizza.
--
--
Tracking Carolina and Will through their European digital nomad experience!

Title: Walking Over The Chain Bridge in Budapest on Our First Night Together in Europe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
--
15
Share
We arrived in Budapest after traveling for twenty-two hours. We were tired.
My husband and I were new to river cruising and decided to get our feet wet with what some call the grand-daddy of Viking cruises — The Grand European Tour.
This cruise would take us from Budapest to Amsterdam over two weeks on the Danube, Main, and Rhine Rivers through the heart of Europe. We had no idea what to expect on our first night.
Before dinner, I asked if my husband could walk through Budapest with me across the famous Chain Bridge. I knew he was tired, but for me — he said yes. I had explained that we’d be departing the next evening before the city was lit and I wanted to get some photographs.
I’m blessed with an adoring and amenable husband. He knows one of my life’s greatest pleasures is taking photographs—especially on a trip.
When we left the ship, we weren’t ready for the beauty of Budapest at night. This walk over the Chain Bridge from Pest to Buda, on that first night, is one of my favorite and most beautiful parts of our European river cruise vacation.
--
--

Title: Experiencing Budapest, this time for real! (Part Five)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Healthier & happier living for 20-somethings

--
Listen
Share
Few days after I came back from Trieste, I had lined up another trip, and this type it was sort of a vacation. Except that it wasn’t, since it was a summer school with a full 9–5 schedule and all that. But it was summer and I was going to be there for a week, so for me it was like taking a vacation trip!
This was my second time in Budapest, since I visited the city previously in 2016, but back then it was November and pretty cold, so I didn’t get to fully experience the city, the agenda was packed so I only got to see a little bit from the night life, which had intrigued me and I knew that sooner or later I would return to finish the job.
Also one big difference since the previous trip was that now I was staying at Pest — the bohemian part of the city, while the first time I was situated at Buda — the part with the hills and castles.
I got a really cheap flight from Skopje, like 40 Euros a round trip, which was a great deal considering that the first time I had to take THREE flights just to get to Budapest and additional two on the way back.
As soon as I got to my accommodation, the Ludovika Kampus Dormitory — which was fairly easy to find, I met my roommates, Pranav from Nepal and Yahya from Pakistan.
Since our dinner was scheduled for later that evening, we went to have coffee in the centre and to do some sightseeing. Some places were familiar to me, the St. Stephen Basilica and the famous Hungarian Parliament (which amazes me every time I see it).
Since Pranav and Yahya hadn’t been to the city before I showed them some of sights that I knew, the weather was great so we took a walk and after that we had some coffee. Soon it was time to go back and to prepare for the dinner where would meet that rest of the participants at the summer school.
The organizers had also provided us with public transport tickets for the whole week, so this was particularly useful since we could use whatever we like — the subway, trams, buses, even ferries!
Soon we met up with the rest of the participants, so there I’d meet the people with who I would spent the next week — Bernat from Catalunya, Silva from Italy, Leonie and Nina from Germany, fellow Balkanian Stere from Romania, Heidi from US/Netherlands, Celine from China, my great friend Vassiliki from Greece, Zuhair from Iraqi Kurdistan and many more.
During the next few days we got to hear some interesting lecture on populism and it’s rapid rise in Europe — but I also got to learn that it wasn’t just a problem that the EU is dealing with, but that the struggle is real for other parts in the world as well.
At that time the situation was also beginning to become complicated in Catalunya and Iraqi Kurdistan — so it was great to share some opinions and discuss the matter.
It was quite nice that we were in Hungary and discussing this topic — since we all know about Viktor Orban and his policy towards refugees. This added another dimension to the discussions and we heard some interesting points, coming from the Hungarian side, or at least some Hungarian experts that took part as lecturers.
So the next five days during the days we we’re discussing and researching this topics, while at nights we were discovering Budapest’s amazing nightlife! One of my favorite things from the Budapest nightlife is the vast number of ruin pubs throughout the city, and during that week we probably got to see like close to 10 different ruin pubs.
The first night we went to my favorite spot, the one that I visited three nights in a row during my last trip — Szimpla Kert! So basically this is like bar, that is set in a garden (or maybe the garden is set inside of a bar) and it has all kind of cool stuff — like old phones, chairs, chandeliers, video arcades — the place has everything, plus some quality drinks and it’s packed with tourists!
The first night we went there with Heidi and Stere, while most of the others were already tired, but the next night we also went to this place and had a great time!
However, during the next few days we got to some see different places and what I can say is that we weren’t disappoint! Budapest has so many ruin pubs to offer, so I’d definitely recommend that if you go there, go to Szimpla Kert for a while, and then visit some other places as well!
So one night we went to this place Golya Presso — also a ruin pub but much smaller than Szimpla but quite similar in a way. A Hungarian friend of mine, Zoltan, told me before that this place was sort of a hub for the leftists, and it definitely had that kind of atmosphere — especially it’s enterier.
Another night we went to this Red Ruin — by the name you can guess what kind place of it was –filled up communist memorabilia and Stalin, Mao, Lenin etc caricatures on the walls.
Has some beer and some palinka there — I have to admit that I could managed to drink just one shot of palinka, since in my opinion it was terrible — rakija is way better than that! We met some crazy drunk people there — one of them was a drunk barking man who scared couple of dogs that were inside the pub (sounds weird but it happened).
One more place that left a good impression on me was this ruin pub called Ankerts, where they had some great draft beer, good music and atmosphere, but unfortunately we didn’t stay there for too long.
During the day, beside the lectures, once or twice we also went around the city, on the Danube bank and it was pretty awesome to watch the sunset there and to have some drinks.
I love this city since it has it all — great architecture with a lot of history, awesome nightlife and good public transport — which means that you can truly get a great experience!
But I’d recommend going there during spring or summer, winter is not really friendly if you want to go and do some sightseeing. Budapest is especially breathtaking at night, with it’s shining lights — the Parliament building is just marvelous at night! The bridges on the Danube are quite the gem too, especially Szechenyi bridge!
I didn’t go to the Buda part this time, since most of the days we had activities and always stayed on the Pest side, which was full of nice surprises on every corner.
On the last day before we departed, actually it was our free day, we took a ferry on the Danube and visited the little riverside town of Szentendre,or as Lilit from Armenia would describe — a Serbian-style art town!
Beautiful small city with a big Serbian minority there and signs around the place that I could actually read — since they were written in cyrilics.
We had great lunch there — gulash inside a bread dish (I guess I can call it like this). We had gulash multiple times that week and other than that I can also remember eating one dessert that was really to die for — called Samloi Galushka.
The rest of the food we had was mostly international — we ate pasta, hummus, pizza, etc.
I guess that it actually was a vacation, beside all of the lectures and discussions, so during that week in Budapest I had fun, met some amazing people again, and learned a lot of new and cool stuff. The last day I had my flight in the morning, so basically it was time to go back to reality once again.
--
--
Healthier & happier living for 20-somethings
Freelance journalist based in Skopje, Macedonia. Contributor for @ZDNet and @ForeignPolicy

5 Pleasurable things to do in Budapest
Planning to visit some place exquisite in the European continent? How about the majestic land of Budapest? Once you pay a visit to Budapest, you will start liking it even more than London, Paris or even Rome. There is not one thing that makes Budapest a beautiful European city but is a collection of varying ideas and thoughts that eventually make things appear more wondrous to the vacationers. Budapest is popularly known as the Paris of the east ad you should always consider exploring the wonderful way by which River Danube separates Buda from Pest. It is known for its elegant architectural splendor that sways away the heart of many leisure seekers. It is also quite a cheap holiday destination than the other prominent cities in the European Union.
Put up at one of the top hotels in Budapest and start exploring the city. If you are wondering about what exactly makes this city worth exploring then you must consider looking at the below mentioned points that will help you in taking the rightful decision. Travelling to Budapest and enjoying its glory will get even more convenient when you know which places you are exactly targeting to visit and enjoy.
· Visit the Szechenyi Baths: It is considered as one of the last remnants of the Turkish influence in Hungary and you must pay a visit to this place of interest for sure. a visit to the thermal baths happens to be a quintessential experience that you would definitely love to enjoy for alifetime. you can consider soaking in the thermal and healing waters of the outdoor pools of Szechenyi either at the wee hours in the morning or right before sunset.
· Danube River Cruise: It is a magnificent city and appears to be absolutely stunning all day long. The buildings that line up the banks of the river twinkle and tend to reflect on the dark waters of the river Danube. Take a sightseeing cruise of the River Danube on both day and night and you can always look ahead to enjoy the essence of a happening vacation break in Budapest.
· Walking across the chain bridge: It is one of the most amazing bridges in the whole wide world which you would love to explore during your vacation. It happens to be the first bridge to connect Buda and Pest together and the constriction was completed in 1849. Do not miss going for a leisurely stroll across the bridge in the evening when it is all lit up for enjoying every bit of the trip. Stay at the Corinthia Hotel Budapest for exploring the attractions thoroughly.
· Taste the impeccable wine: Visit the Faust Wine Cellar which offers a beautiful setting and you can be sure to leave your tasting with a great understanding of Hungarian wines.
· Buda Castle: If you wish to explore the world that lies beneath Buda Pest then the Labyrinth of Buda Castle is what you should aim for. It is one of the seven wonders of the underground world and is eminent for adding to its mysterious allure. It happened to be closed down in 2011 after the police had raided it. One mile of the six miles can be explored and this rule has been set since it has re-opened.
These are some of the places of interest that are worth exploring while coming over to the exquisite city of Budapest.
--
--

Title: Wes Anderson in a Box: Framing The Grand Budapest Hotel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I know this is a blog about photography, but it’s also a blog about the way that we create and interpret imagery. I find Wes Anderson’s films a perfect focal point for this discussion about image, storytelling, and framing. Both because of what people seem to inherently understand about Anderson’s unique aesthetic, and also because of what people regularly misrepresent or ignore.
I’m not going to introduce Wes Anderson because if you’re reading this, you know his films. We all have our favourites- often the films which got us started with his 50s toned, highly symmetrical movies (mine is Rushmore). Today I’ll be talking about 2014’s The Grand Budapest Hotel and later about 2021’s The French Dispatch, because these films present (to me) a progression of Anderson’s use of the cinematic frame as a storytelling device.
Note on history of format and aspect ratio
35mm motion picture film- that is, the film itself- wasn’t a particularly revelatory technology. Industrial processing for 70mm photographic roll film was already established, and filmmaker WK Dickson found that by splitting the roll in half you got two 35mm rolls which were ample enough to capture the image rendered by lenses of the time.
Like many stories in early film history, Thomas Edison stuck his head in, forcing Dickson to spend the next five years attempting in vain to establish a new standard. But in the end and to this day, the economics of 35mm film have kept it as the standard, first capitalising on 70mm film industrialization, and later on its own mass production before any other format had the chance to get off the ground.
Traditional spherical lenses project a circular image. We cut the sides off for convenience and to avoid the outside edges of the image circle, which tend to be blurry. The most judicious use of the image circle (beyond simply leaving it circular) is to square it, which remains the standard in some large format photography. This square is, however, at odds with human perception. Every person experiences vision differently, but with two round eyes spaced apart, we can fairly assume that most people see the world significantly wider than square, and the history of aspect ratio is the economics and technology of rendering a cinematic image that better resembles our own eyes.
Early widescreen was limited by lens and film fidelity. You can only cut so far into your image before degrading the quality, widescreen had some success in using larger format 70mm film, but the most common ratios sat around 4:3. A slightly wider square, which was codified as the Academy Ratio after sound was added to movies.
The 4:3 academy frame was wider than square, without significantly reducing the amount of film (and ergo fidelity) used by each frame. Throughout the 1930s and 40s the Great Depression cut into discretionary spending, 70mm film was considered too expensive to use, and further widescreen advances lay dormant.
By the 1950s, the mainstream adoption of television forced filmmakers to innovate. Widescreen implementations which were as simple as changing the matte in a projector were only possible by letterboxing already small tv screens.
In 1952, 20th Century Fox bought rights to a military technology which allowed for wide angle viewing from inside tanks via oval lenses, and coming out with The Robe a year later– the first film shot in ‘scope’ format. Anamorphic lenses squeeze the image on the way into the film plane, allowing twice as much width to fit into a piece of film. The image is in turn desqueezed by the projector, turning a 4:3 frame of 35mm film into a 1:2.9 image. In 1954 Vistavision was established as a more economical way to widen screens, flipping 35mm negative sideways to give an aspect of 1:1.5 which could be further cropped to 1:2 and the modern television standard 1:1.85 (16:9).
Aspect Ratio in The Grand Budapest Hotel
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a nesting doll of narratives. We open to the shrine of a dead author, a visitor holds a book (The Grand Budapest Hotel), and turns to the author’s picture on the back cover. We match cut to the author in an office in 1985, the author tells us about the way stories fall into your lap once the world knows your an author. The aspect ratio changes to 1:1.85 (16:9).
The film is going to pull this menouvre on us often, and it’s keen to make us aware that multiple threads of storytelling are going to take place. It also wants us to know that these stories are being buffed a little with a polish of nostalgic recollection. When our author calls the hotel, “a picturesque, elaborate and once widely celebrated establishment” we cut again to 4:3, and a bright pink hotel reveals itself against an obvious matte painting and a foreground of dimensionless buildings. This part of the story, the filmmaking insists, is literally flattened by layers of recollection as the author character declares, “The incidents that follow were described to me exactly as I present them here, and in a wholly unexpected way.”
Through the remainder of Grand Budapest the moving frame lines serve to remind us not only that there are multiple timelines, but that each timeline is filtered through its own series of storytellers. Wes Anderson’s visuals get flack for being so easily identifiable, but they have an in-text justification in Grand Budapest, where the further removed our author gets from the action, the more the world takes on qualities of the fanciful and make-believe.
Throughout the film, danger is framed by windows- the Zubrowkan army enter the film via a train window, they are spied through a window in the hotel, and Dmitri’s henchman Joplin pursues Deputy Kovacs, first visible through a bus window: Danger abounds, but the existential threat of war seems almost out of scope with the limitations of the story. In the scene of Gustave’s death the frame is robbed of its intense colour, too raw still for Zero the storyteller (Agatha’s death is given no screen time, only narration over imagery of their wedding.)
Why?
So the movie is a nesting doll of different narratives which get progressively distorted through storytelling. It’s a study in the stories we tell, the people and places, we remember, and how we remember them. But also. Why?
Why 4:3 (1.375:1 for pedants), 1.85:1, and 2.35:1? Each time period in the film lines up with the mainstream adoption of that aspect ratio, and so the changing aspect ratios can be considered another part of the set design, which changes dramatically from timeline to timeline. As the browning halls of the 1968 Hotel are rendered in brilliant pinks and reds when we flash back to 1932, so too does the ceiling of the cinematic frame literally grow taller. The perspective literally grows wider and- perhaps- more nuanced- with the historical perspective. Does the film suggest that we’re so far removed from the 30s that what we can perceive is literally cut off on the sides? It’s for you to decide.
It may seem quite contrived to suggest that the narrowing aspect ratio represents a neglecting of the edges of our historical perception, but evidence for this can be found in the text. Our dual protagonists, Zero and Gustave, are a refugee and a bisexual, respectively. Theirs are stories which have been sidelined throughout history, and positioning them in this historical context- even in what remains a comedic romp for most of its runtime. Asks us as audience to consider what stories and characters like Zero and Gustave have been sidelined.
Wes Anderson’s movies draw attention to their own filmmaking to the point of easy categorisation and parody. But too often I believe people categorise as an easy out from analysis.
The estrangement effect has roots in Chinese theatre and Russian Formalism, but was codified into Western theatre by Bertolt Brecht. Brecht’s aim for the estrangement effect (verfremdungseffekt) was that breaking the illusion, and reminding the audience that they were viewing a piece of fiction would force them to engage with the underlying politics. Wikipedia’s description is quite elegant:
“By disclosing and making obvious the manipulative contrivances and “fictive” qualities of the medium, the actors attempt to alienate the viewer from any passive acceptance and enjoyment of the play as mere “entertainment”. Instead, the goal is to force viewers into a critical, analytical frame of mind that serves to disabuse them of the notion that what they are watching is necessarily an inviolable, self-contained narrative. This effect of making the familiar strange serves a didactic function insofar as it aims to teach the viewer not to take the style and content for granted, since (proponents argue) the theatrical medium itself is highly constructed and contingent upon many cultural and economic conditions.”
“Disclosing and making obvious the manipulative contrivances” may not be Wes Anderson’s obvious aim, but the fact that his films are so readily categorised and broken down may at least hint that the estrangement effect is in place. And what are the politics of The Grand Budapest Hotel? It concerns two fringe identities in the face of encroaching fascism.
It is in this way that Grand Budapest is tidily packaged in that thematic dichotomy can be found in the visual aesthetic, and the two feed back into one and other: The rose-tint of nostalgia against the cultural trauma of fascism.
It can seem counter-intuitive, when one of the major criticisms levied against Anderson’s films is that they hide lack of substance behind beautiful aesthetics. But if we consider that the opposite may be true, can the lush aesthetics of The Grand Budapest Hotel, especially during the aesthetic rug-pull of the tawdry 1968 hotel, be hiding its politics precisely within its visuals? The set designs of Grand Budapest Hotel took inspiration from ski resorts rendered in photochrom, a method of colouring black and white photography by hand. They appear stunning in their subtle pastel palettes. But at the same time, the colours they claim to represent are entirely fabricated- left to the artistic choices of the colourist. The hyperreality throughout The Grand Budapest Hotel reminds us that all is not what it seems, and the centering of characters who would have been sidelined by fascism and other historical oppressions serves to challenge our romanticised notions of pre-war Europe.
Which brings us back to the box. The shape of the box in which the Grand Budapest Hotel plays out literally changes shape throughout the movie. Within, it helps guide us through jumps between time periods, but outside of the box, the changing shape serves to remind us that it is the box that we are watching. That this is a fictionalised, romanticised and nostalgic rendition of a far different reality. I think, if you’ve been willing to follow me this far, the characteristic Wes Anderson visuals and irreverent humour do credit to this film. They make the film appear beautiful and whimsical, but in doing so, challenge the viewer to contemplate what parts of a story remain too painful to tell, what has recollection- and history in turn- brushed outside of the frame?
--
--
Better photography through science and philosophy.

Title: Budapest = Buda + Pest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Share
I knew the Danube River and Hungary at a very young age because of piano — Johann Strauss’s “The Blue Danube”. Nearly 15 years later, in 2014, I finally paid a visit to Hungary.
The Danube river is like a belt twining in the mid Europe. Budapest, straddles the banks of the Danube River, and the buildings in the city are pearls on the Danube belt. I arrived at Budapest at the end of April, as an unprecedented heat wave washed over Europe — from Berlin ,Warsaw, Krakow, Prague, to Budapest, the heat wave was chasing me, along with sudden showers that often arrived late afternoon. When it was not raining, the earth was shrouded in heat radiation.
Budapest used to be two cities — Buda, and Pest. Buda was the capital city, and is presently the capitol. Across the river, Pest is 2 times bigger, where most of the city residents live.
The front foot of Pest was already in modernity, everywhere is Costa Coffee,European version of Starbucks, and every car has a European Union’s license plate, indicating the reform and transition of Hungary; and the back foot was still halted in the old time, as trolleys in 1950s styles were still running, and the marble exterior of most buildings were with had turned into yellow over the years. Pest barely had urban forestry. Exposure to excessive sunlight in late April had melted my skin, as if was some sort of ice cream. Perhaps a while back ago, Pest did have sufficient street trees, but those trees withered. There were always a few corners of the street, full of overgrown glasses, existing there alone without the accompany of street tress.
I did some of my schoolwork (I was an exchange student in a university at Germany) on the first night at a Costa. The coffee shop was quite empty, I was facing a window covered by raindrops that look like crystal sticking on the glass window, reflecting the night light on the street. Only one waitress was serving behind the bar, and she was as young as me. I biked along the river bank crossed the bridge between Buda and pest, again and again. Even Pest was where most of the city population resided, its streets were quite empty, besides a bunch of tourists sitting on the outdoor seating of the cafés around the street corners.
Then the late afternoon rain started dropping. I hided in a Costa Coffee until the rain died down. I paddled the bike over the stone road shining like mirror after the shower. When I got back to the hostel we stayed, I ordered some dishes from the Turkish restaurant across the street — Budapest used to be the biggest Jewish populated city. Millions of Jews were transported to Auschwitz from this city. It’s also the biggest resided city of Romanic people, now, it also a population of Turkish immigrants.
I fled to a Costa coffee until The last night at Budapest, before our departure back to Germany, we met our temporary roommate in the hostel, a Korean lady, around 40 years old- she was single, just quitted her job, flied from South Korea to the European continent, travel alone around Europe. She slept on the upper level of the bunk bed, above me.
About Me:
Made in China. Grew up and lived in China for 24.5 years, resided at Germany for 6 months and travel across Europe. I’ve been living in U.S for nearly 5 years now.
--
--
Made in China. Polyglot. Writes about AI X climate X Personal Growth, sometimes oral history

Title: 📸 — Budapest, Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Hi there! Maeghan & Oli here - we're taking a break to travel the world and hope you'll join us for the ride. 🌏✈️ 👫 www.alittledetour.ca

--
Listen
Share
We’re not going to lie, Maeghan was a little upset to learn that the Grand Budapest Hotel didn’t exist in real life…. but with everything that we heard about Budapest, she felt optimistic with the our next destination.
Budapest was fantastic. We walked around most days exploring the city and eating great food. There were so many different craft beer bars and bottles shops, this is the first time we didn’t have a chance to hit them all! Budapest was also super popular with stag parties and student travellers — I guess it is just that time of year.
We also hit a snag when we had our first encounter with bed bugs in our Airbnb downtown. But our skills as backpackers has reached a new level of awesome and we had identified the problem, found a new place, packed our bags and were out of there in under 15 minutes.
Other than that, we loved it here so much, we decided to extend our stay not once, but twice 😊
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫
On our second day in Budapest. Maeghan was sitting on the couch journaling and Oli was on his computer researching. We decided to switch places so we could recharge our devices and Olivier went on a hunt to find another power outlet. He looked behind the couch and noticed a tiny little bug on the wall in the living room…. it looked kind of like a bed bug…
So he grabbed a spoon, put the little guy in a glass and started a fine eye search to see if there was more. Well… there was.
Olivier found a dozen or so dead bed bug bodies (or a high confidence they were after looking at Google) and put them on a paper towel. Maeghan called the Airbnb host to ask him about this.. since Olivier kept finding more and more bodies and the skins of the bugs inbetween all the crevases of the couch.
Our host said they had bed bugs a few weeks ago, but had the exterminator come twice.. and not to worry unless we found a living one… and we did..
So within 15 minutes… we had their bags packed, space cleaned and they were ready to peace — with success. No bed bugs were carried and they found a new nicer Airbnb all in the nick of time!
The 2nd largest thermal pools in the world next to Iceland. We hope to visit both!
We saw this and thought of all our PasswordBox friends❤️. Ping Pong was an intense sport in the office, we had two and there would always be tournaments.. or two co-workers battling it out. But this seems like a new level of ping pong!
Ruin bar. Made in the ruins of an old building and furnished with only 2nd hand things. Also, has 18 bars in the one location — so you can go to the wine bar, gin bar, craft beer bar… etc. The best place for any group party!
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫

Title: (Hungary) Budapest Life: Where Beauty Meets Everyday Life
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Let me tell you something upfront — Budapest isn’t the kind of city that screams for your attention like Paris or New York. It doesn’t shove its famous landmarks in your face. Instead, Budapest whispers. It draws you in quietly, one crumbling facade, one steaming chimney, one café window at a time. You don’t just “visit” Budapest — you drift through it.
I’ve walked these streets on misty winter mornings when the Danube looks like a silver ribbon cutting through the grey, and I’ve wandered them under the lazy orange glow of summer evenings when locals sit outside sipping fröccs and laughing like they’ve got all the time in the world. Budapest’s charm lives not only in its grand buildings but in the cracks between them.
This post isn’t about the tourist checklist. You already know the Parliament building looks like a gothic wedding cake and that the Chain Bridge is Instagram-worthy from every angle. I want to talk about the streets, the people, the smells, the awkward little corners where life in Budapest feels raw, imperfect, and utterly human.
You know you’re in the real Budapest when the sidewalks get uneven. The main boulevards — Andrássy Avenue, for example — are polished and postcard-perfect. But duck into the side streets, and suddenly the city exhales. Laundry flaps in courtyards, tiny grocery stores glow under flickering neon, old women with floral scarves shuffle along clutching plastic bags, and young students sit on crumbling stoops scrolling on their phones.
There’s graffiti here — some of it art, some of it just bored teenagers marking territory. But the layers of history are impossible to miss. You’ll pass an art nouveau balcony hanging precariously over a 1970s shoe repair shop. Above, the cracked stucco peels like old paint, revealing the city’s stubborn spirit underneath.
Walk around District VIII — Józsefváros. It’s raw, rough around the edges, but it’s real. Here, hip cafés with Edison bulbs and oat milk lattes sit side-by-side with corner bars where old men drink Unicum and mutter about politics. If you want shiny, sanitized Europe — this isn’t it. But if you want life? Welcome to Budapest.
Budapest has a specific smell — part bakery, part car exhaust, part sweet paprika floating from someone’s kitchen window. And yes, sometimes a hint of cigarettes — Hungarians smoke like it’s still 1995. But that mixture? It feels like a real city. A city where people live, not just pose for photos.
Stop by a pékség (bakery) in the morning. The langos might already be sizzling in oil, but most locals are grabbing simple pastries — kifli (crescent rolls), túrós batyu (sweet cheese pockets), maybe a slice of pogácsa (savory scone) if they skipped breakfast. Coffee? Strong. Cheap. No nonsense. Just the way it should be.
Here’s what I love — Budapest locals don’t care that you’re a tourist. They’re not rude, they’re not overly friendly — they’re just… doing their thing. If you want to fit in, keep your voice down, your head up, and your eyes open. Don’t expect big grins and “How’s your day going?” — this isn’t Disneyland. But ask for directions? Most people will help. Stumble through a few words in Hungarian? Their eyes soften immediately.
My favorite? Watching older folks play chess in the parks, completely oblivious to the TikTok kids filming dance videos nearby. It’s two worlds colliding — but that’s Budapest.
Skip the overpriced tourist menus on Váci Street. Head to the side streets for hearty, grandmother-approved meals. Goulash soup in a steaming ceramic bowl. Crispy duck legs with red cabbage. Cheap, buttery nokedli dumplings. It’s heavy. It’s filling. It’s perfect for cold evenings when your breath fogs the air.
And the bakeries? Let me say it again — never underestimate a Hungarian pastry.
Okay, let’s get real for a second. Budapest might feel like another world, but getting here isn’t rocket science.
Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport (BUD) welcomes budget airlines and major carriers alike. From most European cities, flights hover around €30–€100 if you book smart. From the US? Expect around $500–$800 round-trip, depending on the season.
Skip the overpriced taxis at arrivals. The 100E Airport Bus runs straight to the city center for about €5. Runs every 20 minutes. Easy.
It wasn’t the fancy cafés or grand architecture. It was this random Tuesday morning in early spring. Light drizzle. Streets still wet from rain. I ducked into a tiny coffee shop off Kálvin tér. The window fogged up as I sipped bitter coffee and listened to Hungarian indie rock playing softly. Outside, people hurried past with umbrellas, the city carrying on, oblivious to my little moment of stillness.
That? That’s why I travel. Not for the bucket list. For the seconds in between.
Budapest is rough around the edges, sometimes crumbling, often unpredictable — but never fake. It doesn’t try to impress you with perfection. It lets you discover its flaws, its beauty, its rhythm — and decide for yourself.
You might not “fall in love” instantly. But give it time. Walk the streets. Breathe in the mix of pastry, paprika, and city life. Listen to the language you don’t understand but somehow feels familiar.
And when you leave? You’ll miss it — I promise.
--
--
Global logistics expert with experience living in multiple countries. Sharing insights on international trade, diverse cultures, and travel adventures
