Title: Hungary: Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The Marauding Mummy

--
Listen
Share
My inner germaphobe recoiled in horror as I dipped my toes into the steamy, chlorine-free waters of Szechenyi Baths. Nobody else seemed to mind that this place was the perfect breeding ground for a multitude of horrifying drug-resistant bacteria. White and caramel-colored bodies sat placidly in the armpit grease-filled pools, enveloped by rising steam, but a few were busy sucking in their tummies and sticking out their chests for the ‘gram.
“Weeeeeeeeee!” my 5-year-old screamed as he dive-bombed into a pool outdoors, splashing murky water onto several flawlessly made-up faces. The aspiring models waded away, scowling.
The city’s claim to fame — its thermal springs — have long attracted scores of admirers. First came the Romans, who established their regional capital here over 2,000 years ago after Marcus Aurelius discovered that his soldier’s wounds healed faster when they bathed in these hot springs, and then the Turks who, during their occupation in the 16th and 17th century, constructed a handful of public baths which are still being used today.
Among the dozens of baths around Budapest, Szenchenyi is one of the largest and most popular spa complexes in Europe, hosting everyone from Madonna to Richard Nixon. In this handsome building more than a hundred years old, you can find indoor pools with temperatures that range form hot to only-Satan-bathes-here…
…and three open-air pools — only the latter is open to kids under 14.
So there I was, on a chilly May morning, shivering in my bikini. I couldn’t decide which was more appealing — hypothermia or staph infection — but my kids chose for me, having jumped into the pool immediately after disrobing.
As soon as I found myself relaxing in the water, my kids pulled me to the centre of the pool (correction: whirlpool) where we spun around like a a pair of socks in a tumble dryer and I almost fractured my hip bone trying to escape.
After toweling off, we went to Heroes’ Square to cower before the fierce countenance of the Magyars, the ancestors of present day Hungarians . The Magyars — skilled horsemen who are said to have originated from Central Asia — were the most fearsome warriors after the Vikings. I felt a little thrill knowing that my Asian brothers managed to ride all the way here over a thousand years ago, pillaging and conquering towns along the way…
…but the statues bear more resemblance to Harrison Ford than any Asian I’ve known.
Anyway, I totally get why the Magyars wanted to settle here.
Hungary is flat like the Steppes, and a river winds placidly through the capital, carrying with it wealth and news from other parts of Europe. The Danube, however, was not blue as Johann Strauss has promised, but rather the colour of a day-old baby’s poop (which explains why nobody swims there). That did not stop us from sailing with Lagenda Sightseeing Cruise, marveling at some of the city’s flamboyant landmarks, many of which were built in 1896 to commemorate the 1000th anniversary of the Magyars’ arrival and to thumb their nose at their rivals, Vienna.
One of the most grandiose of these is the Fisherman’s Bastion, which is a misnomer since it has no fishermen, but rather, hundreds of tourists all jostling for the perfect picture. This Disney-like monument reclines atop a hill and is purely ornamental, rather than functional.
Its centerpiece, Matthias Church, is way older, dating back to the Middle Ages. It is the site of many royal marriages and coronations…and this is starting to sound like a very dry history lesson so we’ll stop here.
The kings lived nearby, in ated a female servant, salvation is only a short walk away).While I’d love to pay a visit to the king and swig Buda Castle, presumably for convenience (I mean, if he has killed a blood relative for the throne or impregn palinka with him, monarchy ended in 1918 and the royal residence has now been converted into a library and several museums.
The Hungarian Parliament, which was also built as part of the millennial celebrations, makes the Houses of Parliament in London look modest. We booked a guided tour, and were herded like cows around the opulent interior, bristling with hand-carved statues, ceiling frescoes and convenient workplace facilities like a post office, a clinic and — perhaps the most important of all — a hair salon (because God forbid one has a bad hair day during a parliament sitting).
But perhaps the most intimidating room of all was the dome hall, where two guards holding drawn sabres stood watch over the crown jewels. Because it must be incredibly tiresome to stand still and have tourists buzz around you like flies day in and day out, they were ready to flay anyone who gets too close — a poor lady got the fright of her life when a guards sprang into action, snarling and waving his weapon (which he no doubt sharpens every day) in her face.
Like, we get it dude, your life sucks. Stop taking it out on others.
We had our first taste of Hungarian food and liquor at the Great Market Hall, where mountains of fiery red and yellow paprika — used liberally in Hungarian cuisine, from soups to cakes — graced shopfronts, while salami and sausages made from mangalica, a traditional Hungarian delicacy made from a local woolly pig, dangle from the ceilings. There were also shops selling jars upon jars of pickled everything — including melons — and a bakery selling freshly made, piping hot strudels. I bought one stuffed with cottage cheese and it was beautiful.
After a satisfying round of made-in-China souvenir shopping upstairs, we sat down for lunch in Fakanal Etterem, one of the more expensive restaurants in the market hall. The place is as touristy as it gets, with Hungarian tasting platters and roving folk musicians, but the food — which came accompanied with some salty, spicy paprika paste — was enjoyable.
Heck, I was starting to develop a certain fondness for Hungarian grub when I boldly gulped down some Unicum.
Everything about the Unicum is offensive, from its name to its taste. But just as I was about to buy a one-way ticket out of Hungary to get as far away as possible from this liquor, I had some toltott kapozsta, or traditional meat-stuffed cabbages drenched in tomato sauce, and the world was right again.
We also dropped by the Belvarosi Piac, a smaller, more authentic farmer’s market. Locals come here to shop for local produce and eat in one of the handful of casual food stalls owned by renowned Budapest chefs upstairs.
Despite its unpronounceable name, MoszkvatéЯ is a solid Russian eatery specializing in street food versions of traditional Russian cuisine. You’d think the Russians were only good for two things — mobsters and matryoshka dolls — but, no, their pelmenyi topped with caviar and sour cream is every bit as deserving of our attention too.
It is said that you can’t leave Budapest without trying langos, a favorite snack among the locals. We came upon this deep-fried dough at a summer fair, and — after apologizing to our arteries — decided to have ours doused in sour cream and grated cheese. It tasted remarkably similar to ham chim peng, the Asian doughnut that was such a regular fixture in my not-so-great childhood.
We took a cue from the food tours that regularly drop by Callas Cafe and had tea and desserts there. Situated on Andressy Ut, Budapest’s very own Champs Elysees, this gorgeous restaurant serves Hungarian pastries in art deco surroundings. I helped myself to the opera cake, an elegant chocolate confection layered with mousse and wafer, and it was as beautiful as Maria Callas, the world famous soprano who inspired it.
It took me awhile to realize that my mother’s apartment — yes, she lives there — was located in the Jewish Quarter, where 70,000 Jews were forced to live during the Nazi occupation in 1944.
Whole communities were wiped out, but the place is experiencing a revival of Jewish culture, judging from the number of new kosher restaurants in the vicinity. We loved walking around this disheveled, graffiti-sprayed neighborhood, exploring its hidden courtyards and ruin pubs — without the children, of course. Hungary may be part of Europe, but it feels different, grittier and more exotic.
We also stopped by the Dohany Utca Synagogue, Europe’s largest synagogue. Its elegant Moorish facade, however, hides a grim history. Beside it, the Garden of Remembrance stood, a mass grave for murdered Jews. Some of the victims’ names were inscribed into the weeping willow memorial nearby.
And then there is the Raoul Wallenberg Memorial, named for the Swedish consul who saved tens upon thousands of Jews during World War II by smuggling them out of trucks bound for the detention camps and into safe houses. He was eventually arrested by the Soviets for espionage and died in a gulag. But what disturbs me is that real-life heroes like him aren’t as well-known or celebrated as Iron Man or Wolverine. Their faces have disappeared, swept away by the tide of history.
It’s like they never existed.
After the excitement of the baths, we preferred to indulge in some low-key fun and relaxation with the children. So we took a tram to Margaret Island, a peaceful, car-free recreational reserve wedged in middle of the Danube. Locals come here to bike, swim and generally get away from the bustling city.
I mean, what could possibly go wrong, right? Right?!
Well, the problem began when we rented an electric buggy to check out some ruins of a church. Instead of following us, our 3-year-old clambered onto the driver’s seat in front and stepped on the pedal — accidentally it seemed, because he began screaming for help when the car propelled forward for quite a distance….before crashing into a tree.
The boy, while inconsolable, survived with minor scrapes and bruises.
But yes, Budapest is beautiful. Just don’t expect relaxation to be part of the vocabulary when you’re holidaying with kids.
STAY
New York Palace, Autograph Collection This resplendent baroque-style hotel sits within walking distance of Budapest’s top sights. Amenities include a gym, spa and pool. The in-house New York cafe has long been an institution, thanks to visiting poets and writers. Rooms are tastefully furnished, with large bathrooms, but do not that it can be quite noisy as the hotel sits at a busy intersection. Be sure to ask for a quieter room on a higher floor if you’re a light sleeper. $$$
TIPS
Originally published at http://lolibites.wordpress.com on August 26, 2019.
--
--
The Marauding Mummy
Storyteller and globetrotter. Loves having a bit of a laugh at herself and others.

Title: Discovering Budapest and Beyond in a Month
Content:
Sign up

Sign up

Travel tips & guides on inspiring destinations

--
Listen
Share
Hi guys, I’ve decided to continue writing my travel stories on my personal blog website “Wandering Sten” for easier access for everyone. There is no need to create an account and sign in as well as monthly reading limits. Click here to read Discovering Budapest and Beyond in a Month.
It’s my first time traveling to Europe and my first destination is Budapest, the capital city of Hungary. I spent about a month here and there’s so much to say about this Hungarian capital and the country that I don’t think I can fit everything in a single post. But I’ll share a brief and informative overview of my memorable experience living in Budapest and visiting other places in Hungary.
It may be Europe, and it may be part of the European Union but it’s still an affordable city to live in. With some tricks and a diligent search on accommodation across various platforms (best if you have a local to help you find accommodation), you can find a nice place to live without breaking the bank. At the time of visiting, I was working remotely and that means my job doesn’t require me to be in a specific geographic location. I can do it anywhere from my laptop as long as I have a reliable internet connection and luckily Hungary is a developed country with excellent infrastructure including high-speed internet access everywhere.
I love Budapest and all of Hungary in general. I know people have different opinions and have said different things about the city or the nation, but personally, my time there was amazing. The people are friendly to me, the food is amazing, and it’s just a beautiful country all around. To be fair, I had a wonderful guide to show me around and help me with so many things. So whenever possible, I suggest you try to mingle with the locals or go on guided tours by the locals to get the full experience.
I visited Budapest and some other cities back in August 2017 and I’ve come back again for another two months towards the end of that year. I’ve personally visited and experienced everything that I’ve written here and all other facts and tips are thoroughly updated and checked. I plan to visit Hungary again soon and will update this guide accordingly.
Budapest is divided into districts and they are 23 of them. Some of the most popular districts to live in are district 5 which is called Belváros (which means downtown in Hungarian), districts 6, 7, 8, 9, 13, and 1 (Castle district on the Buda side). You can find most of the main tourist attractions in District 5 such as the dazzling Országház or the Hungarian Parliament Building, St Stephen’s Basilica, Shoes on the Danube monument, and the Chain Bridge. However, each district has its characteristics and charms so if you have more time check out other districts as well.
As for pricing, the accommodation in the innercity ranging from 150,000–200,000 Hungarian Forint/month (435–580 Euros) for a 1-bedroom apartment. If you don’t mind living on the outskirts of the city center, let say 20–30 minutes by public transport, you can still find cheaper accommodation ranging from 90,000–120,000 HUF month (260–350 EUR) for a 1-bedroom apartment. For my first visit to Budapest, I stayed in Frangepán ut. which is in District 13 and it’s less than 20 minutes to downtown and I also stayed in Újpest, District 4 and is a quiet and safe residential area located just 30 minutes to downtown Budapest by the public transport.
Another nice thing about Budapest is they have a really good and affordable public transport system. The network is made up of busses, trams, four underground metro lines, water busses, and suburban railways. A one-way ticket costs about 350 HUF(1 EUR) and the monthly pass costs about 9500 HUF (28 EUR).
There’s a funicular with great views that you can take for a ride up to the castle district from Clark Adam Ter. It’s not included in the regular public transport ticket but you can purchase the tickets at the entrances on the way up and down for 1200 HUF (3.5 EUR). During Christmastime, there’s an illuminated tram overlooking the Danube river and the Buda Castle that runs along the Pest riverfront, all the way from Jászai Mari tér by Margaret Bridge to Közvágóhíd. The tram is decorated in beautiful Christmas lights and it’s such a unique experience to ride in the tram. You don’t need to pay extra to ride on the Christmas tram as you can use your standard ticket fares and passes.
The first thing that I noticed when I walk around Budapest is the architecture. The whole city is filled with beautiful buildings from different historical eras in Europe such as Baroque, Art Nouveau, Bauhaus, and Socialist. All the sightseeing attractions also not far from each other and can be reached within walking distance. Here’s the list of places that I think you can’t miss while you’re visiting Budapest:
This is probably the most iconic landmark in Budapest if not the whole of Hungary. Home to hundreds of parliamentary offices, the building is a sight to behold in every angle but the best full view is from the other side of the Danube river. Certain parts of the Parliament Building is open for guided tours daily and you get to see the great vaulted hall, the richly decorated central staircase, the Hungarian Crown Jewels, and the Hungarian Holy Crown.
Heroes’ Square is another iconic monument in Budapest. You will see big statues of the Seven Chieftains of Magyar and other important Hungarian national leaders as well as the 36 m high Corinthian column in the middle of the square with Archangel Gabriel on its top holding St. Stephen’s Crown.
Just behind the Heroes’ Square, there’s the Budapest City Park, a lovely park with lots of leafy walkways for strolls with friends and family. In the area, you’ll find the gorgeous Harry-Potter-like Vajdahunyad Castle — Museum of Hungarian Agriculture and not far from it, Budapest’s most famous and picturesque thermal bath Széchenyi Bath and Budapest Zoo & Botanical Gardens.
Also known as the Great Market Hall, this is a lively and large indoor market that is popular among tourists and locals. The three-story hall is massive in size and looks grandeur from the outside. Come here to browse among the stalls and counters selling seasonal produces, freshly-baked pogácsa (the Hungarian scone), various salamis, lángos, truffle paté, pickles, gourmet jams (plum, lavender), and souvenirs.
It is a small island covered in parkland and recreational facilities situated in the middle of the Danube river. Although quite small in size, it has some medieval ruins, a small zoo, gardens, musical fountains, a water park, playgrounds, running track, swimming pools and even dance clubs! This lovely green island is a great spot for hanging out with friends and located just a few throws away from downtown Budapest. Come here for jogging, picnic with friends and family, or simply taking a romantic stroll with your special one! ;)
This is an elegant avenue connecting the downtown with Heroes’ Square and City Park. It’s almost identical to the upscale Parisian boulevards in Paris and for that reason, you can find many luxury shops and high-end restaurants on this street. Other popular attractions such as the beautiful Hungarian State Opera and House of Terror Museum also located on Andrássy Avenue.
Overlooking the Danube river and across the Pest side of the city, Buda Castle is probably Budapest’s crown jewel. This world heritage site is located in the Castle District/Hill, here you can also find the Royal Palace, Fishermen’s Bastion, and Matthias Church — all are beautiful sightseeing spots that you can’t miss while in Budapest. The entire district is well-preserved (some of it dated back to the Medieval era) and as you strolled the cobblestone walkways, you can find lovely old houses, museums, cozy cafes and restaurants, even do wine tasting in historic Faust Wine Cellar. For the best panoramic view of the city, head to the Fishermen’s Bastion and don’t forget to check out the Castle Bazaar and Royal Gardens for seasonal events and more dining options.
Another great spot for panoramic views of Budapest is Gellért Hill. It’s a 140-meters high dolomite rock hill located by the Danube river on the Buda side of the city. Especially popular for weekend outings, the hill is filled with trees and you can hike on its winding trails that lead up to a Citadella where the Liberty Statue stands.
One of my most favorite things to do in Budapest is trying all different kinds of food and drinks. Forget the stereotypical bland western cuisines here, Hungary has many delicious authentic dishes and Budapest, in general, has a diverse and vibrant dining scene. Though not so popular in comparison to France and Italy, Hungary also produce great quality wines and I loved them! Here’s a list of some food that I’ve tried and loved while in Budapest:
Fun fact: Lángos is the first thing that I ate when I arrived in Budapest and what a good starter it is! Considered as Hungary’s best street food, it’s a fluffy fried dough covered in cheese and other toppings such as sour cream, bacon, onion, and parsley. It’s so delicious and satisfying and you can find Lángos easily in food kiosks, cafes, or restaurants everywhere in Hungary. My favorite place to buy Lángos is from a food kiosk just by the entrance of Lehel Csarnok (Lehel Market) which is a well-known local indoor market. Prices vary depending on where you buy it and whether you have additional topping or not but generally it costs around 350–700 HUF (1–2 EUR).
This is one of the most celebrated and iconic dishes in Hungarian culinary. There are many versions of Goulash whether it’s regional or international, but essentially, it’s a rich stew made from beef (or veal and pork), potato, carrot, spices, and the world-famous Hungarian paprika. It’s a highly fulfilling and flavorful dish that you have to try when visiting Hungary.
This is another of my favorite Hungarian dish and it’s unique. It is a thick vegetable stew made from variations of lentils, potato, peas, beans, or carrot simmered and thickened by flour mixed with sour cream. I imagined this is a typical home-cooked meal for Hungarians and they’re also really easy to make. My favorite is the green-colored peas Főzelék and goes well with bread, you can find this healthy but fulfilling dish in most restaurants in Hungary.
Okay, in my opinion, all the cakes that I’ve tasted in Hungary are delightful but if I must pick one I’d choose Dobos Torte. It’s a moist sponge cake layered with chocolate buttercream and topped with caramel; it’s heavenly! Hungary has a sweet tradition of holding the annual national cake contest where each year during St. Stephen’s Day on August 20th, they pick the best cake and crown it as the “Cake of Hungary.” The recipe for the winning cake then shared with the general public and you can find the cake in almost every dessert shop, cafes, and restaurants in Hungary.
If you can’t remember how to pronounce the name of this pastry that’s okay because you’ll remember how it tastes (and made). Kürtöskalács or the Chimney Cake is a Hungarian treasure in a form of a sweet spiral strip that is spun and then wrapped around a truncated cone baked over charcoal and coated in plenty of sugar while basted with melted butter until its surface cooks to a delectable golden-brown color. How does that sound? Yummy! If you’re extra like me, you can also add additional toppings such as cinnamon, cocoa, shredded coconut (my favorite because I’m tropical), or chopped walnuts and they elevate this famous Hungarian street pastry.
Let’s talk about wines! Hungary is not as well-known in comparison to France, Italy, or the Americas in terms of wines but that’s unfortunate because they have a really good selection of red and white wines that are produced locally. Here are some of them; Egri Bikavér or Bull’s Blood (my favorite) is a bold and dry red wine originated from Eger in northern Hungary, Tokaji Aszú or King of Wines is a famous dessert wine from Tokaji region that’s sweet and can be found in most restaurants in Hungary. Another drink that you can try is Pálinka which is not a wine, but a fruit brandy originated in Hungary and also popular throughout central Europe.
Although I loved Budapest, I was lucky enough to venture beyond the capital for a bit and went to Vác and Eger; two equally fun and memorable destinations to visit! Firstly, there’s Vác which is a great and quick getaway from Budapest that’s often overlooked. The quiet riverside town has enough attractions for a day-trip from Budapest and I loved my visit here. Some places to visit are the Vác Cathedral; a big beautiful church from the Baroque era built in the 11th century, the City Hall, White Church, strolling around the quaint main square and the riverside walkways, or simply checking out local restaurants and dessert shops.
Eger is well-known for its wines, natural thermal baths, and some historical landmarks. The city is beautiful and a unique blend of Christian and Turkish cultures which is visible in its architecture. While you’re here, don’t forget to visit Eger Castle & Museum, the Main Square, Minorite Church, Archbishop’s Garden, Turkish Minaret, and if you have time, definitely go to the Eger Thermal Bath (my favorite part of Eger!) and experience the healing sensation of Hungarian thermal bath. Another great spot to visit while you’re in Eger is Szépasszonyvőlgy or The Valley of the Beautiful Maidens, a popular venue for wine tasting that has below the surface rows of wine cellars where you can drink and buy some of Hungary’s best wines.
If you haven’t been to Budapest, you need to give it a go. Hungary’s capital is often overlooked because many people choose other popular destinations such as Paris, Rome, or Amsterdam. Although it has its flaws, I am so glad that my first European city is Budapest because I love the characteristics and the overall vibes. There are still so many things that I’d love to write about my travel to Budapest and surrounding cities (like my visit to the city of Debrecen, and bar/club hopping experience in Budapest). But I’ll save it for another blog post! ;)
Let me know if you have any questions or comments, I’d be happy to help you to have a great experience as you plan to travel to Budapest.
Hi guys, I’ve decided to continue writing on my travel stories on my personal blog website “Wandering Sten” for easier access for everyone. There is no need to create an account and sign in as well as monthly reading limits. Click here to read Discovering Budapest and Beyond in a Month.

Hungary is so beautiful. It is in fact one of my "first" things in life. Back in 2006, when I boarded the first international flight of my life, it was destined for Budapest. The chartered plane ride from Vienna to Budapest was the most thrilling one. Cutting across winter clouds, when I first saw Budapest from over the air was enthralling. My stay there for few weeks has stayed afresh till this day.
Budapest, the heart of Hungary, is a city rich in history and culture. Among its must-visit attractions is the stunning Buda Castle, a historical castle and palace complex of the Hungarian kings, offering breathtaking views of the city. Another gem is the Parliament Building, a magnificent example of Neo-Gothic architecture, which is especially captivating when lit up at night. St. Stephen's Basilica, with its remarkable architecture and the panoramic view from its dome, is a sight to behold. For relaxation, Széchenyi Thermal Bath, the largest medicinal bath in Europe, provides a unique experience with its therapeutic waters and grand architecture.
For those who love the outdoors, Budapest offers delightful hiking opportunities. The Buda Hills, a short journey from the city center, are perfect for nature enthusiasts. Trails in the hills lead to places like János Hill, the highest point in Budapest, offering an unparalleled view of the city. The trek to Normafa, known for its scenic beauty and fresh air, is both refreshing and invigorating. This blend of urban charm and natural landscapes makes Budapest a multifaceted destination, promising unforgettable experiences to all who visit.

Title: budapest: little differences so far
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
often there will be loads of empty seats but no-one sits in them, even when the tram is busy and all the less-able-to-stand people are sitting! I haven’t figured this one out yet.
is expected in any cafe, and some restaurants. it’s nice to be helpful!
they don’t switch to English, even if you speak it VERY badly. which is great when you want to practise. but potentially embarrassing… yesterday a barman got grumpy with me because I ordered two pints of Dreher (the local beer) but he somehow thought I meant two shots of whiskey, and then he wasn’t happy because he had to pour the shots back into the bottle… oops.
watch where you walk – or you’ll get dripped on.
no broccoli in any of the supermarkets. I’ve seen a couple of them hiding at fruit & veg markets, but never in any of the supermarkets. sad me 🥦
and even if it is broke, still don’t fix it. just put it in the hallway of your apartment block and you can guarantee someone’ll have nabbed it within the hour.
a lot of the greetings mean both hello and goodbye. which means you might hear “szia!” (pronounced like see ya) for hello, and “hallo!” for goodbye. not confusing at all.
made of actual wicker! and it’s not only the old ladies that use them – many other people do, too.
or any other type of coffee. they are just regular bars (without the espresso). also, loads of coffee shops also sell wine and cocktails and stay open til the evening. I like this.

Title: Budapest, Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Budapest was my last trip abroad before Covid hit and I’ve been missing these trips terribly. I’ve been traveling inside my own country for the past two years and I’m happy I’m privileged enough to do it despite this whole Covid mess, but I feel something is missing, so maybe writing and sharing will alleviate the itch.
Budapest was on my bucket list since I started a bucket list of places to visit and oh my… I only regret not staying for longer! Budapest is such a beautiful city with so many amazing places to visit and views that you could spend hours just admiring, specially at night when everything is illuminated.
Here goes my itinerary, information about the places I visited, the places I recommend for eating and the useful tips I wish someone had gave me.
I stayed at the Hotel Memories OldTown and I totally recommended it. The location is great, there are bus and tram stops just around the corner, and one of the main bus stops that connects to the airport is located 2min from the hotel (Kálvin tér M). Even though the hotel is located near a very busy street, most rooms face a totally quiet one, so no trouble sleeping. Breakfast was great, with options for all tastes, all fresh and some homemade. Room was big, super comfortable bed and all the typical amenities. There’s a spa center at the hotel with sauna, jacuzzi…

Title: Budapest, Bratislava, and Vienna — A Europe Trip
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Nearly ten years ago, my husband and I lived in Budapest for a few months right after we were married. Every weekend, we’d pack our bags and visit a new European town or country. That was when the travel bug bit us. Fast forward to today, we were thrilled to have a wonderful opportunity to visit Budapest again. How could we possibly say no? This time, we wanted to take our son to the places where we made wonderful memories ten years ago. And of course, when you’re in Europe, visiting one city isn’t always enough. That’s how Bratislava and Vienna ended up on our itinerary as well.
Flights
First things first. To apply for a visa, you need confirmed round-trip tickets and hotel reservations for the travel dates. I know I’ve mentioned this before in my Kazakhstan blog, but it’s always worth repeating — look for cheaper flights from cities other than the one you reside in. We could have booked flights directly from Kozhikode to Budapest. But the layovers were long, which made the total travel time even longer, and the ticket prices were outrageous! The cheapest flight to Budapest from India was from Bangalore. The flight duration was shorter, and the layovers were minimal. So, we booked our flights from Bangalore. We flew to Bangalore from Kozhikode the day before and stayed overnight at a hotel near the airport. This turned out to be cheaper than booking a direct flight from Kozhikode (including both the flights to Bangalore and the hotel stay). And since we have a kid, it was much more convenient for him. Happy child = Happy Parents. It was a win-win. We booked the KLM flight from Bangalore to Budapest with a 1.5-hour layover in Amsterdam. We flew back to Bangalore from Budapest via Paris on Air France. Both flights were quite comfortable, and we had no complaints.
Stay
From our experience, Airbnb is the best stay option. It is cheaper than hotels and extremely spacious, and most rentals have a washer/dryer. That means you can carry fewer clothes and sleep in spacious rooms. Our son is a huge fan of Airbnb because of how spacious they are. Hotels simply cannot beat this offer. Of course, make sure you book an Airbnb rental with good ratings located near the city centre or one that is easily accessible via public transport.
Once our flights and accommodations were booked, the next step — the most dreaded of them all — was applying for a Schengen visa.
Schengen Visa
Let me be upfront — of all the visas I’ve applied for, the Schengen visa is the most complicated. I’m not joking when I say that one of the factors influencing the choice of our travel destinations is the complexity of the visa application process. All the countries we’ve visited in the past few years (post-COVID) have either had straightforward visa applications or were visa-free. But when the opportunity to travel back to Budapest came up around our ten-year wedding anniversary, we couldn’t say no, especially since we started our married life there.
I’m not going to go into detail about the visa application process, but I will mention a few things that helped us during our process.
To apply for a Schengen visa, you must submit your documents to the VFS application centre closest to your city of residence. We live in Kozhikode, and the nearest VFS centre that processes Schengen visas is in Kochi. However, we couldn’t find any suitable appointment dates in Kochi, so we decided to go with the next closest VFS centre — Bangalore. Coincidentally, we were planning a trip to Mysore during the Navratri holidays, so we extended our holiday to fit the visa appointment in Bangalore.
Before COVID-19, applying for a Schengen visa was simpler because we didn’t need an agent to help us block appointment dates. We could just log into our account on the VFS portal and pick the city, date, and time that suited us. This time, however, we couldn’t get any appointment dates when we tried to do it ourselves. It was disappointing because we took pride in managing our travel plans independently. In the end, we had to approach an agent to book an appointment, and to our surprise and eventual relief, the agent was able to get us dates that appeared unavailable on the portal. We finally got our dates, and they lined up perfectly with our Mysore holiday.
When you go for your visa appointment, it’s a good idea to bring extra documents beyond those listed on the VFS website. We carried copies of our marriage certificate, our son’s birth certificate, copies of our investments, all our old passports, and copies of all Schengen visas older than three years — documents that were not specifically required, but which the VFS centre appreciated us having. The VFS centre also has a photo booth (in case your photos don’t meet their standards), photocopy machines, and printers, just in case you forget to bring a document. So, it’s helpful to keep digital copies of all your documents so you can easily access and print them if needed.
We received our passports stamped with the visas within a few days of application.
Now, it was time to travel!
Our First Destination — Budapest
Although Amsterdam was our first port of entry into Europe, it was a short layover. After waiting through a long immigration line, we rushed to catch our connecting flight to Budapest.We reached Budapest at around 12 PM. Since we finished our immigration at our first port of entry — Amsterdam — we collected our luggage and passed through customs. We were to stay in Budapest for five days, visit Bratislava and Vienna, and then return to Budapest for a day before flying back to India. So, we purchased a two-week travel pass at the airport. This pass provides unlimited use of public transport (metro, bus, and tram) for 14 days in Budapest. There are also single tickets, one-day passes, three-day passes, and monthly travel passes, but sadly, no weekly passes. The two-week pass worked out to be the cheapest option for our 6-day overall stay. If you plan to stay in Budapest for more than three days, get the two-week pass. Don’t buy a three-day pass and then single-day passes for the extra days, as the price difference between the three-day and two-week passes is minimal. If you buy single tickets each time you use public transport, you’ll lose both time and money. One thing you should know about most European cities is that you will rarely need to use a taxi/cab. The public transport system is so well-connected that you’ll be constantly hopping on and off metros, buses, or trams throughout your stay. So, a travel pass makes more sense than individual tickets. Also, think of the time you’ll save. Imagine having to purchase a ticket every time you use public transportation. It simply does not make sense.
With the travel pass, we took the 200E bus to Kőbánya-Kispest M and then transferred to the M3 Metro line to get closer to our accommodation. We stayed in an Airbnb just a three-minute walk from Kalvin Square (Kálvin Tér) Metro station (this falls on the M3 metro line).
There is also a 100E bus that goes directly from the airport to the city centre, but this is the only transport service that is NOT included in the travel pass. Since we had the pass, we skipped it and took the 200E bus instead. The 200E bus stops just outside the airport exit. You don’t need to validate your two-week pass on the bus, but make sure to keep it with you at all times. There are regular checks, and you’ll need to show your pass if asked. Once we reached Kőbánya-Kispest M, we transferred to the M3 metro line and travelled to Kálvin Tér. At metro stations, there are no automated ticket validators. Instead, you’ll need to show your pass to the staff member near the escalators, who will quickly scan it before letting you through.
We reached our metro station, walked to our Airbnb, and self-checked in. After that, we took the day off to relax.
Getting a Local Sim
We made sure our international roaming was activated before we left India. We needed data for the first hours around the city since we did not want to buy a SIM card at the airport (expensive). We visited a local Vodafone store in the city the very next day and bought a local SIM. It was around INR 2500, which got us 6 GB of data for 30 days around Europe.
Sightseeing in Budapest
We travelled in November, which meant it was cold and there were fewer tourists — which worked to our advantage. However, the drawback was that we had to layer up every time we stepped out, which was frustrating the first few days, but later, we got used to it. We had three layers. Our regular clothes, a sweatshirt/sweater on top and a final jacket. We also had gloves, a scarf, and a beanie. We used regular walking shoes, which were quite enough since there was no snow or rain.
Places we visited in Budapest –
As with most of my travel blogs, I’m not going to dive into the details of our itinerary or write in detail about the places we visited. Instead, I’m going to simply list the places we explored each day. We traveled with our 4-year-old son, so if you’re wondering how many places you can cover with a kid in a day, this should give you a good idea.
Day 1 –
1. Hungarian Parliament Building Viewpoint
2. Mathias Church
3. Fishermen’s Bastion
4. Buda Castle and Old Town
5. Szechenyi Chain Bridge
Day 2 –
1. Gellert Hill (Closed due to renovation)
2. Vaci Utca — for shopping
3. Corvinus University
Day 3 –
1. Shoes on the Danube Bank
2. Central Market
3. Vajdahunyad Castle
4. Heroes Square
Day 4 –
1. Ferris Wheel of Budapest
2. Vaci Utca for the second time
3. Christmas Markets around the city
Day 5 –
Budapest to Bratislava
Our Second Destination — Bratislava
Our next stop was the city of Bratislava in Slovakia. We didn’t book any local travel in advance, so we visited the Keleti-Pályaudvar railway station in Budapest, a few stops away from where we stayed, and bought our train tickets to Bratislava just the day before leaving for Bratislava. This worked out cheaper for us. We also reserved seats by paying a little extra. This may not be necessary during the off-season because the trains are quite empty, and you can choose any seat, but during peak season, I suggest reserving seats. Kids under 6 travel for free! It took us 2.5 hours to reach Bratislava by train from Budapest.
We were staying in Bratislava for three days, so we bought the three-day travel pass at the railway station. The pass gives you unlimited bus and tram rides within the city. There is no metro in Bratislava, but trams and buses connect the station to the city centre. Make sure to validate your pass during your first ride. Once validated, it’s enough to do it just once, as the three days are counted from your first trip.
We stayed in an Airbnb very close to St. Michael’s Gate. The city is much smaller than Budapest, and most sightseeing within the city can be done on foot. However, visiting Devin Castle takes about 40 minutes by bus. You can use your travel pass for the bus ride there.
Places we visited –
1. Devin Castle (must visit for breathtaking views of the Danube) — Highly Recommended
2. Bratislava City Centre — St Stephen’s Gate, UFO tower, Bratislava castle
Our Third Destination — Vienna
We travelled from Bratislava to Vienna by bus. Again, we booked the bus tickets just the day before we left for Vienna. We did this online and took the Slovak Lines bus to Vienna Bus station. Remember, there are two stops in Vienna. The bus first stops at the airport and then at the central station. Make sure you book your tickets to the central station, not the airport. We were in Vienna for only a day and took the day pass at a metro station near the bus station where we were dropped off. The return buses back to Bratislava also leave from the same station.
Places we visited in Vienna –
1. Stephensplatz and St. Stephen’s Cathedral
Our Vienna tradition is to have Gelato in Stephensplatz and so, that’s what we did. We went to a place — Zanoni and Zanoni — that had Vegan gelato and also vegan Pizza. They also had egg-free chocolate croissants. We finished a quick lunch here and spent the rest of the day looking around Vienna.
2. Hofburg Palace
3. Maria Theresa Square
4. Christmas Markets
5. Belvedere Palace
We left Bratislava on the 19th and reached Budapest. On the last day in Budapest, we simply walked around Kalvin Square, did some shopping, and called it a day. On the morning of the 20th, we boarded the flight back to Bangalore.
Travel within Europe
Within the cities, we never used a Taxi. The airports are very well connected to the city centre by public transport (Metro, Bus and Tram). If you can walk, you won’t need a cab/taxi during any part of your journey. The cities are well connected by public transport.
For kids under 6, public transport was FREE in all three cities!
About Europe in General
Please be aware of your surroundings and do not fall for tourist scams. So far, the central and eastern European countries we’ve visited (Austria, Hungary, Slovenia, Slovakia, Croatia) are not particularly known for scams. However, scams are more common in places like Italy, France, and Belgium — especially in capital cities and other popular tourist spots. There are several blogs online that discuss the various scams you may encounter, so please read up and stay informed before you travel. Scammers often try to distract you with something (such as asking you to sign a petition or attempting to give you a “free” gift), and while you’re distracted, another member of their group may pickpocket you or steal your bags.
Once in Paris, near Montmartre, we were approached by a girl who asked us to sign a petition for something. This is one of their most common scams. Our advice: just walk away and keep a tight grip on your bags. Also, don’t keep your phone or wallet in your pant pockets. Aravind was almost pickpocketed once but caught the girl in the act, and she quickly ran away. Luckily, he didn’t lose his wallet. The first incident happened in Paris, and the second in Rome. A third incident happened in Athens, where a lady approached me and offered me a free rose. Thankfully, I said no and left. It was only later that I realized this is another popular scam where people offer you free gifts, and once you accept them, they’ll ask for something in return. We encountered no such scams in the three cities we visited this time.
As for food, many vegan eateries can be found in the popular cities if you want to try local cuisine. In Budapest, I suggest you try Napfenyes Etterem — a vegan restaurant that serves local Hungarian cuisine. Make sure you try the Goulash soup! There are also plenty of Indian restaurants if you’re craving Indian food. We always look for Govinda’s — ISKCON’s restaurant. They have branches in several cities and if a city we’re travelling to has one, that’s where we frequent because our son prefers Indian food to local cuisine.
Overall, Europe is always a fantastic travel destination (if you manage to overcome the initial visa hurdle) because once you enter Europe, you have free reign to go anywhere, and everything is so well connected. Also, almost every shop closes by 6 pm. So make sure to do your shopping before then!
Happy travels!
--
--
1
An occasional travel blogger, a full time children's author.

“Almost dead yesterday, maybe dead tomorrow, but alive, gloriously alive, today.” — Robert Jordan, Lord of Chaos
I stepped off the busy burnt-yellow streetcar into a crisp grey late November evening. The bustle so prevalent throughout the centre of Budapest had ebbed away by the time I arrived at my stop. Now it just seemed like a sleepy Sunday afternoon in a small town. We were in Jozsefvaros, or the 8th district of the city, where we had arranged for an overnight staycation in a spa hotel.
We walked towards the hotel as my wife, who had grown up in Budapest, excitedly pointed out the high school she went to almost two decades before, which stood on a square just across from the hotel. It was beautiful in its old-world charm, as was the hotel which had recently been renovated but which originally served as a telecommunications office in the early twentieth century.
As we settled down in our room, I came across a coffee table book bearing black and…

Title: Random Budapest tips
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Updated March 2024
Books to read:
Quick geography lesson:
Buda: on the hilly, leafy west side of the Danube river. The foothills have some apartment buildings… further up it’s full of glam villas. Traditionally more Catholic/royalist.
Pest: the flat, east side of the Danube. Full of apartment buildings, gritty side streets and broad avenues. Traditionally more Jewish, cosmopolitan and socialist.
Food and drink (mostly Pest):
Transport:
Trams are an ideal way to see the city, particularly #2 along the Pest side of the river and #6, which circles the ring road. DO buy a ticket, and, as in all tourist-engorged cities, do watch your wallet.
BOLT is a great app for affordable taxis. You can input start/end points and avoid trying to speak Hungarian. Works elsewhere in Central Europe too.
Buda/Pest highlights:
The “Castle District” on the west side of the Danube (Buda) is full of faux medieval architecture, monarchist pretense… skip it if your time is short. If you want to experience a fun conglomeration of scenes, start at the Bambi coffee shop (straight out of 1962), walk up the hill to Szell Kalman Ter (used to be Moszkva Ter, the tram hub where kids gathered during the 70s and 80s to plot their night escapades) to see the Mammut Mall (modern, erected on the site of an old train factory), the Fenyi Utcai Piac (farmer’s market in a modern/brutalist setting) and have a coffee at a cafe along the pedestrian Lovohaz utca and eat at Pingrumba (mentioned above.) From here, you can grab a #6 tram to head over to Pest…
Random stuff on the east (Pest) side is better. A quick tour below… if you start at roughly 12 o’clock on the clock dial, this zigzags around to 6 o’clock. Most of this stuff — with the exception of the city market — is within 5–10 minutes walk of other points.
Budapest, the melting pot:
Pronunciation:
After returning from Hungary, should you talk about your visit to “Budapesht” (mimicking Hungarian, which turns “s” into “sh”) or “Budapest” (phonetically in English)? Many tourists affect the former pronunciation — which is odd, because almost nobody talks about their trips to “Paree” or “Roma,” right? (I confront the same problem when referring to Indianapolis, which residents universally call “Indy,” when I’m outside in Indiana.)
An hour away:
And a friend’s notes on Prague. Notes on Budapest’s rising prices for tourists. Online resources: LikeLocals.

Title: What to do in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Probably due to the fact I part time live in Hungary, I am often asked about Budapest. So here are my takes and suggestions!
Budapest is a big city with several district articles containing sightseeing, restaurant, nightlife and accommodation listings.Budapest (Hungarian pronunciation approximates to “boo-dah-pesht”) is the capital city of Hungary. With a unique, youthful atmosphere, a world-class classical music scene as well as a pulsating night life increasingly appreciated among European youth and, last but not least, an exceptionally rich offering of natural thermal baths, Budapest is one of Europe’s most delightful and enjoyable cities. Due to its scenic setting and its architecture it is nicknamed “Paris of the East”.
In 1987 Budapest was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List for the cultural and architectural significance of the Banks of the Danube, the Buda Castle Quarter and Andrássy Avenue.
I am obsessed by the Fisherman Bastion …in a photographic sort of way. The proximity with one of my favourite patisserie does the rest!
I know they are new, I know they do not mean or serve much I still love them!
Located in the historic district of Castle Hill, the Fisherman’s Bastion (or Halászbástya) is a neo-Gothic terrace that looks like a structure taken straight out of a fairytale. Designed and built between 1895 and 1902, next door — Fisherman’s Bastion is named after the medieval guild of fishermen who protected Budapest from invasion.
The gleaming white structure provides panoramic views of the city: From here, you can snap some breathtaking pictures of the Danube, Margaret Island and Pest. You may choose to take some time to explore the bastion’s seven ornate turrets, which symbolize the tents of the seven Magyar tribe leaders who settled the Carpathian Basin, ultimately leading to the existence of modern-day Hungary.
Andrassy Utca is one of the most beautiful avenues in Budapest. The big green trees and the high end fashion stores give it an elegant vibe. Very nice to walk along it.It is a lovely wide avenue for a stroll. There are lots of restaurants and international clothing chains, high end on the street. The Opera is here and on the day I was walking they were making a period movie. It was nice to watch. Several places for coffee and of course, the clothing chain COS is here. If you walk to the end you will pass the Terror House and wind up at the big city park with the zoo.
A soak in a thermal bath is a quintessential Budapest experience (it hasn’t cultivated a reputation as the “City of Spas” for nothing). These baths, or fürdok in Hungarian, are heated by natural thermal springs and usually include on-site massage services, as well as steam rooms. There is no other bath as the Széchenyi Baths!!! The Geller are pretty do not get me wrong but you can find similar or better anywere in the world!
SZÉCHENYI BATHS
One of the last remnants of the Turkish influence in Hungary, a visit to the thermal baths is a quintessential Budapest experience. I haven’t visited all of the baths in Budapest, but I have been to several of the most famous Budapest baths and the grandiose Széchenyi Baths are by far my favourite. Early morning or just before sunset is my favourite times for a soak in the thermal, healing waters of Széchenyi’s outdoor pools.
…and discover why Budapest is called the Pearl of the Danube!
Ah, the Chain Bridge — one of my very favourite bridges in the world. It was the first bridge to permanently connect Buda and Pest and was completed in 1849. At the time, the Chain Bridge was considered to be one of the wonders of the world and the architect was so immensely proud of his work that he challenged anyone to find fault with the bridge. It is said that when it was discovered that the lions that stand guard at either end are missing their tongues, the architect committed suicide.
The Great Market Hall in central Budapest is Budapest’s most famous marketplace.
Whilst many locals still use the market hall as a place to buy their groceries, the market is incredibly popular with the tourists too.
Locally grown fruits and veg, and locally sourced meats are found on the lower floors, and souvenirs including lace, chess sets and leather goods are available in the upper floors.
As well as individual ingredients, it is possible to pick up homemade local delicacies like goulash and langos from the food stall upstairs.
Budapest is full of cafes to have a delicious cuppa joe and try one of the sweets Budapest is famous for. Cafe Ruszwurm, on the Castle Hill, is one of Budapest’s oldest traditional confectioners still operating as a cafe.
it is very cosy and small, has just about a dozen seats, There is a wide selection of the day’s fresh pastries, truffles, and coffee concoctions to choose from. The decor is charming too with antique furniture and tools of the old confectionery trade in the glass curio cabinets.
Cafe Ruszwurm is located at Szentháromság u. 7 and is open 9am — 8pm Spring through Fall and 10am — 7pm in Winter.
Completed in 1904, the Hungarian Parliament Building is one of Budapest’s most famous landmarks. The National Assembly of Hungary still meets there to this day. Travelers come mainly to take in the building’s architecture (primarily Gothic Revival style), beautiful statues and paintings, and national significance. According to many, there is no structure in Hungary that serves as a better symbol of the country’s independence and commitment to democracy.
Heroes’ Square (or Hosök tere) is one of Budapest’s grandest landmarks as well as the largest public square in the city. Swing by this area to take a picture of the Millenium Monument which was erected in 1896 to celebrate Hungary’s 1000th anniversary.
The square and the monument are dedicated to “the memory of those heroes who gave their lives for the freedom of our people and our national independence.” At the base of the famous column (topped with the archangel Gabriel) are statues representing seven Magyar chieftains — considered to be the founders of the Hungarian nation. Behind the column are matching colonnades with 14 statues of royalty and other important figures in Hungarian history.
This funicular, which first opened in 1870, is the second oldest funicular of its kind in the world. A system of weights and counterweights is used to help to raise the carriages up and down the hill. The funicular is the fastest way to get to the top of Castle Hill, and is exceedingly popular because of its panoramic views out across the Danube. (You can also get there with this Segway tour)
The speed of ascent was actually slowed down as of 1988, to give passengers more time to enjoy their ride. The track is open daily until 10pm, so it is also a great way to enjoy views of Pest at night.
This stretch of the Danube walkway goes from the Elizabeth Bridge to the Chain Bridge, and is perfect for those who want a short, but interesting walk. Promenading along the Danube is a great way to see many of the most famous sights in the capital.
Looking over towards to Buda side of the river, you will see the Buda Castle, the Liberty Statue on Gellert Hill and the Fisherman’s Bastion. On the Promenade side of the river, you can enjoy restaurants, cafes, Szechenyi Istvan Square and a range of different sculptures, including the Little Princess
Located on Vörösmarty Square and dating back to 1858, Gerbeaud is one of Budapest’s most famous spots to get delicious desserts. Unlike at the other spots, here I have three recommendations. Firstly, the Dobos Torte as they bake it is the very best…secondly because it’s Emil Gerbeaud that gave the world the Gerbeaud slice (also written as ‘Zserbó szelet’), we suggest the rethought/reworked version of this Hungarian favourite: the Gerbeaud Sundae. While it’s quite pricey (2550 HUF + service fee), it’s a huge dessert that’s practically a meal. Two scoops of walnut sponge, one scoop of chocolate ice-cream, two scoops of walnut ice-cream, chocolate sauce, apricot sauce, crispy walnut linzer, whipped cream and apricot foam, topped with a small Gerbeaud slice. It’s super sweet, yet the perfect mix of old and new, cake and cream, warm and cold. Secondly, we recommend the classic cake served with vanilla ice-cream and the legendary ‘cat’s tongue.’
Sissy, wife of Emperor Franz Joseph and Queen of Hungary always dropped in the Gerbeaud cafe when she was in Budapest.
MY SUPER FAVOURITE REMAINS THE DOBOS TORTE!!!
I like very much the idea and feeling of sipping a cafe while surrounded by books and magazines.
The building shows some wonderful neo-renaissance characteristics, especially when we’re drinking a hot black coffee in the room decorated with Lotz Károly’s murals. Used to be my favourite with a superb coffee place, sadly the coffee has closed, Bookshop is great
39 Andrássy út ·Website
Once the residence of Manó Mai (1855–1917), photographer ro the imperial court, this 120-year- old listed building houses an exhibition hall, the Sunlight Atelier, bookshop and library.
20 Nagymező Street Website
This is the main English language bookstore of Budapest. They offer decent prices and a large selection of travel books, both for Hungary and the other countries. You can find unique gifts for the book lovers in your life at Bestsellers. Street & River loves this place!
11 Október 6. St Website
It’s a little quiet island in the heart of the city with great coffee and tasty, homemade cakes, cute service and a wide range of foreign language books.
30 Nagy Diófa ut. Website
They seem to have everything…..except a coffee place!
1072 Budapest Rákóczi út 12.
I strongly believe in Budapest like in most of Mittel/Eastern Europe you can eat well and genuinely with 4/7 Euro. The places below reflect this feeling and are my favourites. You can have a meal with 900–1600 HUF
Our favourite restaurant during the stays in Budapest. The portions are huge at a decent price (and you can always ask for a smaller portion for 70% of the price!). The lovely home-made lemonade is a mix of lemon, orange and basil which is super refreshing and you can order a half a litre of it. Their goulash is superb as well as the
The service is always really nice too, answering all the questions we had about the dishes. Family and friendly staff. This is where you can find us in the evening when we are in the Capital!
Budapest, Hold u. 11, 1054 Hungary
This place is a cheap place to eat traditional, and not only. It;s a buffet type, and not a traditional restaurant, and I think it’s a bit underrated, compared to the very overrated and expensive “City Market” restaurant choices — this place is just around the corner from the City Market, and has the same nice dishes, for less money — and you always have a place to sit and eat, unlike the market. We live very close when in Budapest so it is our fav lunch place
Lonyay utca 7, Budapest 1093, Hungary
A new find, next to the beer owned Kaltenberg Restaurant. It is very nice and modern, Staff is attentive and the food is good!
Kinizsi utca 30–36 1092 Budapest, Hungary
Address: Október 6. utca 14., v. district, M3 blue metro, Arany János utca stationOpen: 11.30–20.00 dailyTel: (+36 1) 269 3861
A simple, inexpensive cash-only eatery with only 5–6 tables (prepare to share the table with other guests). If you want to try hearty Hungarian food this the place to go. Menu in English is available.
Daily menu (soup + main dish or főzelék + meat or sausage) from around HUF 800 -1 200. Try mushroom paprikash with galuska, or máglyarakás (a typical local sweet treat: layers of sliced crescents, apples, apricot jam, with meringue on top and baked in oven.
Address: Jókai utca 20., VI. district, M3 blue metro, Nyugati pályaudvar stationOpen: Mon-Fri: 11.30–22.00, Sat: 11.30–16.00, Sun: ClosedTel (+36 1) 312 0557, website
A pretty good-value, cheap restaurant in Budapest’s downtown, close to the Opera, with a daily menu of two options (a couple of soups, mains, and desserts): for 890 HUF (two courses), or 990 HUF (three courses).Soups: Újházy chicken broth — 530 HUF, bean soup with pork knuckle: 960 HUF,Mains to try: pork rib gipsy style with fries (Cigánypecsenye): 1555 HUF, Hagymás rostélyos ( rump steak with fried onions and fries): 1795 HUF,Desserts: pancakes (túrós=sweet cottage cheese, walnuts and chocolate sauce, jam): 420–515 HUF (two pieces), Chestnut puree with whipped cream (gesztenyepüré): 685 HUF.
Address: Bajcsy-Zsilinszky E. út 15. , district V.
Despite the touristy location, Lugas is a fairly good place right behind St. Stephen Basilica. You can sit at the terrace if the weather allows. They serve mostly typical Hungarian meals:
--
--

Title: 36 Hours in Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
It’s the first of October and I’m in one of the most beautiful cities in all of Europe. I walked nearly 20 miles today through 2,000 years of history: through the overthrow of kingdoms and empires, the fall of communism, the rise of capitalism, the evidence of centuries-old glitz, and the stories of human survival and defeat… and through it all, Budapest (pronounced Boo-da-pesht) has held its head high.
The bus ride from the airport last night took me past lights illuminating modern outlet malls. Giant billboards stood above a newly paved highway for Pizza Hut, NewYorker clothing, a Mercedes dealer, mattress stores and diamond merchants. Was this right? Had I just landed in Hungary? I was expecting sturdy grandmothers, about as wide as they were high, slinging potato sacks into communist-built trucks, clothed in brown, and selling unevenly carved salt blocks on the side of a dirt road. But this looked like I was riding past a strip mall in middle America.
We left the outskirts and were soon in the city proper: Baroque, Gothic, Classical and Art Nouveau architecture… it was like Prague, only the streets were wider and the buildings a touch more opulent. We pulled into downtown, and what I’d later learn to be the Pes(shh)t side of the city where a giant white Ferris wheel, a replica of the London Eye, stood next to the Danube River and a purple-lit Chain Bridge.
I exited the bus and walked down a narrow cement canyon made up of 5-story high buildings. Drunk college kids staggered and laughed in packs, weaving their way down the sidewalk. It was a Monday, but may as well have been a Saturday night- it was like walking through the East Village in Manhattan. Graffiti was scribbled on old decaying buildings, giving it that mysterious post-communist look. Dark alleyways and shuttered store fronts looked like part of an intended stage set. Kids covered in tattoos smoked cigarettes in doorways and wandered into crumbling ‘Ruin’ bars (pop-up bars with antique furniture and communist paraphernalia in abandoned buildings) before hitting the late-night pizza parlors, pianos bars, or even taco stands. I’d later learn I was just a few blocks from the big tourist draw of Saint Stephen’s Cathedral, down from the Four Seasons, the Ritz, and the Parliament. Luxury was mixed with disintegrating alleyways; it was all part of the city’s pallet.
I found my Air BnB, after having walked past it twice, tucked away between a furniture store and a construction site, located on one of the uprooted side streets in the Jewish Quarter. The cement walls on the exterior and in the open courtyard were crumbling, a patchwork of grey filler smeared the walls in no particular pattern. Chicken wire caged the mineshaft-like elevator, which was surrounded by a spiral staircase. There was a central area between the buildings that opened to the sky where trash was kept and laundry hung from railings. Red ivy cascaded alongside large cracks that ran the building like deep scars: another perfect backdrop for an East Berlin spy movie and no wonder it was $35 a night.
The inside of the apartment, though, could have been a museum: 2 old-fashioned typewriters, an antique sewing machine, gilded mirrors, fedoras hanging from walls, and half a canoe posing as a bookshelf. The place was big, maybe 800sq ft, with 12’ ceilings. During the day, light would pour in from double-paned windows and every once in awhile there would be a burst of pigeons, like fireworks over the rooftops, visible through the windows. In the living room, old wooden oars hung curtains and in the bathroom, antique golf clubs hung towels.
I looked down at my phone to see how many miles I had clocked walking through the city that day: 19.3. No wonder I was exhausted. Making my way into the apartment, I searched for anything edible in the old-fashioned kitchen. A bar of chocolate and an apple were propped up against an Italian espresso Moka Pot. Caffeine, an apple, and more caffeine? It looked like it was time to track down some authentic Hungarian cousine… would pizza count?
The night before I had ridden the massive white ferris wheel to get a view of the city from above, then photographed the beautifully lit Chain Bridge. I grabbed pizza (it rivaled New York City’s) and ice cream and sat watching the crowds flow in and out of the square in front of Saint Stephen’s Cathedral.
I read somewhere that this city can be substituted in films for Moscow, Paris, Berlin, Rome, and even Buenos Aires. 4 historical periods are visible in the architecture, including 1st Century Roman ruins next to Buda Castle and medieval buildings at one of the bath houses. The city just feels familiar- like I’ve been here before and have been waiting unknowingly to come back.
In the morning, I went for a run over to the Buda side where the Buda Castle is. The lush rolling hills of Buda (previously a separate city from Pest) includes gorgeous lookouts of the city from Fisherman’s Bastion: neo-Romanesque architecture with a view of the Parliament across the Danube. I did a 3hr historical (free) walking tour later and learned that Hungarians prefer the term Central Europe, not Eastern Europe; that post-communism is a mixture between democracy and communism; that the Turks brought the bath houses, coffee houses, and even paprika here over 500 years ago; that the Austro-Hungarian empire (post 1867) had a shared capital between Vienna and Budapest. (Each city tried to outdo the other in architecture and panache resulting in a building boom that made most of the city’s grandiose buildings of today.) And interestingly, 70% of Europe’s gold is from Hungary, which may explain the demand for the region and its prosperity.
I wandered back and forth over the 3 bridges, visiting the Parliament and an art instillation from 2005 called Shoes on the Danube River (a memorial of shoes left behind by Jews during WWII who were shot into the Danube. The shoes had been worth more than the people and they’d been instructed to remove them ahead of time). Learning about historical tragedies like these (over 600,000 Jews were killed in Hungary during WWII) and the rise and fall of the many kingdoms, empires, and modern governments had me in a trance, the crunch of pebbles under my feet, the feel of the leather shoes against my fingers. I stared across the river to the Buda side with its rolling hills and castles, the crisp fall air wrapping around me like a hug from an old friend.
As the sun dipped below the horizon, I made my way to the 1888 Baroque-style Turkish Baths at Széchenyiin City Park, my towel and swimsuit stuffed in my backpack. For the equivalent of $7, I had the use of all the mineral pools of varying temperatures from ice cold plunges to naturally hot pools, saunas and steam rooms. Faucets on ancient pipes in the sauna could be turned on to refill your water bottle, which reminded me of the fire hydrants around the city that also have a device allowing people to refill with delicious tap water. Water was flowing from everywhere, I had never seen anything quite like it.
When I got here 2 nights ago, I had known almost nothing about Budapest. I came because of a $49 airfare from Paris and a spare two days. Getting off that plane and riding into a worn yet opulent city that faces a fairy tale of castles and palaces across a winding river had me more fascinated than I expected; I knew immediately that 2 days wouldn’t be enough.
One thing I’m embarrassed about is that I didn’t experience Hungarian food. The immigrant cultures of Turkish and Italian were so prominent, with gyro shops and pizza restaurants everywhere, there wasn’t much of a draw to heavy Hungarian food. Still, I did learn the importance of Paprika (a mild pepper powder) in every dish- like in goulash (pronounced gulyas) and paprikash. Onions, garlic, potatoes, paprika and bacon make the basis for most Hungarian dishes, which run close to 3,000 calories per serving.
Another interesting tidbit is that the 500-year-old coffee culture, brought in by the Ottoman Empire, had created more than 400 cafes by the 19th Century. Intellectuals and writers would gather, chain smoking and waxing poetic in their caffeinated excitement. The culture was squashed by the communists after WWII, but it’s made a comeback since their independence in 1989. Coffee ‘take away’ and drip coffee isn’t very popular, so chains like Starbucks and McCafe have adjusted by serving espresso in china teacups.
As I rode the bus back out to the airport, a day and a half after my arrival, the scene looked more familiar in the light and more reasonable than my initial assessment. Of course there would be malls outside of this bustling city with English billboards- Hungarian is one of the top 5 most difficult languages in the world after all. With communism over, this country had sprung at the opportunity to connect with the capitalist west- and they play the part well.
Budapest, known as the Paris of the east, should be on everyone’s bucket list; I know I can’t wait to return.
--

Title: Budapest: First Impression
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
19
Share
Budapest is only one hour flight from Frankfurt. I have heard so many great reviews of the city that I decided it was time to visit the capital of Hungary.
Jacob had a birthday on the 10th of October and I decided to surprise him by flying with him to Budapest for three days. Turned out, it was a fantastic present for both of us.
In the BUD airport, I withdrew local forints from an ATM, bought my 3-day Budapest public transportation ticket, and off we went to the city center by bus.
It turned out the only time I needed cash was when I used city toilets. All the restaurants, cafes, museums, and parking garages accept credit cards.
On the second thought, we found another use for unspent forints. More about it in the next story about the city.😉
Our apartment was located in a beautiful and grandiose building erected at the beginning of the 20th century, at the time when modern Hungary was a part of the powerful Austro-Hungarian Monarchy.
The apartment was located in a mostly flat Pest part of the capital, just 10 minutes walking distance away from the Hungarian Parliament building. From there, we could enjoy fantastic views of the hilly Buda and Obuda parts of the city, located across the Danube River.

Title: The Best of Budapest of What We Saw At Night
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
--
13
Share
We arrived in Budapest yesterday afternoon. It took quite a bit to get here from Wisconsin but that’s for another post. Our travels went as planned and we stepped on to the Viking Longship we were traveling on around 2 o’clock in the afternoon.
After drinks, dinner, and partially unpacking in our stateroom, I dragged my husband across town to walk over the famous Chain Bridge at night to get a much-wanted, even required, photograph of the Budapest Parliament Building.
It and other buildings in Budapest are beautifully illuminated at night, as are the bridges that span the Danube River in that part of Hungary.
Walking from our boat, between the Liberty Bridge and the Elizabeth Bridge, to the Parliament Building was at least a couple of miles. After traveling on a plane for most of the last day, walking was a welcome relief.
My husband and I are big walkers on vacation. We enjoy it.
Before we got to the Chain Bridge, we had beautiful views of Buda Castle high on the Budapest side of the Danube. Again, gorgeous!
--
--

Title: An Unforgettable Visit With The Family To Budapest.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
1
Listen
Share
It was the summer of 2015. My husband and I travelled to Budapest with our son and his better half.
Our three-day trip to the city was the most enjoyable and unforgettable. Budapest has a distinct charm, and its glorious setting astride the Danube River makes it a great place to visit.
The Budapest vacation helped us to build lifelong memories and break away from the usual hectic routine. It allowed us to enjoy a new culture, food and experiences.
The Szenchenyi chain bridge spans the river Danube between Buda on the western side and Pest on the eastern side. It is a permanent bridge across the Danube in Hungary. A series of bridges connect Buda and Pest.
Budapest is the most beautiful city on the Danube. The city’s panorama is breathtaking, and you can enjoy the most when on a cruise ship.
The best part of the tour was taking a cruise down the Danube, passing landmarks like the National Parliament and Buda Castle. It was an incredible experience!
Especially in the evening hours when you get to see the illuminated parliament. You get to enjoy the complimentary welcome drink as you take in the sights of the city.
The Liberty bridge is the southernmost public road bridge in Budapest. It is the shortest bridge in the centre of Budapest.
Our Funicular ride to the Buda Castle was enjoyable. You get a captivating view of the city below.
Buda Castle is a remarkable castle. The National Gallery, National Library and the History Museum are located inside this castle. It sits on the top of the castle hill.
We enjoyed the old-fashioned pastry shops and many good cafes and restaurants — a must-see place for anyone visiting Budapest.
Every colourful dish was equally inviting, and it was difficult to resist the temptation to gobble them all up!
The Dohany Synagogue was very close to our Airbnb. It is the largest European synagogue and has a seating arrangement for nearly 3000 people.
You can see travellers clicking pictures of the interior. You get to see the brilliant Tohrah Ark made of coloured and golden geometric shapes.
The weeping willow tree is in the synagogue's backyard. It has metal leaves on which family names of Hungarian Jews murdered in the Holocaust are carved.
On the last day of our stay, we visited the St Gerard Sagredo statue. It is one of the historical landmarks in Budapest.
The views from this place on top of the hill are stunning — one of the most visited attractions in Budapest.
Heroes Square is one of the major squares in Budapest. It has the museum of fine arts on the left and the Palace of art on the right.
The central feature is the Millennium memorial. The two colonnades behind the monument each have seven statues representing significant figures of Hungarian history.
“Travelling in the company of those we love is home in motion.”- Leigh Hunt.
The most significant benefit of family travel is bonding with the dearest people in your life and exploring places together.
Every year we look forward to family travel, visiting a new place, exploring and creating memories.
--
--
