Title: #98: The Grand Budapest Hotel [dir. Wes Anderson, 2014]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Our two heroes, concierge extraordinaire Monsieur Gustav H (Ralph Finnes) and his lobby boy protégé Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori), sit across the table from each other in a moving railcar headed to the memorial of the tragically deceased Dowager Countess Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis (Tilda Swinton). The mysterious old woman, a close friend (and frequent lover) of M. Gustav, had feared her death was imminent just three months prior, though specifically what she knew remains unclear. In her wake, the vultures are coming, ready to pick apart her financial corpse and no leave aspect of her estate unclaimed. Gustav, however, comes as a dove wishing to pay respect to the woman and ensure that she is as beautiful in death as she was in during her last stay at the Grand Budapest Hotel in Zubrowka. But before they reach their destination the train comes to an abrupt stop in a barley field, invaded by Zig Zag Stormtroopers looking for undesirables which, it seems, includes Zero. It takes Gustav both his tenacity and his previous kindness to the mother of the Zig Zag commander to earn protection for the young refugee. A woman is dead, and Europe seems to be following.
In 1914, Gavrilo Princip’s bullets struck Austria-Hungary’s Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie. They would die together as their car sped away on the streets of Sarajevo, the first domino in a long chain to fall that would lead to The Great War, ending true monarchy in Europe in just four years’ time, and shattering the continent’s economy and stability in the process. The rise of fascism that followed, in hindsight, seems inevitable. By 1945, the Second World War would be fought on many of the same battlefields, an attempt to push back against the totalitarian evils of Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, and while the Allied resistance would ultimately win it came at a grave cost — before the midpoint of the twentieth century, Eastern European culture as we knew it was destroyed, replaced with a brutalist architecture and new forms of totalitarianism in the form of Soviet expansion.
When Wes Anderson’s 2014 masterpiece The Grand Budapest Hotel begins, we are not with Gustav at the grand chateau atop the mountain, but in a cemetery after the aforementioned Soviet Union itself has fallen. A young girl has come to visit the grave of a renowned Author (only known as such, played by the great Tom Wilkinson). She greatly admires a book of his and starts to read at the gravesite, one that was written in 1985 about a time in 1968 when he himself visited the titular hotel after its character and history were stripped in favor of the aesthetic du jour in Eastern Europe. No longer does the exterior resemble the pink majesty on the film’s poster, nor does the interior suggest an opulence reserved for royalty. Even the film’s aspect ratio has changed, from a small letterbox to a widescreen vantage like many of the historical epics being made at the time, only serving to contrast the drab and dreary nature of the establishment. The closest thing to culture or opulence we can spot is a painting of a boy holding an apple at the concierge desk.
It is at the hotel that the Author, now portrayed by Jude Law, spies an older gentleman (F. Murray Abraham) sitting patiently for no one in the lobby. When the author inquires about him, all he is told is that the man is the owner of the hotel and that he only stays once or twice a year, and even then, refuses to stay anywhere but a small room with a cot. The two meet in the baths (covered with grimy tile rather than elegant marble) and agree to join each other for dinner. It is there, in a large and empty dining hall, that the old man decides to tell the story of his time as a young lobby boy named Zero, his mentorship under the tutelage of the incredible and indelible Gustav H, and how the hotel came to be in his name.
As we see his story we realize how truly great the Grand Budapest Hotel once was, with its raised balconies, elegant carpentry, vaulted staircases, and chandeliers galore. The clientele is comprised of the world’s upper crust, coming from far and wide to experience the best Zubrowka has to offer, and the staff make it their mission to ensure they get it. The film is now in the nearly-square Academy ratio (again, like the films of its time), turning the wide realism into a jewel box we can’t help but admire. But underneath the majesty is an obvious melancholy, that throughout this fictional tale of excitement and adventure, prison breaks and murder, we are also seeing what we lost when Europe set itself on fire.
Let’s forget, for a second, that the sovereign nation of Zubrowka and the Zig Zag forces are entirely fictional and, instead, recognize the real-world counterparts they represent — Eastern Europe and Nazi Germany, respectively. When most of us today think of the latter we, correctly, picture a fascist, totalitarian, and extremely oppressive regime responsible for the decimation and destruction of numerous minority communities throughout the continent, most notably Jews and Romani. When we think of the former, however, we usually picture a more run-down, war-torn part of the world replete with brutalist architecture, grey skies, and impoverished citizens (like the hotel of the ‘60s). It has been the butt of many jokes throughout Western pop culture, my personal favorite being the incredibly exaggerated Bratislava sequence in 2004’s Eurotrip. It is important to remember, though, that this idea we have of a large swath of Europe is only part of the story and a small one at that. The current state of Eastern Europe is a direct aftermath of two global wars, along with further Soviet occupation and smaller conflicts in places like Bosnia and, most recently, Ukraine. One of the great tragedies of our time, and the main one The Grand Budapest is grappling with, is how much of that region’s culture has been lost, bulldozed, and forgotten in the wake of conflagration.
World War I was a knotty, complicated conflict with no clear good or bad guys to pick from (though much of the allied West was keen to point the finger at Germany and their Kaiser, who they already hated anyway). With two bullets fired from a young man’s gun and the month of confusion that immediately followed, all of Europe’s longstanding treaties and agreements, the same ones that had prevented full-scale continental war throughout a perilous and tumultuous nineteenth century, drove every nation in the area into hell. Young men were enlisted on the promise of national pride only to be used as machine gun fodder in the unmoving trenches in Belgium. Others were sent to Arabia in an attempt to push back the already sickly Ottoman Empire not to liberate the locals but to create desert empires of their own. By the time America was dragged in to help the English and French secure victory from the face of otherwise sure stalemate, all of Europe’s true monarchies had fallen and every nation had, on some level, lost. It was supposed to be “the war to end all wars”, but the emotional crater it left was the perfect cauldron to breed hatred and resentment, and the inevitable power struggle commenced.
Smartly, Grand Budapest is primarily set in 1932, nearly smack dab in between the two world wars. The imagery in the costume and production design is most obviously that of the second, but I believe that much of the early story is actually referencing the first. In that war, despite the hellish destruction, there was a pretend air of dignity attached. When Gustav and Zero are first accosted near a barley field the decorum and history between the commander and the concierge allows for safe passage (presumably in both directions). But when they arrive at the estate it is immediately clear that something is amiss, and the staff is ushering our two heroes away for a private discussion.
What is taking place, as we will soon learn, is a quick reading of the dowager countess’s will, which leaves the bulk of her estate to her ungrateful children — all except the painting “Boy with Apple”, which has been bequeathed to a one M. Gustav H. Much like Europe in the wake of WWI, unhappy with whatever lot they were left with, so, too, is Céline’s son and chief heir, Dmitri (Adrian Brody). Not only is he furious that he wouldn’t receive the entire estate in full, but that even a sliver of it should go to a man far below his station (and, adding insult to injury, the man she was having a lurid affair with). The rest of the film is, essentially, the remnants of the old-world empires grasping at every ounce of power they can and refusing to allow anyone from a lower class to have even a sliver. All Gustav wants is the painting, and many will die in Dmitri’s attempt to get it back.
By compressing the larger time period into a short year, Anderson presents a crisscrossing subtext with numerous overlaps. In our world, the period between the two world wars allowed for the larger societal dissatisfaction to curdle into outright hatred and destructive nationalism. In the film, it happens all at once, with Dmitri using the increasingly oppressive Zig Zag corps to place Gustav in prison for a murder that the son himself almost certainly committed (Céline’s) — the ZZ is more than happy to play along to continue aligning itself with wealth and power. The allegory there is pretty simple as this is, effectively, what happened in Germany as soon as it was clear that the Nazi party was gaining insurmountable ground in the political sphere. Better to team up and consolidate rather than fight back.
What followed, tragically, was the Holocaust — a decade-long massacre across Europe that claimed the lives of an estimated 6 million Jews and millions of others based solely on their religion, ethnicity, political stances, or sexual orientation. Much of Eastern European culture, particularly Polish and Czech, was expressly suppressed and overtaken by the Aryan Reich — what was originally there was deemed too intellectual, too ephemeral, too Jewish. When we return to the hotel in the movie’s third act we see that nearly every shred of pink and rose and red, the ornate nature of the palatial estate we marveled at earlier on, is covered in black banners with ZZ logos. The total decimation of the structure has not yet taken place (the version of the hotel we see in widescreen), but the first attempt is apparent. Rather than tear down and rebuild in their own image, ZZ would rather cover up and pretend it was always theirs.
Working backward, it is no surprise that the monastery in the mountains provides little more than a detour, pretending to help Gustav and Zero find the one informant who can clear the concierge’s name (and, we will learn, knows about the contents of a secret will that has been hidden within the sought-after portrait). Instead, they are so ineffectual as to allow Dmitri’s bodyguard and hitman, J. G. Jopling (Willem Dafoe), to murder Madame D’s butler, Serge X (Mathieu Amalric), inside of a confessional. An irony, to be sure, but one also not without its real-world parallels like everything else.
The rise of fascism in Germany and Italy is a seminal tragedy borne in the wake of another, but we shouldn’t ignore the power structures that refused to stand in their way. And while the already rich and powerful certainly have gotten their due blame, a key group that gets largely forgotten in their culpability is the Catholic Church. The Vatican, and Pope Pius XII specifically, was largely silent during the Holocaust despite numerous pleas for help. I’ve heard it argued that there was only so much the Church could have publicly done, but I must disagree. Behind the scenes, Pius himself sheltered a small number of Jews and privately urged a few of his closest officials to do the same. But publicly, he remained neutral and refused to condemn the actions of Nazi Germany. He was more afraid of retaliation than doing what was right, despite the fact that the largely Catholic continent routinely looked to him for guidance. By outwardly staying silent it gave license to the general public to do the same. He allowed the assassins into the monastery.
A common thread throughout Grand Budapest is how it was truly the common man who maintained and tried to protect the precious culture and history that those in charge seemed more than willing to dismiss and destroy. When Gustav decides to secret “Boy with Apple” out of Madame D’s estate before anybody can stop him it is with the help of the staff, including Serge X and the maid Clotilde (Léa Seydoux), that the painting makes its way to the safe in the hotel (though it is Clotilde’s betrayal and Serge’s false testimony that lead Dmitri to Gustav — collaborators came from everywhere). To break Gustav and his new compatriots out of the comically large prison, it takes cooperation and coordination from everyone around him, including a fellow prisoner not in on the escape keeping quiet out of solidarity. The tools used are snuck in via Mendl’s fantastic baked goods, made with love by his assistant and Zero’s soon-to-be wife Agatha (Saoirse Ronan), and even the prison guards are too enamored with the craft and design to risk ruining the beauty to check for contraband. What’s more, the concierges across Europe are banded together in a secret society to ensure that nothing is lost that shouldn’t be.
So, too, did normal people carry the burden of protection of people and culture from the Nazis as their scourge spread across Europe. It wasn’t the bourgeois who hid Jews or assisted the allies in their attacks on German soldiers in France, but the everyday working class and those in bureaucratic positions with the power to do more than their jobs required. There are famous names among them, such as Oskar Schindler who spent a fortune protecting 1,100 Jews, and Raoul Wallenberg who risked his life (and lost it) smuggling over 7,000 more out of Europe, but many of the righteous were unknown and overlooked. These were people who had little to gain and so much to lose, and yet felt the need to act anyway. In addition to the lives that were saved, there are numerous artifacts, religious and secular, that only exist today because of the kindness regular men and women showed, great works of art that only survived due to their help.
Gustav H, in many ways, represents all of them in one. He is shown to be a solitary man content to live, alone, in the confines of a small closet nestled within the grand hotel’s chambers. He reads his men poetry during dinner every night, despite them paying little to no attention while they stuff their faces with delicious food (that he, himself, will not be eating). He values the painting not because of what it can make him financially (although he does recognize the practical nature of doing so before anyone can steal it back), but because of the beauty it contains — the painting will one day find its home behind his desk in the hotel and seemingly stay there until the establishment is demolished. He is also a man who wishes to comport with the elite (much like Schindler did), using his position to attend to the wealthy clientele (particularly the women), but he never truly becomes them even when the secret will names him to be the inheritor of the entire Grand Budapest Hotel, which Madam D is revealed to be the silent owner of prior to her death.
Of course, his most selfless act is his protection of Zero from certain death. Zero is a refugee from a different war-torn nation, a young man without a home or family to return to. It is clear from their encounter with the ZZ in the barley field that he is considered an undesirable, but Gustav refuses to allow anything to happen to the boy. He can say all he wants that it’s because he doesn’t want to replace such a perfect lobby boy, but we know he cares for those who need protection by his actions. Despite not having much to pass on himself, he makes Zero his sole heir — a gesture that Zero takes to heart and never forgets. The two become inseparable, and Gustav’s desire to shelter him will unfortunately lead to his demise. Near the end, the two are once again accosted on a train passing through the same barley field. The faux principles espoused during the First World War have since given way to true hatred and violence. There is no protecting Zero anymore, and Gustav is shot unceremoniously.
“We have lost some enthusiasm, it is true. We don’t go now in rose-colored spectacles to exhibitions, but we haven’t forgot when we did so.”
In June of 1830, a now-unknown author published the above in the essay “A Gossip About Art and Artists”, the earliest known example of any variation of the term “Rose Colored Glasses”. It harkens back to a time when many would where spectacles not to aid their vision, but to instead recolor the world around them in hues of pink and rose, to better hide blemishes and mistakes. A combination of two older turns of phrase, the 1700s use of the term “rosy” to denote cheerfulness and optimism, and the older still use of spectacles to represent one’s ability to discern the world around them. By bringing the two together, the author recognized that we once used rose-colored glasses to pretend we could see the world better with a different perspective, turning nightmares into beauty. The actual practice may be gone, but the irony in their writing indicates that the practice has become metaphorical.
For a director as keenly aware of his production design, the colors used in any Wes Anderson film cannot be viewed as accidental. Across his filmography, there is a pattern — darker and richer colors are readily prevalent, particularly browns, greens, and blues. There are always flashes of yellow and the occasional deep red, but rarely anything that one could deem “rosy”. The contrast he creates with harsh colors used to populate the measured and meticulous diorama of set design allows for an obvious subtext that beneath the layers of control and order there is a darkness and uncertainty that plagues all of us. The Grand Budapest begins with these same color palettes, the only notable red being the carpet strewn over the hotel lobby in 1968. But when we move backward to Gustav’s era, nearly every aspect of the hotel is pink, rosy, and lovely. Even the uniforms of the hotel staff are royal purple. The only spot that is not resplendent with the blushing hues is Gustav’s room, which is instead drab and light brown.
Anderson is telling a story, through the eyes of an old man, of a time long past and one that he views with great affection. The story, far more than any Wes has told before or since, is incredibly dark and violent. We are seeing a world attempting to hold on to its history and culture while the forces gaining ground are doing everything they can to strip it away, and because of the framing device (and our knowledge of actual history), we know that one day, it will. It’s no surprise that from Zero’s perspective, the time of his greatest adventure, fraught though it may be, is colored as rosy as the most beautiful flower he’s ever seen. Zero loves the hotel, he loves Gustav, and he loves what Zubrowka once was to a young, scared, orphaned boy searching for a new life and new home.
Zero also loves Agatha, though it is clear early on that she will be tragically lost before the Author makes his visit. When her image is first shown, Zero refuses to even discuss her further — it is too painful. When he, finally, begins to elaborate on their courtship it is with a grand smile and flowing tears that he does so. In his telling, the lights of Zubrowka revolve around her wonderful visage, a halo around a woman taken far too soon. We, the listeners, are like the Author wondering what tragedy would befall her — we even briefly believe that Jopling took her life, leading to an upsetting sense of relief when it is revealed his victim was instead Serge’s sister (why should we care any less about her?). In the end, her death is even more unceremonious than Gustav’s will be just one scene later. After the adventure is over Gustav presides over Zero and Agatha’s wedding, though instead of joy we get the matter-of-fact tale of how she died within two years.
“The Prussian grippe. An absurd little disease,” Zero tells us. “Today, we treat it in a single week; but in those days, many millions died.”
Recognizing the danger of looking at the past through rose-colored glasses is just as important as remembering the beauty that we lost. If Anderson was somehow making the argument that the world was a better place before the war, he undercuts it so brilliantly in moments just like this. We may be living in a time when so much of what made the world worth living in is gone, but it is also true that we don’t have to worry about disease in the same way — the things that killed millions without fail are now as survivable as a cold to most of us with the proper treatment and care (something we’ve seen since in compressed real-time with the COVID pandemic). Wars are still taking place across the globe, but many of us are privileged enough to live in places where that is not currently the case.
The question remains why Zero has chosen to maintain the hotel even in its dilapidated state, and why he chooses to return to a place that brings him so much pain regularly. The Author surmises that it must be his way of remembering the world his mentor, Gustav, cherished, one of class and culture. Zero, instead, dismisses this.
“You see, we shared a vocation, it wouldn’t have been necessary. No, the hotel I keep for Agatha. We were happy here, for a little while.” As for the world Gustav cherished, he continues, “To be frank, I think his world vanished long before he ever entered it. But I will say, he certainly sustained the illusion with marvelous grace.”
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a movie in a fictional place but in a real time, one when Europe wanted to pretend that, despite the devastation of The Great War, the era of prestige and bourgeois charm of the late 1800s was still intact and not, in fact, a dead man walking. People like Gustav H. lovingly acted as caretakers both in an attempt to restore this perceived greatness but also to remember it, in case it ever truly was lost. Gustav’s legacy is not the hotel he oversaw nor the wealthy women he consorted with, but the memories and ideas that he passed onto Zero. The same is true of us — we are the caretakers of the best of our time and our world. It is our responsibility to pass what we cherish onto future generations. But, it is vital that we do not forget the challenges and the problems that we collectively endured as well. Recalling our era with rose-colored glasses will only make it harder for the future to maintain what it has, what it cherishes. Only once we can enjoy the great things we have and learn from the mistakes surrounding them can we truly be the concierges to the next generation.

Title: Budapest: First Impression
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
19
Share
Budapest is only one hour flight from Frankfurt. I have heard so many great reviews of the city that I decided it was time to visit the capital of Hungary.
Jacob had a birthday on the 10th of October and I decided to surprise him by flying with him to Budapest for three days. Turned out, it was a fantastic present for both of us.
In the BUD airport, I withdrew local forints from an ATM, bought my 3-day Budapest public transportation ticket, and off we went to the city center by bus.
It turned out the only time I needed cash was when I used city toilets. All the restaurants, cafes, museums, and parking garages accept credit cards.
On the second thought, we found another use for unspent forints. More about it in the next story about the city.😉
Our apartment was located in a beautiful and grandiose building erected at the beginning of the 20th century, at the time when modern Hungary was a part of the powerful Austro-Hungarian Monarchy.
The apartment was located in a mostly flat Pest part of the capital, just 10 minutes walking distance away from the Hungarian Parliament building. From there, we could enjoy fantastic views of the hilly Buda and Obuda parts of the city, located across the Danube River.
--
--

Title: The Best of Budapest of What We Saw At Night
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
--
13
Share
We arrived in Budapest yesterday afternoon. It took quite a bit to get here from Wisconsin but that’s for another post. Our travels went as planned and we stepped on to the Viking Longship we were traveling on around 2 o’clock in the afternoon.
After drinks, dinner, and partially unpacking in our stateroom, I dragged my husband across town to walk over the famous Chain Bridge at night to get a much-wanted, even required, photograph of the Budapest Parliament Building.
It and other buildings in Budapest are beautifully illuminated at night, as are the bridges that span the Danube River in that part of Hungary.
Walking from our boat, between the Liberty Bridge and the Elizabeth Bridge, to the Parliament Building was at least a couple of miles. After traveling on a plane for most of the last day, walking was a welcome relief.
My husband and I are big walkers on vacation. We enjoy it.
Before we got to the Chain Bridge, we had beautiful views of Buda Castle high on the Budapest side of the Danube. Again, gorgeous!
--
--
13

Title: An Unforgettable Visit With The Family To Budapest.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
1
Listen
Share
It was the summer of 2015. My husband and I travelled to Budapest with our son and his better half.
Our three-day trip to the city was the most enjoyable and unforgettable. Budapest has a distinct charm, and its glorious setting astride the Danube River makes it a great place to visit.
The Budapest vacation helped us to build lifelong memories and break away from the usual hectic routine. It allowed us to enjoy a new culture, food and experiences.
The Szenchenyi chain bridge spans the river Danube between Buda on the western side and Pest on the eastern side. It is a permanent bridge across the Danube in Hungary. A series of bridges connect Buda and Pest.
Budapest is the most beautiful city on the Danube. The city’s panorama is breathtaking, and you can enjoy the most when on a cruise ship.
The best part of the tour was taking a cruise down the Danube, passing landmarks like the National Parliament and Buda Castle. It was an incredible experience!
Especially in the evening hours when you get to see the illuminated parliament. You get to enjoy the complimentary welcome drink as you take in the sights of the city.
The Liberty bridge is the southernmost public road bridge in Budapest. It is the shortest bridge in the centre of Budapest.
Our Funicular ride to the Buda Castle was enjoyable. You get a captivating view of the city below.
Buda Castle is a remarkable castle. The National Gallery, National Library and the History Museum are located inside this castle. It sits on the top of the castle hill.
We enjoyed the old-fashioned pastry shops and many good cafes and restaurants — a must-see place for anyone visiting Budapest.
Every colourful dish was equally inviting, and it was difficult to resist the temptation to gobble them all up!
The Dohany Synagogue was very close to our Airbnb. It is the largest European synagogue and has a seating arrangement for nearly 3000 people.
You can see travellers clicking pictures of the interior. You get to see the brilliant Tohrah Ark made of coloured and golden geometric shapes.
The weeping willow tree is in the synagogue's backyard. It has metal leaves on which family names of Hungarian Jews murdered in the Holocaust are carved.
On the last day of our stay, we visited the St Gerard Sagredo statue. It is one of the historical landmarks in Budapest.
The views from this place on top of the hill are stunning — one of the most visited attractions in Budapest.
Heroes Square is one of the major squares in Budapest. It has the museum of fine arts on the left and the Palace of art on the right.
The central feature is the Millennium memorial. The two colonnades behind the monument each have seven statues representing significant figures of Hungarian history.
“Travelling in the company of those we love is home in motion.”- Leigh Hunt.
The most significant benefit of family travel is bonding with the dearest people in your life and exploring places together.
Every year we look forward to family travel, visiting a new place, exploring and creating memories.
--
--
1
We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.
Coach. Mentor. Storyteller. I write from the heart—lessons from life, leadership, and the quiet moments that shape who we become.

Title: A Spontaneous trip to Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I wouldn’t classify myself as spontaneous. I always like to evaluate and ponder big decisions or dilemmas before taking any action. That being said I am becoming more aware of the privilege that being in my early 20s affords me. I am not settled in a specific place, have no real commitments apart from my work and no one yet depends on me to live their life. I find stating this particularly freeing, it is good to be able to make last-minute plans with friends and this is a luxury that is only typically afforded at the start and end of your life. However, this is not something I usually take advantage of and most recently I have been wanting to utilize it as I know I will miss it as life progresses.
In the company I work at, we have an internal shop slack channel where people can buy or sell goods. Last month, my friend spotted last-minute plane tickets being sold a week in advance for a weekend getaway to Budapest and naturally he suggested that we go. I was originally unsure about this, I wanted to spend this weekend achieving some tasks before climbing in Portland. But naturally, something in my mind told me to use this privilege in my life and go on the trip. So somewhat apprehensively I agreed! This blog is going to go over our adventure in Budapest!
Day 1
Our departing flight left at 8 am, so this meant a 5 am starting journey to Luton airport (thanks Ben for driving us). I typically don’t like taking early morning flights but I really enjoyed the experience of waking up early and being in another country by lunchtime.
Our flight landed just after lunch, and after getting through the terrible queues for passport control (thank you Brexit!) we got a bus and metro into town and picked out a great brunch spot for lunch called cookie beacon. This was a great restaurant to eat, it catered for Ben’s burger craving and my gluten allergy. They also had keto cookies, which were really good and filling. During this time we outlined what we wanted to achieve on this trip, where we wanted to go and the experiences we wanted to have.
We first headed into central Budapest (on the Pest side of the river) to check out a thermal bath. We decided that as it was a Friday, this was the best time to try and go to avoid it being overcrowded. We chose the Széchenyi Thermal Bath, while it is more expensive than some of the other baths it looked much better and was located in a lovely area near the central park. I would definitely recommend checking out a bath while in Budapest, while it is not on the level of the Blue Lagoon in Iceland they don’t have the eggy smell that sulphur baths have and unlike a swimming pool, they get very warm.
One word of advice is to make sure you bring your own flip-flops to these baths, most require you to wear them and the prices they charge for them are extortionate!
After spending the afternoon in the bath, we took a walk back to the Airbnb we picked out and cooked up some dinner, excited to make the most of our time in the country.
Day 2
As this was our only full day in Budapest we wanted to make the most of it. We decided to take an early morning walking tour of Budapest. These are pretty common in Europe, they are free to sign up for and the tour guide will expect tips at the end. I always enjoy taking these types of tours when a visit a new city, they are a great way to see as much of the city as you can and they provide much-needed context to any attractions.
We had a great tour guide (thanks Regina!), and some highlights for me included the St. Stephen’s Basilica church, the USSR and Nazi monuments and the Hungarian Parliament building. Regina was incredibly knowledgeable about all the sites we stopped off at and gave some great recommendations for clubs and bars in Budapest to visit.
One interesting moment for me during the tour was the Nazi monument. This monument was created in memory of the Nazi invasion and subsequent occupation of Hungary. As Regina explained to us, this statue has potential implications that Hungary is absolved from collaboration with the Nazi government and the actions that they took. As a result, this is a controversial attraction for some, especially Jewish Hungarians.
After taking the tour we grabbed some lunch and then walked across the river to Buda to visit the castle, stopping to take some scenic pictures of the Hungarian parliament building from the river.
To end our day we decided to double down on our spontaneity and go to a bar and club. We received a great piece of advice from Regina to visit the Szimpla Kert ruin bar, these ruin bars are built from bombed buildings in WW2. Instead of being rebuilt, they were minimally converted into bars and make for a really nice setting as they have a lot of natural light and character to them.
We ended our day with a night out at the Instant-Fogas Complex club. Clubbing is not something that I do often as in the past I have not had enjoyable experiences, but in the spirit of this holiday, I thought I would give it another go. Surprisingly we had a great time, even catching the closing stages of a Hungarian rock concert before the dancefloor started getting busy.
Day 3
After enjoying ourselves the night before we decided to have a lazy morning. We grabbed coffee at Anna’s cafe in the centre near the river and then relaxed in Elizabeth Square. At lunchtime, we headed back to the airport to catch our flight home.
Conclusions
Overall this was a really special trip for me. It took me outside of my comfort zone for the first time in a while and also took me away from my regular schedule. It felt really good to be spontaneous and I loved the trip. Budapest is a wonderful city full of beauty, character and history. Is it hard to comprehend coming from Britain that within the space of 70 or so years, Hungary has known 3 different types of political systems. It opens your mind and after all, that is the beauty of travelling, to take yourself out of your bubble and experience another country’s culture and educate yourself on their history.
Usually, I am very keen on planning out a schedule when going abroad, but during this trip I allowed myself to relax and let the plans get made as and when we chose to. There was something very freeing and relaxing about this. This was only possible as I had such good friends with me, I could trust that I could be honest with them and we had each other best interests at heart.
Overall this trip has been an amazing experience and I can’t wait to go on another weekend trip, spontaneous or not!
--
--
MSc AI and ML Student @ ICL. Ex ML Engineer @ Arm, Ex FPGA Engineer @ Arm + Intel, University of Warwick CSE Graduate, Climber. https://www.nathanbaileyw.com

Title: My First Day In Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
It was early on Thursday morning.
Neither my dad nor I got a good night’s sleep.
My father ate something which evidently didn’t agree with him.
While I was jittery with a mixture of anxiety and excitement.
Excited because I was about to visit a part of the world I’d never been to before:
Eastern Europe.
Prior to this experience, I’d never stepped foot in Eastern Europe before.
Sure, technically speaking, Istanbul is in Eastern Europe.
And I’d also been to Greece as a kid.
But this was different.
For the first time in my life, I’d be venturing deep into the land of the iron curtain.
I’d heard so much about this part of the world, and in modern times it’s been described as a European paradise.
All the benefits of capitalism while maintaining its traditional roots.
Something I wish I could say the same about Britain.
So yes, I was excited.
But I was also anxious.
Not about the journey, but about something else.
Namely my love life.
But I’ll save that for day 3.
Stick around and keep reading this series if you’d like to know what happens.
Either way, I barely got any sleep before our flight and was absolutely knackered.
I woke up around 8 and got ready for the taxi’s arrival at 9.
Everything was going according to plan.
We left the house at 9AM and zoomed off to the airport.
Despite the airport being miles away, we got there in just 45 minutes.
0 traffic = 0 problems.
The airport too was a walk in the park.
We checked our bags in with zero problems and got through security without a single hiccup.
I was a little nervous about the sheet of paper I’d been given by the immigration beaurea.
It didn’t look super legit and I wasn’t sure if I’d be turned away at passport control.
Thankfully, I didn’t and everything was cool.
We find our gate and chill out in the seats.
After a few minutes of listening to music and playing chess, we were ready to board the plane.
We queue up and see something strange…
Some people are being escorted out of the line and are being told some awful news.
Me and my dad looked at each other, puzzled.
What could possibly be going on?
Turns out, some people weren’t given any seats to board the plane!
It seems Budapest is quite a popular destination.
Thank goodness we had the foresight to check-in online prior to arriving at the airport, otherwise it would have been us who’d be escorted out of the line.
With a sigh of relief and a few empathetic looks, we were on the plane and seated.
The flight flew by in a flash as I slept through all of it.
2 hours later, we were in Budapest and ready to start our Eastern European adventure.
I’d done some research and was clued up on what to do once arriving at the airport.
We did all the formal stuff like going through passport control and picking up our bags.
Next came the fun part:
Finding our way into the city.
Me and my dad each bought a 15 day transport pass which allowed us unlimited access on every transportation in the city for… you guessed it, 15 days.
I had a look online and people were saying there was a week pass, but they’ve clearly changed it.
Either way, we grabbed one of those (called a 15-Day Budapest Pass) and made our way to the bus stop.
The plan was to get the 100E bus which would take us straight into the city centre.
We would have done this if it weren’t for the fact that our Budapest pass isn’t valid for that particular bus (typical).
I asked one of the conductors what to do and he told us we could get the 200E bus that would take us to where we needed to go.
Sweet!
I picked up a map and started doing some high IQ geographical calculations in my head.
I love this about going to a new place.
There’s a certain thrill about figuring out how to find your way around.
I do this everywhere I go.
When I first lived in Istanbul, I would always be hopping on different buses/tubes and exploring.
When I moved to London, I’d spend months venturing into the city centre and finding my way round.
Budapest was no exception.
We got on the 200E bus and ended up at the closest Metro station (Kőbánya-Kispest).
This was our first taste of Hungary, and I’m not gonna lie, it was weird.
A lot of the advertising was similar to the stuff you’d see in rural Turkey, except with a European twist.
Instead of a woman in a headscarf advertising a homemade pide restaurant, we had juiced up Europeans advertising a local supplement company.
The buildings were a mix of modern monstrosities and Soviet era crumblings.
It wasn’t until we entered the city of Budapest that I was faced with the sheer beauty of humanity’s potential.
There was also a moment where a homeless guy walked onto the bus and stunk the place up.
It brought me back to a sunny Spring day in Sheffield where a man who hadn’t showered in months had everyone gasping for fresh air with his stench.
Not exactly the warmest welcome…
From Kőbánya-Kispest we took the blue M3 Metro line to Ferenciek Tere.
If you’re curious, this is right into the centre of Pest and just a minutes walk from the Danube.
In hindsight, we didn’t need to go to this station as Deak Ferenc Ter (the stop before it) would have helped us get to our desired destination a lot faster.
Even so, we learnt this later on after some research.
From Ferenciek Tere we walked on the main street up towards Astoria and eventually reached Blaha Lujza Ter (where our hotel and subsequently our AirBNB was).
On our walk, we got our very first look at Budapest.
And honestly?
I was a little underwhelmed.
Lots of homeless people.
A strange smell in the air (mostly urine).
Much fewer Hungarians than I had pictured.
And it was absolutely scorching hot.
No doubt, this was my fault.
I had this idea of Hungary being a European bastion of beauty.
I expected everything to be pristine, clean and perfect.
With those kinds of high standards, I was bound to be met with some dissapointment.
If you’re Hungarian and reading this, don’t be offended.
I love Budapest.
I just want to give you my honest first impressions before fully discovering the true beauty of the city.
After a few minutes of walking, I noticed something concerning.
My dad was limping.
And he wasn’t limping a little, he was limping quite heavily.
He’d mentioned the night before our flight that he had a pain in his foot, and clearly the pain hadn’t subsided.
I asked him if he was alright and he grimaced back, “I’m fine, just get a bloody move on”.
I heard the man and we marched on towards our hotel.
We didn’t have to march long as within a few minutes were outside our hotel in the middle of town.
It was a really weird hotel.
Looked utterly rubbish on the outside, but the inside was as lavish as you could possibly imagine.
It’s called the Atrium Fashion Hotel and it’s located on Csokonai utca, one street behind the Blaha Lujza ter Metro station.
If you want to visit Budapest, I think you’d enjoy your time at this hotel.
Our room was cosy, the hotel staff were extremely helpful and friendly (Hi Adam!) and it’s right in the centre of Pest.
We were only there for one night, but we had a good time.
After getting into our room, we did what any normal people would do:
Have a shower and then a nap.
(Not together obviously, that would be weird lol).
After waking up, it was pretty late.
Like I said, neither of us slept well the night before and needed to recover.
Once we woke up, it was time to go for a wander.
My dad struggled to get into his trainers as his foot was as swollen as Arnold Schwarzenegger’s biceps. But once they were in, we were ready to go.
The first point of call was to find the place where my dad would be attending his business conference.
While he’d be spending most of his days in Budapest there, I’d be free to check out the Hungarian capital solo.
After swerving in and out of meandering side-streets, we were able to find the conference hall with little difficulty.
Weirdly, it was located right in the middle of Pest’s party district.
Surrounding the conference venue were plenty of pubs, bars and nightclubs which were teeming with tourists and locals all day and all night.
Luckily for us, we were also able to find an incredible Hungarian restaurant with a live pianist.
My dad instantly fell in love with the piano player and couldn’t stop applauding his every move.
I honestly think he loved the music more than the food, which is saying something because the food was outstanding.
I had a Goulash soup followed by a Goulash dish.
The result?
Love.
I officially love Hungarian food.
It’s incredible.
While I was busy guzzling down the wonderful meal that was in front of me, my dad was staring starry eyed at the pianist as he played love songs with his elegant fingers.
At one point, my dad got so into it that he began singing at the top of his lungs and began drawing confused looks from everyone in the restaurant.
My cheeks flushed red in embarassment as I pleaded for him to stop, but he wouldn’t listen:
“WEEEE ARE THE CHAMPIONS, MY FRIENDS…..
AND WEEEE’LL, KEEP ON FIIIGHTING TILL THE END…”
Safe to say we both had a great time on our first night in Budapest.
Tomorrow would be even better…
If you liked this little story, stay tuned for the next ones.
I’m going to be sharing everything I did and all the things I was feeling on my travels.
Thanks for reading,
Godfrey
P.S. If you want to create your own content creation business, click here and sign up to my email list.
I’ll send you a free guide that will help you start.
--

Title: The Most Interesting Statues in Budapest (and their stories)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Budapest, like other capital cities, have interesting memorials and statues that turn heads and force conversation. And there are plenty of them too; afterall, the largest statue park in Europe is also here, measuring a huge 56 hectares (Kerepesi Cemetery).
Memento Park is also just outside the city, and born from a difficult past. After the lifting of the Iron Curtain, Hungarians uprooted and dumped almost every statue placed during the communist period. Out of the city; out of the mind. The following are a list of the most interesting statues in Budapest.
Belgrád rkp., 1056
A lovely stroll down the Pest-side of the Danube pedestrian zone will bring you to these two wholesome figures. It’s a spitting distance to the ‘little princess’, and a beautiful place to photograph and take in the views of the Buda side. Look out for The Marriott Hotel.
Actually, not much is known about these statues, except that the Sculptor Raffay Dávid had known he wanted to be a sculptor from an early age — three years old!
Széchenyi Lánchíd, 1051
When I first arrived in Budapest, I was told the Myth about the Lions on the four corners of the Széchenyi Bridge. It goes a little something like this.
In 1852, sculptor János Marschalkó unveiled his stone work to be used on the recently opened Széchenyi Bridge. He was so proud of his work that he announced he would throw himself off the bridge if any faults were found. The story goes on to say that a girl spoke up that the lions had no tongues. He threw himself off the bridge out of embarrassment.
Whether he did or not, it’s a story full of passion, big-headedness, and a pinch of comedy (OK, tragedy). János Marschalkó lived well into the 1870’s, and for good reason — the lions HAVE tongues, they just can’t be seen from a low perspective.
NB — This made me think of The National Library in Sarajevo — Check it out!
Corvin sétány 1, 1082
I’m sure you know Bud Spencer — an actor, famous for adventure comedies, crime escapades and spaghetti westerns. This rootin’, tootin’ and gun-shootin’ Italian, originally from Naples, starred in over 50 films, a handful of TV and even a video game. Although Budapest is well known for filmmaking, Bud Spencer never came to Budapest, neither filmed any scenes here. So why the statue?
Bud Spencer didn’t receive the attention he did until he teamed up with Terence Hill in the late 60’s. Together, they created simple yet action packed films that everyone around the world could enjoy. Hungarians, during the communist occupation, fell in love with the entertainment he brought with each new film. They were the popular stars from a foreign country — an attractive one from outside the communist reach. Although they appeared dubbed, the story lines were easy enough to follow without needing to know the language.
The huge bronze statue weighs in at half a ton, and was placed there a year after his death in 2016 by sculptor Szandra Tasnádi as a beautiful sign of respect. It is the first one of its kind, and at the unveiling was Cristiana Pedersoli (daughter) and Olympic water polo player György Kárpáti (friend). The inscription “We never fought” were the words Terrence Hill used to describe Bud at his funeral.
Zrínyi u., 1051
One of the most visited and famous statues in Budapest is the fat policeman — you can tell by his shiny belly. His location couldn’t get any better as he gets to stare at the St. Stephan's Basilica all day. Tourists can’t help but get a snap of themselves with him.
The fat policeman statue in central Budapest was sculptured by Illyés András in 2008, and can be found on the corner of Zrínyi and Október 6. Street. The sculpture itself was based on the characteristics of peoples faces dwelling in the city, with the portly physique taken from the sculptors grandfather.
Práter u. 11, 1082
This collection of statues portrays a group of boys playing marbles outside an old brick school building. It is a depiction of a scene early on in the book Pál utcai fiúk — the Paul Street Boys.
You’ll find this gem just round the corner from Corvin Shopping Plaza.
This book by Hungarian author Ferenc Molnár tells the story of two gangs of children fighting over rundown territory. The book became hugely popular and turned into a famous Hungarian classic, still taught in primary school.
NB — If you like this story, the National Museum in Budapest has created a marble run and area in honour of the Pal Street Boys — perfect for young kids!
Walking Tour Idea — If you're looking for a street map of these statues, check out our link here.
Falk Miksa u., 1055
Columbo is one of Hungary’s most admired characters — it might have something to do with Peter Falk’s Hungarian heritage. His mother, a Jewish Hungarian emigrated to the States before he was born.
His statue shows his typical thinking posture with cigar in hand, while his basset hound dog named ‘dog’ stares at him patiently. Funnily enough, the statue was placed opposite the National Comedy Theatre, and visible from Jászai Mari square.
Dob u. 12, 1072
Carl Lutz was the Budapest based Swiss Vice-Consul from 1942 until 1945 — the end of World War II. As a designer and leader of the largest most successful rescue operation, he was instrumental in saving more than 62,000 Hungarian Jews. In fact, Budapest is the only capital in Eastern Europe where enough Hungarian Jews survived to continue their community — over 100,000.
You’ll find these statues one block away from the Dohány Street Synagogue’s Tree Of Life. The inscription reads: In the building at Szabadság tér 12, Swiss Vice Consul Carl Lutz honorably represented the interests of the United States of America and other countries between 1942 and 1945. He courageously saved the lives of tens of thousands of Hungarian citizens persecuted as Jews.
Belgrád rkp., 1051
The Little Princess statue is one of the most famous sculptures in Budapest because of its perfect location. This statuette sits on the railings next to the pedestrian area on the Pest side of the Danube and scenic Tram 2. Expect great views and a perfect place for photographs.
The artist, László Marton created this in 1972, taking his eldest daughter as inspiration. Apparently, she would wear his dressing gown and parade around as a princess. This statue is so loved that copies have sprung up in the Hungarian town of Tapolca and in front of the concert hall of the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Space in Japan.
Szabadság tér 16, 1054
Ronald Reagan is a little strange as a statue in Budapest, let alone in the very important Freedom Square (Szabadság tér). It feels out of place until you realise it was created to honour Reagan and his efforts in ending the cold war. The end of the cold war would end the Soviet occupation of Hungary.
The positioning is perfect — not only is he walking toward the American Embassy, he is also staring at the monument dedicated to the Soviet liberation of Hungary in World War II from Nazi German occupation.
Vajdahunyad stny, City Park, 1146
One of the most fascinating statues in Budapest is the one known as ‘Anonymous’, and definitely one of my favourites. The hooded man is sitting in a relaxed pose, holding a pen. An inscription starts with a capital ‘P’, and continues with “dictus magister ac quondam bone memorie gloriosissimi Bele regis Hungarie notarius” (and Bela the master of the king of Hungary was struck by the notary who were once of the most glorious of good memory). The ‘P’ is likely his name, or an abbrev. of praedictus, meaning ‘aforementioned’.
The anonymous statue of Budapest was the notary of the Hungarian king Béla III, and famous for his work Gesta Hungarorum (“The Deeds of the Hungarians”) over 800 years ago. It’s the most detailed account of the Hungarians’ arrival to the Carpathian basin. Being a very important writer, people make their way to the inner court area of the Vajdahunyad Castle to touch his pen, and receive special, ungodly writing powers. Worth a try.
These statues of peoples shoes on the Danube river bank hold on to one of the haunting and saddest situations in Hungary’s history. These 60 pairs of shoes are a memory to those who were killed by Arrow Cross Party in 1944–45. Let’s back up a little.
When Germany waged war through Europe, it was only a matter of time before their attention came to Hungary. The government was overthrown in October 1944, Ferenc Szalasi was the puppet that took the job. His fascist and antisemitic ideas were poured into the Arrow Cross Party, who beat and killed Jewish citizens of the city.
As shoes were valuable, the victims were made to remove their shoes before being executed and left to fall into the cold, strong current of the Danube. Almost 100,000 Jews vanished. 80,000 Jews left the country by force, and the other 20,000 were shot along the river banks. These life-sized shoes with amazing detail were installed in 2005 by Can Togay (Director; The Summer Guest) and Gyula Pauer (Sculptor).
--
--
Photographer & Educator

Title: “The City of Smiles”- Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A lot of Hungarian soldiers and civilians died during World War I and their loved ones went numb. Their fathers, brothers, husbands and sons were somewhere away from home, either mixed in soil or were feeding themselves to birds. Until then Budapest was more attractive than a magnet to tourists from every part of the world. The post-war effects and an approach of the new war engulfed Budapest.
Budapest was now in the arms of mass suicides, which arose from the day of losing their loved ones. Budapest became “The city of Suicides”. Will you believe me if I say all these happened because of a popular song “Gloomy Sunday”, which was printed in Sunday Times? It was also called ‘the suicide song’ and ‘the killer song’. It was written in a hundred languages around the world and has claimed to have killed hundreds of people.
All the people who drowned in the deep waters of Danube River had left behind the newspaper cutting of Sunday Times, which had the lyrics of the song. It was composed by Rezső Seress and published in 1933. Here are the lines.
“Not where the black coach of sorrow has taken you
Angels have no thought of ever returning you
Would they be angry if I thought of joining you?
Gloomy Sunday
Death is no dream,
For in death I’m caressing you
With the last breath of my soul I’ll be blessing you
Gloomy Sunday”
The song somehow gave hope to all the people who wanted to reunite with their loved ones.
In 1937, ‘The Sunday Times’ wrote an article on the “ City of Suicides”. It’s funny how the newspaper criticises and asks to ban the song and the lyricist for suicides. When it was The Sunday Times, who propagated and shared those lines throughout Budapest in the first place. The song was then banned on radios.
The politicians, social activists, common people were searching for a solution. To bring out people from their sad lives. And now professor Jeno and hypnotist Binczo brought out the“Smile School”. This was to counteract the unending love for suicides.
People of Budapest had already forgotten how to smile. Not even a four-year-old smiled. The Smile School was introducing them to a different world. At first people were made to wear a smiling mask. Teaching them, how to smile by hiding their feelings inside. They thought that teaching the people how to smile would make them happier. And finally forget the pain!
Then they started teaching different styles of smile, the Roosevelt smile, the Mona Lisa smile, the Dick Powell smile, the Loretta smile, and a lot more. They could choose the smile of any celebrity they loved and the fees was depending on the type of smile they want to master. They claimed to charge up to $500 for teaching the Roosevelt smile in six weeks. Roosevelt had the best smile!
The Mona Lisa smile is more difficult but cheaper. They were asked to do the smiles they were learning five times a day, using a mirror. Founder of Smile School, hypnotist Jeno said says the best business is enabling pupils to achieve the talent of smiling naturally.
Thousands of people around Budapest joined the Smile Schools desperately to learn how to smile! All around the world, where Budapest was once called the “ City of Suicides” a new name came up, “The City of Smiles.” However there was no reduction in suicides, the change was only in the name!
There were still people dying around with the song “ Gloomy Sunday” near the banks of Danube.
By then the whole Smile School was proved to be a hoax by Het Leven.
BUDAPEST, “CITY OF SUICIDES,” IS TAUGHT TO FORCE A SMILE
A joker in Budapest, Hungary lately evolved the “smile school” The idea was made in purpose to counteract the bad publicity Budapest has gotten from the number of suicides supposedly inspired by the Budapest song, Gloomy Sunday. The suicide rate in Budapest is actually very high, even now.
The Smile School was then shut down, with the beginning of World War II. But this simple odd idea of teaching people smile led to the evolution of Laughter brigades and Laughter clubs around the world!
Love,
Dona
--
--
💻 Engineer | 📚 Storyteller | 💡 Always curious | 😁 Witty on a good day

Title: 10 Beautiful Things To Do In Budapest — dcglobejotters
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I wasn’t ready for Budapest.
In 2004, T, my sister, brother-in-law, and I found super cheap flights to Budapest and decided to travel there on a whim. Being that it was 2004, Budapest wasn’t on many travelers’ radars like it is now.
Of course we expected it to be beautiful, much like many of the other European cities we had previously visited. But we had no idea just how majestic and spellbinding Budapest truly is. A magical merge of striking allure, historical grandeur, and cutting-edge grittiness that had us enamored right from the start.
There are so many things to love about Budapest, but here’s a good start: it’s brimming with stunning architecture, amazing thermal baths, breathtaking views, and a distinguished culture.
Still not convinced? It’s extraordinarily affordable, especially when compared to many other European cities.
Below are the top ten things to do in beautiful Budapest.
One of the most iconic landmarks in all of Hungary, the Parliament Building is a spectacular example of exquisite Neo-Gothic architecture. This masterpiece of a building is a popular tourist attraction, equally due to its magnificent splendor and idyllic location along the meandering Danube River. It’s worth walking around the back as well to get the full scale of its grandness, as well as the sheer beauty of the structure.
Hailing as the second longest river in all of Europe, it’s pretty much impossible to miss this imposing Danube River. Riverside strolls and sails are not only a must here, they’re pretty much inevitable. The Danube River is the beating pulse of Budapest, coursing its way through the expansive city.
Fun fact: The capital city of Budapest was the result of the unification of separate towns of Buda and Pest in 1873.
One of the many things we loved about Budapest is its walkability, and perhaps nowhere within the city encourages individuals to explore it by foot than the Szechnyi Chain Bridge.The pedestrian-friendly bridge offers fantastic views of both Buda and Pest and is one of the main bridges in Budapest that links the majority of sites.
Perched upon Castle Hill, Fisherman’s Bastion is a remarkable spot to enjoy panoramic views of the river and Pest beyond it. Its historical charm and opulence outweigh the fellow tourists that will inevitable accompany your visit. Think striking towers, spilling-over terraces, and attractive cobbled streets. A lovely spot to soak up Budapest’s radiance.
This luxurious historical castle and royal palace complex pays homage to the Hungarian kings. As the most prominent building of Castle Hill, it dominates the hill and provides beyond impressive views of the city and river. While it’s worth visiting at any time of the day, nightfall is particularly special when it’s dramatically illuminated.
Thing to know: Riding the funicular is a relatively cheap and scenic way to reach the Buda Castle hill. Click here for rates and hours of operation.
Promise me this: you will not leave Budapest without visiting at least one of its delightful spas and soaking in its thermal baths. One of the highlights of our trip was spending an afternoon at Gellert Spa and Bath. Dating back to 1918, Gellert Baths is one of the city’s oldest and most famous bathhouses.
The building’s interior is ornate and lavish, with a number of various wellness treatments offered. My sister and I opted for a massage and soak in the heated pools. Note that the establishment does get busy, so you may want to go on the earlier (or later) side in hopes of avoiding large crowds. We visited later in the day and found the spa and pools to be pretty quiet. Remember to pack your swimwear and some thick skin-the Hungarian masseuses are known to be very strong and firm (I can definitely attest to this!).
It should be no surprise that Hungarian food is HEAVY. Stick-to-your-ribs heavy. But also, pretty damn delicious. Depending on what time of year you travel to Hungary, your level of appreciation for its gluttonous heavy ways may vary. It was cold during our travels, and our bellies and souls craved as much warming comfort food as we could possibly get. So you might say that we welcomed all of its savory goulashes, stews, and soups with open hearts and eager tastebuds.
Hungarian cuisine is the epitome of comfort food, and we wouldn’t have wanted it any other way.
Hands down the best meal of the trip was at Gundel, a formal restaurant that serves delicious gourmet Hungarian fare.
There is no shortage of grand and historical coffeehouses in Budapest. If you need to seek some solace from the cold, you are in for a real treat-we absolutely loved the cafe scene here. The most charming and delightful of all of the cafes that we visited was Gerbaud, an elegant cafe that’s worthy of the hype (and elevated prices).
The coffee, pastries, and desserts were decadently divine. We absolutely loved it here.
As mentioned previously, Budapest is a gloriously walkable city, with an efficient and reliable metro system to boot, making it a very easy city to explore. Take the time to meander and marvel at the unique architecture, iconic sites, and distinctive neighborhoods.
Heroes’ Square St. Stephen’s Basilica
Okay, so technically not in Budapest, but beautiful and lovely nonetheless, is Szentendre, an enchanting and picturesque Hungarian town alongside the Danube. A short and simple forty-five minute train ride delivers you directly to the quaint little village of a town, characterized by baroque architecture, historical churches, colorful houses and narrow, cobbled streets.
The charming main square and alleyways are lined with museum and art galleries, adorable shops and boutiques, and cozy restaurants and cafes.
We were captivated by Szentendre’s beauty and quietness. An absolutely delightful day trip from Budapest!
Four full days gave us a great introduction to the amazingness of Budapest. With its more recent rise in popularity, I’d love to return one day, especially to see how much the city has changed. Wishing you the happiest of travels to beautiful Budapest and beyond!
Recent Reads: Porto & Douro Valley, Cape Town, Kaieteur Falls
Originally published at http://dcglobejotters.org on May 2, 2019.

Travel and D.C.blogger obsessed with food, wine, coffee, yoga, books, and seeing every inch of this gorgeous world.

Title: Budapest June 2025
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Travelling and seeing as many places as I can is a passion. It has never been solely about showcasing pictures just for the sake of it. It’s always been about the culture, community, language of communication, behaviour of the people, the structures, monuments, the history behind it and more such. It’s about knowing and absorbing and sharing this knowledge through written work and of course images corresponding to them.
Two days spent in Budapest, the capital of Hungary 🇭🇺 was like having been there for a long time. The way we devoured the sights of this city divided in two parts by the Danube River was just nothing short of amazing. This is an enchanting city with a vintage feel. Though the whole of Europe has an old world charm, there are differences in the structures and monuments from city to city.
We left on a Sunday morning by train from Vienna to Budapest with our daughter and family. It took only a little more than two and a half hours. The train was super comfortable where we could play card games with our little grandson who was our chief entertainer. Once there we took local trams and trains, hopping in and out of them to get around. But it was mostly a walking tour with our 4 year old in tow. He had his scooter and stroller when he required them. In his name we took a few ice cream and snack breaks. It was 35 degrees in the scorching sun which we combated with water, hats and sunscreen, running to the shaded parts of the promenades whenever possible.
After checking in at the hotel in Pest, we headed to Vajdahunyad Castle. It is a grand castle which has parts of buildings from different time periods displaying varied architectural styles. Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque. Its facade looks like a fairy tale castle. It’s an amazing amalgamation with a vast garden around it. This castle with vibrant stain glass windows, houses a museum of the Hungarian life over the years. It features their farming culture, use of animals such as cattle and horses. All the floors are lined with portrayals of the village life. Our grandson had an exciting time in the castle museum looking and touching all the stuffed real looking animals. He could even milk a fake cow.
The garden at the castle is vast, well tended and lush.
There is a sinister looking statue of a hooded person in the courtyard. It reminded me of ‘He who must not be named’ or Lord Voldemort from Harry Potter. It is the statue of Anonymus, created by Miklós Ligeti. Anonymus was a 12th-century chronicler whose real name remains a mystery. He served as a notary to King. He inspired the Dracula stories in books and movies. On the outer wall of the castle, there’s also a bust of Béla Lugosi, the Hungarian-American actor who is renowned for his role as Count Dracula in the original 1931 film.
While coming out of the castle grounds, we saw a hot air balloon at a distance. Naturally we walked towards it to go up in the air on it. When we approached the ticket counter and enquired we were told the balloon will go up only at 6 pm. It was only noon time and it was impossible to come back for it. We all felt ‘deflated’ by it.
Budapest is made up of two formerly separate cities, Buda and Pest, which lie on opposite sides of the Danube River. The Chain Bridge, which we saw from a distance, completed in 1849, was the first to connect them. In 1873, the two cities were officially unified under the name Budapest. We remained in the Pest side as we didn’t have time to go to Buda. Perhaps when we come next, we can only cover Buda, which apparently is a classier and more residential part of the city.
In spite of the intense heat, we lingered at the banks of the Danube which reflected the blue of the sky with a few boats floating on it. We saw the majestic looking Parliament building, which is the largest building in Hungary. Built in 1904, it’s a gothic structure influenced by the City Hall in Vienna. It’s declared as a UNESCO Heritage site.
While searching online for places to visit, my daughter came across this powerful memorial. Lined along the riverbank are worn looking cast iron shoes, symbolizing the Jewish victims shot into the Danube during World War II. Seeing it deeply moved me, as it brought the horrors of that time to life. This was created by film director Can Togay and sculptor Gyula Pauer. It honours Jews killed by members of the Arrow Cross Party. Victims were forced to remove their shoes before being shot, their bodies falling into the river. The memorial marks the place where they stood ..only their shoes remained.
The one regret I have is not having been able to go across the famous Chain Bridge to Buda. I looked at it longingly, the beauty of it enhanced by the blue of the Danube. Designed by English engineer William Tierney Clark and built by Scottish engineer Adam Clark, it was the first bridge across the Danube in Hungary. It was opened in 1849.
We stayed in Pest as it’s the livelier side, full of attractions, and it’s where most tourists end up wanting to spend their time in Budapest. It was crowded in the popular squares of the area where we stopped in shaded cafes to have cool drinks. Great for people watching. The Intercity Hotel was very comfortable. We slept well out of sheer exhaustion that night and had a filling breakfast in the morning.
Next day we went in search of The Metropolitan Ervin Szabó Library in Budapest, famous for its vintage interiors. It is a sprawling public library complex, with its main structure in an ornate 19th-century former palace, built in neo baroque style. Unfortunately we could not go into the classical side because there was a film shooting going on. What a disappointment! We had to make do with wandering in the less interesting part where there was a modern lending library. We admired the facade and had lunch at a near by open restaurant with our little hero making up games and running all around. I had an interesting salad with sun-dried tomatoes, red lettuce and Hungarian cheese topped with blueberry marmalade.
We debated going to Buda for a quick visit but we were not sure whether we would get back to the train station in time for our return. We decided to go and see the largest synagogue in Europe which was a few minutes walk away. It is a magnificent structure built between 1854 and 1859. It has twin octagonal towers topped by onion domes which has an oriental touch. The Star of David is embossed into the stone tablets. There is alternating yellow and red brick work on the imposing building ..standing the test of time.
Again sadly we could not go in because it was time to get back to our hotel for our luggage and head to the station. But we were happy to view the awe inspiring facade.
Some of the underground metro stations take you back in time like the late 1800s or early 1900s because of its vintage feel. It is compact and quaint in its tiled look with wooden benches and frames. Took me back into another era. Loved the ageless feeling while waiting for train which itself looked as if it was from another time long past. I visualised suited, hatted gentlemen with their canes or hooked umbrellas and slender women in long frocks and fashionable hats of that time waiting at the station.
I forgot to mention the street book shop that we saw while walking towards the Ervin Sazbo Library. It was heartening to see the lovely colourful cart with hoards of books surrounded by eager buyers. Mostly Hungarian books, so we didn’t delve further. We also passed by a big well organised secondhand book store with books from floor to ceiling.
Though there were hardly any books in English, it was a sight to behold and to be photographed.
On Sunday after our sightseeing and long walks in the hot sun, we went for dinner in a restaurant where they served beverages on little trains. This place was chosen for the youngest and most important traveller in our group. We ordered Hungarian food and drinks. It was fascinating to see the drinks coming on mini trains. There were railway tracks on every table. There was live music by musicians who came from table to table. They played a Greek song for us at our request along with Hungarian and German. It was a unique experience.
On our return train, I dozed off almost half the way vaguely listening to the little fella’s chatter like a lullaby in the background. Felt good to be back to our present turf reminiscing about the two days well spent in Budapest, thanks to our daughter and son in law. A special thanks to the little one for entertaining us all through.
Mallika Menon
About the author:
Mrs Mallika Menon, English literature MA, B.Ed, Diploma in Journalism, is an English teacher, Yoga Instructor and a Journalist residing in Bangalore, India, after a long stint of living in Greece. Also an ardent Traveller to different countries exploring culture, history and sights.

Budapest has become one of the top tourist destinations in Europe, for a good reason. Often, we do not recognize the beauty of the place that we live in anymore. But Budapest is simply amazing, and there is no reason to argue about it. It is not a city to tick in one or two days. Here you can easily spend a week discovering something new. But as in every place, being a tourist or live and work somewhere are two different things. Read till the end of this article if you want to know more about the complex image and the less charming sides of Budapest as well.
After having been to several corners of Europe, I can say that Budapest is the most picturesque city at night when it is enveloped in lights. No, it is not Paris. Budapest is the city divided by the river Danube into two parts, Buda as Pest. Hence the name Budapest.
I can be bored of seeing Jungfrau in Switzerland, the picturesque villages of Austria, or the countless churches of Italy. Still, I cannot cross the river Danube without throwing an eye on the ensemble of stunning monuments (The Buda castle, The Fisherman’s Bastion, The Chain Bridge, the…

Title: Budapest’s Coffee Obsession: A Historical and Cultural Exploration of Hungary’s Coffee Houses and Its Influence on Society
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Food | Travel | Culture

Member-only story
--
Share
Today, coffee is more than just a drink; it’s a necessary component of the traditional morning ritual. Coffee plays an essential role in daily life, whether you stumble out of bed and head straight for the cafetière or impatiently wait in line, hoping the barista rushes to serve you a flat white so you can get to work on time. Coffee has become a cultural phenomenon embedded in societies worldwide, but the journey of coffee stretches far beyond the early-morning hustle of today’s world. In Budapest, coffee is one of the many threads of the city’s rich tapestry. This documentary, Budapest’s Coffee Obsession, takes audiences on a historical exploration of rich brewing techniques through the travels of coffee lover Lyrkan Thuery. This paper will begin by conducting a brief textual analysis of two screen productions: Rise of Empires: Ottomans (2020) and The Story Of Coffee (2016). The analysis of the two…
