Title: Budapest = Buda + Pest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Share
I knew the Danube River and Hungary at a very young age because of piano — Johann Strauss’s “The Blue Danube”. Nearly 15 years later, in 2014, I finally paid a visit to Hungary.
The Danube river is like a belt twining in the mid Europe. Budapest, straddles the banks of the Danube River, and the buildings in the city are pearls on the Danube belt. I arrived at Budapest at the end of April, as an unprecedented heat wave washed over Europe — from Berlin ,Warsaw, Krakow, Prague, to Budapest, the heat wave was chasing me, along with sudden showers that often arrived late afternoon. When it was not raining, the earth was shrouded in heat radiation.
Budapest used to be two cities — Buda, and Pest. Buda was the capital city, and is presently the capitol. Across the river, Pest is 2 times bigger, where most of the city residents live.
The front foot of Pest was already in modernity, everywhere is Costa Coffee,European version of Starbucks, and every car has a European Union’s license plate, indicating the reform and transition of Hungary; and the back foot was still halted in the old time, as trolleys in 1950s styles were still running, and the marble exterior of most buildings were with had turned into yellow over the years. Pest barely had urban forestry. Exposure to excessive sunlight in late April had melted my skin, as if was some sort of ice cream. Perhaps a while back ago, Pest did have sufficient street trees, but those trees withered. There were always a few corners of the street, full of overgrown glasses, existing there alone without the accompany of street tress.
I did some of my schoolwork (I was an exchange student in a university at Germany) on the first night at a Costa. The coffee shop was quite empty, I was facing a window covered by raindrops that look like crystal sticking on the glass window, reflecting the night light on the street. Only one waitress was serving behind the bar, and she was as young as me. I biked along the river bank crossed the bridge between Buda and pest, again and again. Even Pest was where most of the city population resided, its streets were quite empty, besides a bunch of tourists sitting on the outdoor seating of the cafés around the street corners.
Then the late afternoon rain started dropping. I hided in a Costa Coffee until the rain died down. I paddled the bike over the stone road shining like mirror after the shower. When I got back to the hostel we stayed, I ordered some dishes from the Turkish restaurant across the street — Budapest used to be the biggest Jewish populated city. Millions of Jews were transported to Auschwitz from this city. It’s also the biggest resided city of Romanic people, now, it also a population of Turkish immigrants.
I fled to a Costa coffee until The last night at Budapest, before our departure back to Germany, we met our temporary roommate in the hostel, a Korean lady, around 40 years old- she was single, just quitted her job, flied from South Korea to the European continent, travel alone around Europe. She slept on the upper level of the bunk bed, above me.
About Me:
Made in China. Grew up and lived in China for 24.5 years, resided at Germany for 6 months and travel across Europe. I’ve been living in U.S for nearly 5 years now.
--
--
Made in China. Polyglot. Writes about AI X climate X Personal Growth, sometimes oral history

Title: (Hungary) Budapest Life: Where Beauty Meets Everyday Life
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Let me tell you something upfront — Budapest isn’t the kind of city that screams for your attention like Paris or New York. It doesn’t shove its famous landmarks in your face. Instead, Budapest whispers. It draws you in quietly, one crumbling facade, one steaming chimney, one café window at a time. You don’t just “visit” Budapest — you drift through it.
I’ve walked these streets on misty winter mornings when the Danube looks like a silver ribbon cutting through the grey, and I’ve wandered them under the lazy orange glow of summer evenings when locals sit outside sipping fröccs and laughing like they’ve got all the time in the world. Budapest’s charm lives not only in its grand buildings but in the cracks between them.
This post isn’t about the tourist checklist. You already know the Parliament building looks like a gothic wedding cake and that the Chain Bridge is Instagram-worthy from every angle. I want to talk about the streets, the people, the smells, the awkward little corners where life in Budapest feels raw, imperfect, and utterly human.
You know you’re in the real Budapest when the sidewalks get uneven. The main boulevards — Andrássy Avenue, for example — are polished and postcard-perfect. But duck into the side streets, and suddenly the city exhales. Laundry flaps in courtyards, tiny grocery stores glow under flickering neon, old women with floral scarves shuffle along clutching plastic bags, and young students sit on crumbling stoops scrolling on their phones.
There’s graffiti here — some of it art, some of it just bored teenagers marking territory. But the layers of history are impossible to miss. You’ll pass an art nouveau balcony hanging precariously over a 1970s shoe repair shop. Above, the cracked stucco peels like old paint, revealing the city’s stubborn spirit underneath.
Walk around District VIII — Józsefváros. It’s raw, rough around the edges, but it’s real. Here, hip cafés with Edison bulbs and oat milk lattes sit side-by-side with corner bars where old men drink Unicum and mutter about politics. If you want shiny, sanitized Europe — this isn’t it. But if you want life? Welcome to Budapest.
Budapest has a specific smell — part bakery, part car exhaust, part sweet paprika floating from someone’s kitchen window. And yes, sometimes a hint of cigarettes — Hungarians smoke like it’s still 1995. But that mixture? It feels like a real city. A city where people live, not just pose for photos.
Stop by a pékség (bakery) in the morning. The langos might already be sizzling in oil, but most locals are grabbing simple pastries — kifli (crescent rolls), túrós batyu (sweet cheese pockets), maybe a slice of pogácsa (savory scone) if they skipped breakfast. Coffee? Strong. Cheap. No nonsense. Just the way it should be.
Here’s what I love — Budapest locals don’t care that you’re a tourist. They’re not rude, they’re not overly friendly — they’re just… doing their thing. If you want to fit in, keep your voice down, your head up, and your eyes open. Don’t expect big grins and “How’s your day going?” — this isn’t Disneyland. But ask for directions? Most people will help. Stumble through a few words in Hungarian? Their eyes soften immediately.
My favorite? Watching older folks play chess in the parks, completely oblivious to the TikTok kids filming dance videos nearby. It’s two worlds colliding — but that’s Budapest.
Skip the overpriced tourist menus on Váci Street. Head to the side streets for hearty, grandmother-approved meals. Goulash soup in a steaming ceramic bowl. Crispy duck legs with red cabbage. Cheap, buttery nokedli dumplings. It’s heavy. It’s filling. It’s perfect for cold evenings when your breath fogs the air.
And the bakeries? Let me say it again — never underestimate a Hungarian pastry.
Okay, let’s get real for a second. Budapest might feel like another world, but getting here isn’t rocket science.
Budapest Ferenc Liszt International Airport (BUD) welcomes budget airlines and major carriers alike. From most European cities, flights hover around €30–€100 if you book smart. From the US? Expect around $500–$800 round-trip, depending on the season.
Skip the overpriced taxis at arrivals. The 100E Airport Bus runs straight to the city center for about €5. Runs every 20 minutes. Easy.
It wasn’t the fancy cafés or grand architecture. It was this random Tuesday morning in early spring. Light drizzle. Streets still wet from rain. I ducked into a tiny coffee shop off Kálvin tér. The window fogged up as I sipped bitter coffee and listened to Hungarian indie rock playing softly. Outside, people hurried past with umbrellas, the city carrying on, oblivious to my little moment of stillness.
That? That’s why I travel. Not for the bucket list. For the seconds in between.
Budapest is rough around the edges, sometimes crumbling, often unpredictable — but never fake. It doesn’t try to impress you with perfection. It lets you discover its flaws, its beauty, its rhythm — and decide for yourself.
You might not “fall in love” instantly. But give it time. Walk the streets. Breathe in the mix of pastry, paprika, and city life. Listen to the language you don’t understand but somehow feels familiar.
And when you leave? You’ll miss it — I promise.
--
--
Global logistics expert with experience living in multiple countries. Sharing insights on international trade, diverse cultures, and travel adventures

Title: Wes Anderson in a Box: Framing The Grand Budapest Hotel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I know this is a blog about photography, but it’s also a blog about the way that we create and interpret imagery. I find Wes Anderson’s films a perfect focal point for this discussion about image, storytelling, and framing. Both because of what people seem to inherently understand about Anderson’s unique aesthetic, and also because of what people regularly misrepresent or ignore.
I’m not going to introduce Wes Anderson because if you’re reading this, you know his films. We all have our favourites- often the films which got us started with his 50s toned, highly symmetrical movies (mine is Rushmore). Today I’ll be talking about 2014’s The Grand Budapest Hotel and later about 2021’s The French Dispatch, because these films present (to me) a progression of Anderson’s use of the cinematic frame as a storytelling device.
Note on history of format and aspect ratio
35mm motion picture film- that is, the film itself- wasn’t a particularly revelatory technology. Industrial processing for 70mm photographic roll film was already established, and filmmaker WK Dickson found that by splitting the roll in half you got two 35mm rolls which were ample enough to capture the image rendered by lenses of the time.
Like many stories in early film history, Thomas Edison stuck his head in, forcing Dickson to spend the next five years attempting in vain to establish a new standard. But in the end and to this day, the economics of 35mm film have kept it as the standard, first capitalising on 70mm film industrialization, and later on its own mass production before any other format had the chance to get off the ground.
Traditional spherical lenses project a circular image. We cut the sides off for convenience and to avoid the outside edges of the image circle, which tend to be blurry. The most judicious use of the image circle (beyond simply leaving it circular) is to square it, which remains the standard in some large format photography. This square is, however, at odds with human perception. Every person experiences vision differently, but with two round eyes spaced apart, we can fairly assume that most people see the world significantly wider than square, and the history of aspect ratio is the economics and technology of rendering a cinematic image that better resembles our own eyes.
Early widescreen was limited by lens and film fidelity. You can only cut so far into your image before degrading the quality, widescreen had some success in using larger format 70mm film, but the most common ratios sat around 4:3. A slightly wider square, which was codified as the Academy Ratio after sound was added to movies.
The 4:3 academy frame was wider than square, without significantly reducing the amount of film (and ergo fidelity) used by each frame. Throughout the 1930s and 40s the Great Depression cut into discretionary spending, 70mm film was considered too expensive to use, and further widescreen advances lay dormant.
By the 1950s, the mainstream adoption of television forced filmmakers to innovate. Widescreen implementations which were as simple as changing the matte in a projector were only possible by letterboxing already small tv screens.
In 1952, 20th Century Fox bought rights to a military technology which allowed for wide angle viewing from inside tanks via oval lenses, and coming out with The Robe a year later– the first film shot in ‘scope’ format. Anamorphic lenses squeeze the image on the way into the film plane, allowing twice as much width to fit into a piece of film. The image is in turn desqueezed by the projector, turning a 4:3 frame of 35mm film into a 1:2.9 image. In 1954 Vistavision was established as a more economical way to widen screens, flipping 35mm negative sideways to give an aspect of 1:1.5 which could be further cropped to 1:2 and the modern television standard 1:1.85 (16:9).
Aspect Ratio in The Grand Budapest Hotel
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a nesting doll of narratives. We open to the shrine of a dead author, a visitor holds a book (The Grand Budapest Hotel), and turns to the author’s picture on the back cover. We match cut to the author in an office in 1985, the author tells us about the way stories fall into your lap once the world knows your an author. The aspect ratio changes to 1:1.85 (16:9).
The film is going to pull this menouvre on us often, and it’s keen to make us aware that multiple threads of storytelling are going to take place. It also wants us to know that these stories are being buffed a little with a polish of nostalgic recollection. When our author calls the hotel, “a picturesque, elaborate and once widely celebrated establishment” we cut again to 4:3, and a bright pink hotel reveals itself against an obvious matte painting and a foreground of dimensionless buildings. This part of the story, the filmmaking insists, is literally flattened by layers of recollection as the author character declares, “The incidents that follow were described to me exactly as I present them here, and in a wholly unexpected way.”
Through the remainder of Grand Budapest the moving frame lines serve to remind us not only that there are multiple timelines, but that each timeline is filtered through its own series of storytellers. Wes Anderson’s visuals get flack for being so easily identifiable, but they have an in-text justification in Grand Budapest, where the further removed our author gets from the action, the more the world takes on qualities of the fanciful and make-believe.
Throughout the film, danger is framed by windows- the Zubrowkan army enter the film via a train window, they are spied through a window in the hotel, and Dmitri’s henchman Joplin pursues Deputy Kovacs, first visible through a bus window: Danger abounds, but the existential threat of war seems almost out of scope with the limitations of the story. In the scene of Gustave’s death the frame is robbed of its intense colour, too raw still for Zero the storyteller (Agatha’s death is given no screen time, only narration over imagery of their wedding.)
Why?
So the movie is a nesting doll of different narratives which get progressively distorted through storytelling. It’s a study in the stories we tell, the people and places, we remember, and how we remember them. But also. Why?
Why 4:3 (1.375:1 for pedants), 1.85:1, and 2.35:1? Each time period in the film lines up with the mainstream adoption of that aspect ratio, and so the changing aspect ratios can be considered another part of the set design, which changes dramatically from timeline to timeline. As the browning halls of the 1968 Hotel are rendered in brilliant pinks and reds when we flash back to 1932, so too does the ceiling of the cinematic frame literally grow taller. The perspective literally grows wider and- perhaps- more nuanced- with the historical perspective. Does the film suggest that we’re so far removed from the 30s that what we can perceive is literally cut off on the sides? It’s for you to decide.
It may seem quite contrived to suggest that the narrowing aspect ratio represents a neglecting of the edges of our historical perception, but evidence for this can be found in the text. Our dual protagonists, Zero and Gustave, are a refugee and a bisexual, respectively. Theirs are stories which have been sidelined throughout history, and positioning them in this historical context- even in what remains a comedic romp for most of its runtime. Asks us as audience to consider what stories and characters like Zero and Gustave have been sidelined.
Wes Anderson’s movies draw attention to their own filmmaking to the point of easy categorisation and parody. But too often I believe people categorise as an easy out from analysis.
The estrangement effect has roots in Chinese theatre and Russian Formalism, but was codified into Western theatre by Bertolt Brecht. Brecht’s aim for the estrangement effect (verfremdungseffekt) was that breaking the illusion, and reminding the audience that they were viewing a piece of fiction would force them to engage with the underlying politics. Wikipedia’s description is quite elegant:
“By disclosing and making obvious the manipulative contrivances and “fictive” qualities of the medium, the actors attempt to alienate the viewer from any passive acceptance and enjoyment of the play as mere “entertainment”. Instead, the goal is to force viewers into a critical, analytical frame of mind that serves to disabuse them of the notion that what they are watching is necessarily an inviolable, self-contained narrative. This effect of making the familiar strange serves a didactic function insofar as it aims to teach the viewer not to take the style and content for granted, since (proponents argue) the theatrical medium itself is highly constructed and contingent upon many cultural and economic conditions.”
“Disclosing and making obvious the manipulative contrivances” may not be Wes Anderson’s obvious aim, but the fact that his films are so readily categorised and broken down may at least hint that the estrangement effect is in place. And what are the politics of The Grand Budapest Hotel? It concerns two fringe identities in the face of encroaching fascism.
It is in this way that Grand Budapest is tidily packaged in that thematic dichotomy can be found in the visual aesthetic, and the two feed back into one and other: The rose-tint of nostalgia against the cultural trauma of fascism.
It can seem counter-intuitive, when one of the major criticisms levied against Anderson’s films is that they hide lack of substance behind beautiful aesthetics. But if we consider that the opposite may be true, can the lush aesthetics of The Grand Budapest Hotel, especially during the aesthetic rug-pull of the tawdry 1968 hotel, be hiding its politics precisely within its visuals? The set designs of Grand Budapest Hotel took inspiration from ski resorts rendered in photochrom, a method of colouring black and white photography by hand. They appear stunning in their subtle pastel palettes. But at the same time, the colours they claim to represent are entirely fabricated- left to the artistic choices of the colourist. The hyperreality throughout The Grand Budapest Hotel reminds us that all is not what it seems, and the centering of characters who would have been sidelined by fascism and other historical oppressions serves to challenge our romanticised notions of pre-war Europe.
Which brings us back to the box. The shape of the box in which the Grand Budapest Hotel plays out literally changes shape throughout the movie. Within, it helps guide us through jumps between time periods, but outside of the box, the changing shape serves to remind us that it is the box that we are watching. That this is a fictionalised, romanticised and nostalgic rendition of a far different reality. I think, if you’ve been willing to follow me this far, the characteristic Wes Anderson visuals and irreverent humour do credit to this film. They make the film appear beautiful and whimsical, but in doing so, challenge the viewer to contemplate what parts of a story remain too painful to tell, what has recollection- and history in turn- brushed outside of the frame?
--
--
Better photography through science and philosophy.

Title: 📸 — Budapest, Hungary
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Hi there! Maeghan & Oli here - we're taking a break to travel the world and hope you'll join us for the ride. 🌏✈️ 👫 www.alittledetour.ca

--
Listen
Share
We’re not going to lie, Maeghan was a little upset to learn that the Grand Budapest Hotel didn’t exist in real life…. but with everything that we heard about Budapest, she felt optimistic with the our next destination.
Budapest was fantastic. We walked around most days exploring the city and eating great food. There were so many different craft beer bars and bottles shops, this is the first time we didn’t have a chance to hit them all! Budapest was also super popular with stag parties and student travellers — I guess it is just that time of year.
We also hit a snag when we had our first encounter with bed bugs in our Airbnb downtown. But our skills as backpackers has reached a new level of awesome and we had identified the problem, found a new place, packed our bags and were out of there in under 15 minutes.
Other than that, we loved it here so much, we decided to extend our stay not once, but twice 😊
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫
On our second day in Budapest. Maeghan was sitting on the couch journaling and Oli was on his computer researching. We decided to switch places so we could recharge our devices and Olivier went on a hunt to find another power outlet. He looked behind the couch and noticed a tiny little bug on the wall in the living room…. it looked kind of like a bed bug…
So he grabbed a spoon, put the little guy in a glass and started a fine eye search to see if there was more. Well… there was.
Olivier found a dozen or so dead bed bug bodies (or a high confidence they were after looking at Google) and put them on a paper towel. Maeghan called the Airbnb host to ask him about this.. since Olivier kept finding more and more bodies and the skins of the bugs inbetween all the crevases of the couch.
Our host said they had bed bugs a few weeks ago, but had the exterminator come twice.. and not to worry unless we found a living one… and we did..
So within 15 minutes… we had their bags packed, space cleaned and they were ready to peace — with success. No bed bugs were carried and they found a new nicer Airbnb all in the nick of time!
The 2nd largest thermal pools in the world next to Iceland. We hope to visit both!
We saw this and thought of all our PasswordBox friends❤️. Ping Pong was an intense sport in the office, we had two and there would always be tournaments.. or two co-workers battling it out. But this seems like a new level of ping pong!
Ruin bar. Made in the ruins of an old building and furnished with only 2nd hand things. Also, has 18 bars in the one location — so you can go to the wine bar, gin bar, craft beer bar… etc. The best place for any group party!
See more on our website www.alittledetour.ca🌏✈️👫

Title: The Grand Budapest Hotel is Probably Not Praxis.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The (Counter)Cultural One-Stop for Nonfiction on Medium… incorporating categories for: ‘Art’, ‘Culture’, ‘Equality’, ‘Photography’, ‘Film’, ‘Mental Health’, ‘Music’ and ‘Literature’.

--
Listen
Share
This article is a postscript to a previous article I wrote about how Wes Anderson’s The Grand Budapest Hotel uses a timeline of cinematic technology and formatting to differentiate nesting framing devices. Hinted at but slightly outside of the scope of that article was Anderson’s use of theatrical techniques. Specifically- in echoing Brecht’s Epic Theatre. The Grand Budapest Hotel deals directly with fascism, so it seems worthwhile to compare the Marxist and antifascist underpinnings of Brecht’s technique, with the ways Wes Anderson succeeds (and fails) to employ them.
One of the primary goals for the establishment of the Frankfurt School was to interrogate why the German Revolution of 1918 ended the way it did. How did the birthplace of Karl Marx find itself at the end of a political upheaval turning to the allures of capitalism, and ultimately, fascism?
Bertolt Brecht’s Epic Theatre is one of a number of artistic forms which attempted to side-step the motivations of capitalism and to speak directly to his audience. I am no Brecht scholar, and a lot of nuance will be glossed over in this article, however put as simply as possible Epic Theatre employed a range of techniques aimed to snap their audience back into reality. And where were they really? They were in a theatre, watching a play.
Brecht thought that by refusing to let his audience suspend their disbelief, he could force them to engage with the ideas and values of his play, rather than getting lost in investment in the character’s emotional journeys. Brecht was a Marxist, and the ideas and values his plays contained were often specifically anti-capitalist ones. Some thinkers of the Frankfurt School further theorised on these techniques, which we’ll talk about later in this article.
“I find Bertolt Brecht’s epic form, only out of focus, muddied by the bourgeois values of the neoliberal era.” says G.D. Brown of Wes Anderson’s most recent film The French Dispatch in a fairly incendiary Popmatters Article.
No matter Wes’ personal politics, his work is forged in neoliberalism. No matter how artistically successful any viewer may find his works, it is the box office that decides whether Wes Anderson keeps making movies. Furthermore, if he does aspire to the same revolutionary art which forged the Brechtian aesthetic, it is not apparent from his subject matter, nor his frequent brand collaborations.
“It is hardly a wonder that Anderson has directed commercials for SoftBank and American Express, for the likes of Stella Artois, Prada, H&M, AT&T, Hyundai, and Sony. His highly-stylized advertisements have connected common products and the arms of finance to sophisticated notions of film as elevated art, to visual reassurances of certain standards of taste and cultured cool. Of course, Anderson is not the first director of artistic merit to commercialize his talents. Supper won’t pay for itself.” G.D. Brown, Life After Brecht: Wes Anderson’s Lowbrow Dialectics
For Brown, the neoliberalism of Anderson’s aesthetic is rotten to its core: Its themes of minority identity under fascism function as appeals to the comfort of modernity rather than provocative calls to action. Indeed, the communists in Grand Budapest are just as hostile and threatening to the film's protagonists as the fascists (whether the communists depicted in Grand Budapest represent anything like actual communism is outside of the scope of this article.)
“In Brecht’s plays, his cues leading audiences away from the naturalist immersion of storytelling and toward the theater as an unreal portrayal (his breaking the fourth wall, his narrators and movements into song, and so on) were meant to prod the viewer into meaningful engagement with their own historical circumstances…
Anderson has faced criticism for his portrayal of largely white, upper-class characters in contrast with the roles of workers and people of color. As the viewer becomes aware of Anderson’s on-screen values, they must, like Brecht, take on the dialectical mindset to best understand the infusion of revolutionary form and bourgeois content, placing Anderson in the context of the neoliberal turn of the last half of the 20th Century.”
— G.D. Brown, Life After Brecht: Wes Anderson’s Lowbrow Dialectics
The accusation- for those who find this style exhausting (and I’m aware my writing often falls into this style)- is that Wes Anderson uses the stylings of revolutionary art, which is real and important. However, he uses them as a hollow appropriation. Anderson (though not necessarily through conscious intention) is packaging up the Brecht’s technique the same way he packages up other high-brow aesthetics (fine art, high fashion), resulting in an easily digestible remedy for intellectual and class anxiety.
An excellent quote from Luc Boltanski and Eve Chiapello’s The New Spirit of Capitalism, (which I pilfered from an also great Broey Deschanel video) spells out the process by which contemporary capitalism consumes and repackages revolutionary ideas, saying:
“To maintain its powers of attraction, capitalism therefore has to draw upon resources external to it, beliefs which, at a given moment in time, possess considerable powers of persuasion, striking ideologies, even when they are considered hostile to it.”
— Luc Boltanski and Eve Chiapello, The New Spirit of Capitalism
Conversely, it could be argued that this form of neoliberal media is the necessary conduit to deliver revolutionary ideas to a mainstream audience. In The Andersonian Theatricality by Irene Kalesi, Anderson’s use of humour is explored as a cloak through which to smuggle critique and revolutionary ideas. Having made the link to Brechtian technique, Kalesi writes:
Comedy when used accurately can be the harshest judge of situations and the greatest fighter for change. Jones points out that “comedy is a vehicle for subtly (or not so subtly) addressing these injustices by mocking the social norms in the hope of slowly changing the masses’ beliefs about the inequalities”. Therefore, the employment of comedy can be pointed towards parodying and thus criticizing war and the collapse of the social ideals. The comedic atmosphere helps the audience engage with the film’s sensitive topic, namely a story that takes place during a tumultuous historical period. This bittersweet story needs the comedic perspective in order to avoid being an overly emotional burden on the viewer. The power of theatre is that it helps the audience not to identify with a character per se but it makes them contemplate deeply about the events happening on stage. According to Aristophanes, serious matters should be touched by the genre of comedy. As Dicaepolis from “Acharnians” says: “Comedy too can sometimes discern what is right. I shall not please but I shall say what is true”. Therefore, the power of comedy is to reveal truths and centralize issues that concern the spectators.
— Irene Kalesi, The Andersonian Theatricality
In Marxist theory, praxis is the putting of theory into action: it can be used to emphasise the importance of engagement and activity toward a common goal, without dismissing the importance of theory.
So does Wes Anderson’s work, specifically The Grand Budapest Hotel, hold up to the criticisms of the Frankfurt School aestheticians who created the groundwork for understanding Brecht’s epic theatre? I’m not uniquely qualified to tell you. But we can try to chase the logic down together: Writing specifically about Brecht, Walter Benjamin wrote:
“The task of epic theatre, Brecht believes, is not so much to develop actions as to represent conditions. But ‘represent’ does not here signify ‘reproduce’ in the sense used by the theoreticians of Naturalism. Rather, the first point at issue is to uncover those conditions. (One could just as well say: to make them strange.) This uncovering (making strange, alienating) of conditions is brought about by processes being interrupted.”
— Walter Benjamin, Understanding Brecht
And furthermore:
“Epic theatre casts doubt upon the notion that theatre is entertainment. It shakes the social validity of theatre-as-entertainment by robbing it of its function within the capitalist system. It also threatens the privileges of the critics. These privileges are based on the technical expertise which enables the critic to make certain observations about productions and performances. The criteria he applies in making his observations are only very rarely within his own control; he seldom worries about this, but relies upon ‘theatre aesthetics’ in the details of which nobody is particularly interested. If, however, the aesthetic of the theatre ceases to remain in the background, if its forum is the audience and its criterion is no longer the effect registered by the nervous system of single individuals but the degree to which the mass of spectators becomes a coherent whole, then the critic as he is constituted today is no longer ahead of that mass but actually finds himself far behind it.”
— Walter Benjamin, Understanding Brecht
This leaves us at somewhat of a junction in considering Anderson. Is the Andersonian Aesthetic a reproduction of these ‘theatre aesthetics’, or does the use of theatrical technique and aesthetic in a cinematic context alienate the viewer from more conservative cinematic techniques? I think your opinions about neoliberalism may define where you sit.
If all revolutionary aesthetics are consumed and repackaged under capitalism, is praxis in media possible? Herbert Marcuse, another thinker of the Frankfurt School, was slightly more optimistic.
“It seems that art as art expresses a truth, an experience, a necessity which, although not in the domain of radical praxis, are nevertheless essential components of revolution”
— Herbert Marcuse, The Aesthetic Dimension
Marcuse took it one step further than Benjamin in that he believed it was the authentic artistic experience that anyone could encounter the thirst for revolution and come to sympathise with the failings of capitalism. Whether Wes Anderson’s art hits even this bar for authenticity is again up to personal judgment.
That capitalism will, in time, homogenise all cinematic aesthetics into a sort of grey sludge seems inevitable. You can see it happen in real time. But hangers-on like Wes Anderson, who thrive in a space that is alternative if only by degrees- these artists may well be the first glimpse of real art many filmgoers experience. Can intellectually honest ideas be mined from these works? This writer believes that even if they can’t, you ought to look.
--
--
The (Counter)Cultural One-Stop for Nonfiction on Medium… incorporating categories for: ‘Art’, ‘Culture’, ‘Equality’, ‘Photography’, ‘Film’, ‘Mental Health’, ‘Music’ and ‘Literature’.
Better photography through science and philosophy.

Title: Postcards From Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The joy of blogging while exploring your home country. A slice of your life, Food, culture, nature and more.

Member-only story
--
10
Share
Dear Margaret,
I traveled home to Hungary several times since I moved to France, the last time we met. I always just ran through the city to catch my connection to my home town and never stopped by to embrace the beauty of it again. Since you moved abroad too, there was nothing to keep me here for longer.
This time, it was different. My boyfriend came with me and I started to look at the streets we used to walk distinctly — like I’ve never seen them before, like an actual tourist.
At first glance, it seemed like everything remained the same — your favorite art nouveau buildings, the century old parks, historical squares… If only those walls could talk!
Yet, everything seemed changed. It’s been only 4 years since we said our goodbye here but it feels like decades have passed.
I took my boyfriend to the Danube river, or as we call it in Hungarian: Duna, for a stroll taking advantage of the last warm days of summer. I never noticed before how green our capital is, did you Margaret? I don’t recall if we ever talked about it.
--
--

Content:

When I was younger, single with not many cares in this world, I traveled quite a bit. I still do but it’s different now.
I was fortunate to work for a company based near Bristol, England. Once or twice a year I would travel to our corporate offices for meetings and/or training. Lucky me!
I would almost always take advantage of being overseas and book my vacations from there. Inexpensive flights to European cities made it a no-brainer.
One of the trips I took was to Budapest. I was quite spoiled as I acquired hotel points that allowed me to stay in hotels I would not have otherwise been able to afford.
Like the Marriott right on the Vltava River overlooking the Chain Bridge and Castle Hill. This was the view from my room.
I spent five or so days wandering around. For three of those days, a co-worker friend flew over and met me. It was nice to have someone to hang out with for a few days.

Title: Melody of Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
The more we observe a city, the more apparent it becomes that it surpasses the sum of its parts. It resembles a colossal, intricate organism with its network of organs and unique internal dynamics. These dynamics are a tapestry woven from our daily interactions within the city: the bustling morning and evening rush on the tram or subway lines and leisurely strolls along the riverbank — it all contributes to this vibrant tapestry.
Though it sounds idyllic, it stands worlds apart from the vast data streams of corporations, the omnipresent data visualization tools, the ongoing buzz about artificial intelligence across various platforms, or even the fundamental essence of artistic expression — music.
“Melody of Budapest,” sponsored by Telekom Hungary, aims to bridge these divides by transforming the city’s dynamic mobility patterns into a musical piece using data science and AI. Initially, Janosov and the data team of Telekom Hungary processed large-scale cell tower-based mobility data at a resolution of 100m into digestible information. This unpublished data covers the temporal and spatial specifics of every mobile phone event on Telekom’s network in Budapest, Hungary, from June 2022 to 2023, linked to their…

Title: Contemporary Art on the Lower Danube (Budapest, Salzburg, & Vienna)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Recently, I was on a river cruise through the Lower Danube on AmaWaterways with Christian (TellMeWhyTravel). The stops along the way included Budapest, Hungary, Bratislava, Slovakia, Durnstein, Salzburg, and Vienna, Austria. All of the cities are known for its historical importance from war, due to their strategic location on the river, to arts and culture, where some of the greatest minds which ever existed created. However, by the time you’ve gotten to this page, you already know about Mozart, the Hungarian Parliament, Buda Castle, and the other tourist attractions your tour guide will show you. As our tour guide YOLO (Yes! That’s his name!) said, “Do you see ABC? ABC, another bloody church, additional broken castle.” While I can respect the art and architecture, and the blood, sweat, and tears that went into the churches, castles, and monuments of the era, once I’ve seen one (or two) I’ve kind of seen them all. (There are definitely some cool churches and castles but that’s for a different story!)
I’m going to take you off the beaten path and show you some of the art and culture of today in these cities. Today’s obscure artists will be the Mozart’s, Picasso’s, and Spielberg’s of tomorrow. The Internet has brought most of the things to our homes but art is something we must experience in person!
If you’re staying at the Aria next to the Church of St. Stephen, you’re in a good place to start.
Most of the museums are within walking distance between 1–3 miles and you’ll get to see the other landmarks of Budapest along the way!
So let’s get started!
Want to check out some contemporary art museums further up?
Both of these museums looked pretty cool, unfortunately the Q was temporarily closed for installation.
If you’re already tired or didn’t see anything interesting you can check out the Széchenyi Thermal Bath, which features 18 pools and saunas but also has an exciting retro architecture, which reminded me of high school.
But maybe you’re not done yet. Walk down past the ruin bars to the Palace District.
Have a drink or two here, usually you’ll find some live music, poetry reading, or lively conversation!
From here there are a few advanced options:
About 25 minutes away is the Ludwig Museum, related to the Mumok in Vienna. It’s worth seeing some of the collection which includes Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol, and Joseph Beuys.
Cross the bridge and at the base of Gellért-hegy Jubileumi park is Faur Zsófi Gallery. We hiked to the top of it, but the park is still undergoing renovations but a stunning view nonetheless.
Also closeby is the music venue A38, where we were lucky enough to see the band Henge.
Not tired yet? Cross the chain bridge and get to the Buda side of the city.
In the oldest part of the city, Obuda, stands a shrine to one of the city’s most famous contemporary artists, Victor Vasarely, the father of the optical art movement.
Then cross back over to Pest and hit Kalman Maklary Fine Arts an interesting contemporary gallery (no exhibitions this year yet) which is close to parliament and a short stroll from the Aria.
If you happen to come in mid October, check out Art Market Budapest which is also near the first round of galleries near the opera house and the Aria.
Now if you didn’t finish all of that in your two day pre-cruise, don’t worry, you’ll have a chance to come back at the end of the cruise!
Sailing
The Slovak National Gallery is close to where the ship docks.
Three options for the outskirts of the city; I don’t think you can walk here, you might need to take a taxi, bike, or public transportation.
Rudavskys Magic Garden: The garden is closed for the winter, but looks incredible when it’s warmer!
The Július Koller Society
Tranzit
Danubiana Meulensteen Art Museum: This looks like a very cool museum atop a peninsula jutting into the Danube. I didn’t see it from the ship, but along with its sculpture park, it seems like an awesome place to check out the latest contemporary art!
Sailing
The next stop is in the Wachau Valley, specifically Durnstein. While Durnstein is a quiet town with not much contemporary art, 8km from Durnstein is a small cosmopolitan town, Krems an der Donau, with some interesting art options.
The map is zoomed out to show the proximity to Durnstein where the ship is docked.
Sailing
The following day we docked and took about a 90 minute bus ride to the quaint city of Salzburg, known for being the birthplace of Mozart. It’s also known for being the backdrop to the 1960’s classic The Sound of Music.
The city is surrounded by a steep rock face which made it an impenetrable during times of war. However, the top of mountain is a contemporary art museum. You get natural and manmade art from the top of the elevator ride!
But before we get there, global gallery Thaddaeus Ropac has two locations in Salzburg! Check to see if there are exhibitions at the farther one near the train station before you trek up there.
Finally, Galerie HAAS & GSCHWANDTNER is moving from its downtown location to somewhere else within Salzburg. Check their website to see where they end up!
Sailing
We made it! Vienna, Austria the largest, most cosmopolitan city on the Danube. The art scene here is huge with tons of galleries, museums, and history.
We will try to avoid the two most famous artists from Austria, Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt, because the Neue Gallery on 86th and 5th in New York houses Ronald Lauder’s huge collection of Austrian art including Klimt’s Lady in Gold.
The bus to old city will drop you about 5 minutes northeast of St. Stephen’s Cathedral.
There are a lot of galleries in the first district, here’s the east side of the city first.
The west side is next, the order is assuming that you are coming from the bus drop off location
On the east side of the outer museum loop
There are a few major art fairs that take place in Vienna:
March: Spark Art Fair
May: Affordable Art Fair
September: Vienna Contemporary and Curated By
November: Vienna Art Week
Austrian artists that I didn’t get a chance to see:
Stefan Eins: He stopped by my Times Square exhibition multiple times and had some crazy stories about when he started Fashion Moda in the South Bronx in the 80s.
Andre Heller: Multi-hyphenate who commissioned Luna Luna
Helmut Lang: the famed photographer
Franz West: Sculptor and artist
On the outskirts of the city is the Essl Museum, which houses what is considered the most important collection of Austrian art after 1945.
From here the ship sails back to the beginning port, Budapest.
Did we miss something? Drop a comment and we’ll be sure to check it out next time and let you know how it was.
Interested in recreating this experience? (You’ll now have the maps to save time instead of us stumbling around)
Here’s the link to the AmaWaterways cruise and the Aria hotel, which is voted the best in Central Europe consistently!
NB: There was an issue with Google Maps acting weird so instead of wasting time figuring it out, I made different maps for each art “district” in Budapest and Vienna.
--
--

Title: Day 53- Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
5
Listen
Share
Budapest is one of my favourite cities. Had an absolutely delightful day here. I would even chuck in a few of my other blog buzz words including “beautiful”, “lovely” and “ absolutely amazing”.
What better way to start the day. I had booked a tour which could have up to 8 guests and showed up at Central Market Hall. It was $145 which was a massive stretch but honestly why not. This is an incredible building inspired by the Eiffel Tower. The Hungarian government built four of these across the city in the 1870’s after all the open air markets got infested with cockroaches and snow for most of the year.
To my incredible fortune, the mysterious Mr & Mrs Chapelle from the US were both unwell and unable to attend. Private tour baby! With portions made for 4! I steeled myself for feeling like a spoiled baby.
I now also felt no concern in asking Orsha to photograph me as her happy customer.
Over the four hours and 12 spots I was reminded just why I love food tours. The history of a people is in their food. It explains their culture, customs and sends you directly into every family’s dinner table. Hungarian food also happens to perfectly correlate with my food preferences. We are talking:
I will now give you the rundown in several loose listicle paragraphs.
Market foods were first up.
This is their street food. A donut covered in garlic juice, sour cream and a mild cheddar. How could this not be delicious.
Next up we had the salami. I tried types called horse, curly haired pig, pork cheese (has all the different bits of the animal as different cubes) and Hungarian winter. Horse weirdly tasted how I thought it would. A wild earthy flavour that made me think of riding horses.
Some of the interesting things we saw in the market include a tonne of foie gras- Hungary is one the worlds largest producers- a tonne of fat and a delicacy of a whole chicken with an egg still in it.
A benefit of being on this tour alone was that Orsha had to field all my questions. She was likely unprepared for the grilling that arrived. Some facts for you:
The pickle tasting. That is right. The Hungarians are super into pickles. I was led down several alleys to the pickle basement. Cordoned off due to its offensive fragrance. She was concerned I might not like the smell. As an amateur pickler and somebody that has hosted an actual pickle party she couldn’t have worried more pointlessly.
Enter Marika, my hero. Handmaking pickles in the basement for over 50 years.
I got to choose my very own pickle selection and try them out. Easily the best I have ever had. My favourites were the kraut and the mini watermelons.
When I get back I am going to flat out not stop until I have prepared a pickle jar with a smile on it. Look forward to Christmas presents everybody as I think a month of unemployment should just about do it.
Also coincidentally I screenshotted this yesterday. I will just leave it here.
You know what else the Hungarians are into? Deliciousness. Lunch was this sausage and goulash place. Served with oodles of cabbage and horseradish. Divine. Followed by some iced coffee and cake that I ate before taking a picture of. It started with one forkful, then quickly snowballed until both slices were gobbled up.
I learnt a bit more historical stuff from Orsha too. Something I noticed as soon as I got off the train was how decrepit all the old buildings were. I asked Orsha what was up with that.
Basically what happened was that the Hungarians sided with Germany in both world wars. Hence they had massive damage in WW2 from gunfire and allied bombing.
After WW2 Hungary lost heaps of its land and was handed to the Soviets. After that they were largely communist. The soviets converted all the rich aristocratic houses into social housing and didn’t bother to repair them for 50 years. Hence the damage on these houses is genuinely from WW2.
There was also a large wall discovered from the original Budapest boundaries recently that we strolled past.
The strangest part of the whole thing was the final portion of the tour. Wine and cheese tasting with an actual sommelier in a huge cellar. I must say this was certainly not designed for one person, and certainly not a wine noob such as myself. I laughed and sipped and enjoyed desert wine with blue cheese as I nodded along to my very own personal wine lecture. A glorious combination.
My personal sommelier had not much to say to me after I requested to try some non alcoholic wines. I was having too much fun at this time and asked him all about what he thought about them. He said simply that it was a disgrace and “grape juice”. Oh Gregor. Keep pouring em.
I strolled home after this, quite drunk and somehow lost an earring. A perfect day really. Topped up off with such a heavy nap that I fell asleep on my sunglasses and hairbrush.
Loving it here. Really coming into its own this whole “Europe” thing. The further east we are getting the more I am loving it which is promising. The fast pace is also a nice change that is making time go very fast.
Today was just great. I very clearly need to do more food tours as it is just about my favourite experience a human can have. Tired but loved today.
Xxxx
--
--
5

Title: We Missed the Point of The Grand Budapest Hotel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I’m well aware that we don’t all rewatch films at the same time. We are all subject to individual whims that diverge and intersect largely at random. That said, I do think that in the near future many of us will be rewatching Wes Anderson’s The Grand Budapest Hotel.
This prediction is based on several factors: the impending release of Anderson’s new film The Phoenician Scheme, a renewed (or perhaps wholly original) fondness for Ralph Fiennes following his performance in Conclave, and the general critical consensus that The Grand Budapest Hotel represents the culmination of Anderson’s artistic vision. Essentially, if we’re due for a Wes Anderson rewatch, this will be the film a good 75–80% of participants will pick.
It’s my belief that when people do return to it, they’ll find the same thing I found during my recent rewatch. It’s better now than it was the first time. Why? Because time is a flat circle and our moral dilemmas have a habit of resurfacing in new disguises.
Viewers noted from the film’s release that one of its key themes was the rise of fascism. What I think we lacked in 2014 was an understanding of fascism as a recurring threat rather than one that was just as much an article of the past as the Grand Budapest itself. Sure, we could link the film’s commentary on the treatment of immigrants to ongoing crises in the world, but we didn’t see fascist militaries boarding trains and demanding visas. We saw… logistical challenges.
This political inattentiveness at the time of the film’s release contributed to a chronic misinterpretation of the two protagonists. Primarily, critics were prone to forgetting there were, in fact, two protagonists.
Readers may have noticed my use of the pronoun “we” up to this point when making my points. The “we” I am referring to are fellow white beneficiaries of the imperial core. To those reading who do not fit into that category, my apologies, but you’ll see the utility in a moment.
Our greatest failing when initially addressing The Grand Budapest Hotel at the time of its release, was to center our attentions almost entirely on M. Gustave for analysis. He is by all means a fascinating character with many aspects to pick apart and discuss; however, his function in the narrative is to serve as a catalyst and foil for our true central character, Zero.
The Grand Budapest Hotel is presented in layers, a trick Anderson has become quite fond of if his more recent film Asteroid City is any indication. The film opens on a young girl reading a book next to the grave of the book’s author, who awaits us in the next layer to detail a story from his youth, where in the next layer he meets with the aging proprietor of a hotel far past its prime situated in the fictional alpine nation of Zubrowka, and in the final layer where most of the film takes place, the proprietor recounts his time as a lobby boy at the hotel. By all accounts, the narrator and arbiter of style for most of the film is Zero (or at least the image of Zero his older self conveys to the author).
Like many of Anderson’s films, this one concerns itself with nostalgia for bygone eras. This nostalgia textures the memory of previous times to such a degree that they become more of a fantastical setting than a true reflection of the past, putting a pair of rose-tinted glasses on for the audience. Against the backdrop of a pastel 1930s Europe, we’re confronted with a group of characters who deliberately clash with it. While the staff of The Grand Budapest and the other members of the Society of Crossed Keys all stand out with vivid color, they are contrasted by the setting’s rising fascist movement dressed entirely in monochrome.
A common criticism I’ve found of Anderson’s work is that he prioritizes style over substance, that his chief concern is the aesthetic coherence of an auteur rather than the merit of his narratives. While in some cases this may be fair, what my rewatch of The Grand Budapest Hotel illustrated for me is that to measure style against substance is to create a false dichotomy. That is because, in this film style elucidates substance, substance that in 2014 we were perhaps less primed to recognize.
The rosiness of The Grand Budapest’s past and the whimsical absurdity of its inhabitants are the product of Zero’s recollection, because at this point in his life the hotel may as well be a fairyland compared to what came before. We learn later in the film, following a frustrated outburst from Gustave that gives way to a host of xenophobic insults, that Zero came to Zubrowka from an unnamed Arab country going through a state of political turmoil. He fled after witnessing the execution of his entire family and the lingering threat from the encroaching fascist army will mean death for him, should they choose to deport him.
While most reviews of the film at its release were positive, the few notable criticisms were leveled against the plot, some saying it felt nonsensical and unconnected to any broader theme. And when you view the film with Gustave as its true protagonist, the criticism makes sense. However, when you consider the film from Zero’s perspective, there’s an obvious logic as to why he would focus on patently silly events and madcap drama. To him, these are the good times. Times when he had his mentor and wife with him, when the fascists were a distant presence that only occasionally menaced him, and he had a home that filled him with a sense of purpose. This is the story he wishes to tell.
In the narrative layer where he speaks with the author, the now dilapidated Grand Budapest is the last vestige of that former life Zero still possesses. He explains that he maintains it not in memory of Gustave, who embodied the hotel’s spirit and ultimately bequeathed it to him, but in memory of his wife Agatha. This was the place they were happy together, however short that time may have been. The utility of memory is such that by sharing it we allow ourselves to be better understood.
We made the mistake of assuming fascism was included in the movie to emphasize that theme of memory, that is was a thing of the past that poked a hole in an otherwise happy period, but we also presumed that the only associations with it that mattered are our own. It is easier for us to relate to Gustave, because like him, our confrontations with fascist oppression are taken on by choice. Even with the added context that some of us, like Gustave, are queer and have that as a potential target on our backs, our existences are not constantly hounded by fascist dogma in the same way those of immigrants and refugees are.
While Zero’s growth over the course of the film is defined by him establishing himself as an integral part of the Grand Budapest’s community, Gustave’s arc centers his developing awareness of his own privilege and the value of his relationships with others. He comes to understand that there are ways to relate to others beyond providing a service.
The scene that I find most striking ten years later is a scene shot entirely in monochrome. It is an echo of an earlier scene and an escalation of the film’s color language. The fascist army boards the train and enters the train car occupied by Gustave, Zero, and Zero’s wife Agatha. They request the travelers’ papers, though this time with a heavier threat hanging over their heads should they produce the wrong kind of papers. Zero pulls out a wrinkled and ripped work visa, which Gustave confirms the legitimacy of and even produces a card from a commander in the fascist army indicating they should be allowed to pass. The fascist army members do not accept this. And Gustave, as the author is told by an older Zero, gave his life trying to ensure Zero’s safe passage. What precisely happened to Zero and Agatha in the two years between Gustave’s death and the death of Agatha and her child is left ambiguous, but one can presume they were not happy times.
It is easy for things to become commonplace which would have been unthinkable just a few years prior. We now live in a version of the US confident in its power to harass, detain, and deport immigrants on a whim. We have people boarding our trains and asking for our documents at this very moment. What The Grand Budapest Hotel wants us to realize is that we have a duty to the person sitting next to us. It can be easy to allow injustices to pass us by due to relative distance, to cling to a veneer of civility and not make a fuss.
Perhaps the most insidious misinterpretation of the film is that Gustave is a good man because of his civility, that his politeness brings him karmic rewards because he does not discriminate in who he is polite to. The aforementioned scene refutes this assertion, bookmarked in black and white so the audience takes care to remember. Gustave was a good man because he knew when to take action, and he gained that knowledge through his friendship with Zero. If his strength is his civility, then true civility must include a refusal to sit by and allow harm to come to the people around you.
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a better film now in 2025 than it was at release, because present political circumstances make it far more difficult for us to miss the point. Zero was always the heart of the story, his attachment to the hotel always in relation to how it provided a home for him rather than a vocation. It is only now that we begin to develop the consciousness to understand these things outside of our own privileged experience. It is no longer possible to ignore.
We feel the weight of the world of memory Anderson presents more keenly now because we have lost the benefit of distance from the time it represents.
--
--
Opinion writer interested in what keeps us entertained.

Title: Poznań, Budapest and the Blood That Binds Them Together
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Teatime History is your one stop destination for a better understanding of human history. Let us debunk myths, examine the legends of the past, and explore the innovations which have transformed our lives.

Member-only story
--
Share
There is a certain pattern I notice in cities all over Europe that is both unique and also interesting. If there is a huge shopping mall either as part of the complex or in the immediate vicinity of the main railway station of an urban area, that particular city has a lot to offer to its visitors. In the case of Poznań, it is no different either.
On the surface, the city on the River Warta is one of Poland’s largest urban conurbations, a hub of education, and an important business center. However, once you scratch the surface, the city becomes significantly more than another bustling metropolis. Poznań is home to a plethora of historic and cultural references.
Amid the many modern buildings and high-rise apartments, the city also showcases an eclectic mix of Baroque, Gothic and neoclassical architecture. There are many Budynek zabytkowy (listed buildings) and Pomnik historii (historic monuments) scattered around in the city, the ownership of which comes with certain obligations and restrictions.
On second thoughts, I believe a major shopping mall attached to the main station complex in…

Title: Script Analysis: “The Grand Budapest Hotel” — Part 2: Major Plot Points
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
Official Screenwriting Blog of The Black List
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
Reading scripts. Absolutely critical to learn the craft of screenwriting. The focus of this weekly series is a deep structural and thematic analysis of each script we read. Our daily schedule:
Monday: Scene-By-Scene BreakdownTuesday: Major Plot PointsWednesday: SequencesThursday: Psychological JourneyFriday: Takeaways
Today: Major Plot Points.
In every scene, something happens. A plot point is a scene or group of scenes in which something major happens, an event that impacts the narrative causing it to turn in a new direction.
A relevant anecdote. Years ago, I was on the phone with a writer discussing a script project. My son Will, who was about four years old at the time, must have been listening to me talking about “plot points” during the conversation because after I hung up, he asked, “Daddy, what’s a plop point?”
That’s in effect what a plot point is. It’s an event that ‘plops’ into the narrative and changes its course. So when you think Plot Point, think Plop Point!
The value of this exercise:
* To identify the backbone of the story structure.
* To examine each major plot point and see how it is effective as an individual event.
* To analyze the major plot points in aggregate to determine why they work together as the central plot.
This week: The Grand Budapest Hotel. You may download the script — free and legal — here: The Grand Budapest Hotel.
Screenplay by Wes Anderson, story by Wes Anderson & Hugo Guinness, inspired by the writings of Stefan Zweig
IMDb plot summary: The adventures of Gustave H, a legendary concierge at a famous hotel from the fictional Republic of Zubrowka between the first and second World Wars, and Zero Moustafa, the lobby boy who becomes his most trusted friend.
Writing Exercise: Go through the scene-by-scene breakdown of The Grand Budapest Hotel and identify the major plot points. Post your thoughts in comments and we’ll see if we can come up with a consensus.
For Part 1, to read the Scene-By-Scene Breakdown created by Rob Hoskins, go here.
Tomorrow we consider the script’s structure in terms of its sequences.
If you’d like a PDF of The Grand Budapest Hotel, script scene-by-scene breakdown, go here.
Major kudos to Rob Hoskins for doing this week’s breakdown.
Tomorrow: We focus on the sequences in the script.
This series started here and we have 26 volunteers to do scene-by-scene breakdowns of contemporary movie scripts. The scripts we have already analyzed are in italics.
American Hustle: Jon RaymondArgo: Nora BarryBarney’s Version: John MBelle: DaniMBeginners: AliBoyhood: Jacob JensenEnough Said: AliFlight: 14ShariFrankenwenie: Will KingFrozen: Christina SekerisGone Girl: NateKohler1Gravity: Matt DuriezHanna: John ArendsLincoln: pgronkLooper: erikledrewMoonrise Kingdom: Daniel BiglerMud: AlejandroParanorman: OhScottyPrisoners: Melinda Mahaffey IcdenShort Term 12: Carolina GroppaThe Artist: Traci Nell PetersonThe Grand Budapest Hotel: Rob HoskinsThe Social Network: Nick DykalThe Way Way Back: RickyWadjda: iamdanielWhiplash: Steven Broughton
If you’d like to participate and do a scene-by-scene breakdown yourself, please indicate which script in comments or email me. We are using scripts available on our site here. Note some of the 2014 scripts are now available there including Belle, Birdman, Boyhood, Calvary, Get On Up, Gone Girl, How To Train Your Dragon 2, Kill The Messenger, Locke, St. Vincent, The Boxtrolls, The Fault In Our Stars, The Grand Budapest Hotel, The Theory of Everything, and Wild.
For new volunteers and those who have already volunteered, but not sent me a breakdown yet, please do so as soon as possible. Thanks!
Circling back to where we started, reading scripts is hugely important. Analyzing them even more so. If you want to work in Hollywood as a writer, you need to develop your critical analytical skills. This is one way to do that.
So seize this opportunity and join in the conversation!
I hope to see you in comments about this week’s script: The Grand Budapest Hotel.Comment Archive

Title: Create a map of Budapest districts colored by income using folium in Python
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Data contains intelligence that can change the world — we help people discover, manage and use this intelligence.

--
Listen
Share
Ever wondered how to draw a map of less common geographical areas? And color them based on some data? This pair of tutorials shows how to build this from scratch! First, you need to construct the border of your polygons — Part 1 is about this task. After that you need to create a map, and color those polygons according to some value of your interest. That will be shown in Part 2.
Part 1 of this tutorial is available here.
There are many tutorials on the internet for drawing maps in Python, even more sophisticated maps like heatmaps (where heat is basically the density of points in an area) or choropleth maps (where polygons are colored according to some arbitrary value). However, these tutorials are mainly done on states of the United States. View some great ones with plot.ly or an also otherwise superb one with folium. For the US, these packages have some convenience methods, but for the rest of the world, they’re of little use. Alternatively, they are based on some accidentally available json file like this one with Altair. Obviously, these are not general solutions to the problem of creating a map of some areas of your choice. I aim to give a general solution in these articles.
In this second part you will:
The code is also available on GitHub:
github.com
A GeoJson is actually a JSON file with some predetermined structure. The function above generates a GeoJSON file from a list of points by JSON dumping a dictionary formatted like a GeoJSON file. In these dictionaries, there are only 3 keys: lat, lon and name. Lat and lon stand for the coordinates, while name identifies the shape that the point belongs to. The order of these dictionaries in the list is also critical, you can read about this in the first part of this tutorial.
GeoDataFrames are a subclass of classic `pandas` DataFrames with a special column. This special column, geometry contains all the information that makes this DataFrame geo-aware. A GeoDataFrame object can be easily created from a GeoJSON file, you can add additional data to polygons easily, and just as easily convert it back to a GeoJSON file for visualization purposes.
In this snippet to the left centroids are added to each polygon. By this, we can add a nice marker to the centroid’s location depicting information about the polygon - in this case, the district. Just as easily as this, other data can be added using a plain pandas merge. Here, income tax per capita data is added to each polygon!
The creation of the map consists of 4 important steps:
Firstly, map creation is just as easy as it seems. You should provide a starting position, a starting zoom, and a tiles argument which is responsible for the basic design of your map. Be aware, that folium expects coordinates in latitude, longitude order!
Secondly, creating the choropleth is also easy, but it requires a neatly structured GeoJSON file. The parameters of the choropleth method speak for themselves, but you can refer to the documentation if something is not clear. This creates a layer where polygons are colored according to income tax per capita data — the more the greener, the less the yellower.
Thirdly, A FeatureGroup object is created. This object consist of Marker objects signalling each district’s name and the respective income tax per capita value to give the reader exact amounts apart from the color coding from choropleth. Lastly, LayerControl is added to the map in order to make it possible to show or hide layers, such as the choropleth or the FeatureGroup layer.
Finally, the map can be saved and the created .html file opened using your browser. You can find it on my github, in the outputs folder, but here is a snippet of it:
The main takeaway here is that in creating a beautiful choropleth map — just like in any data science project — data preparation takes around 90% of the effort. We got to know OpenStreetMap data structures and the Overpass API, and solved an interesting problem in Part 1. In Part 2, using GeoDataFrames made it easier to add information to our GeoJSON files and maps. It is also clear for me, that if you are creating maps in Python, folium is the way to go. As you can see, creating a map can be a one-liner, and creating choropleth maps or showing markers with html popups are really easy with folium.
--
--
Data contains intelligence that can change the world — we help people discover, manage and use this intelligence.
Machine Learning Team Lead, Chatbot Developer@K&H (KBC Bank Hungary)

I knew so much, when I was living in Budapest thirty years ago. And not only a lot more Hungarian than I know today.
I knew about the national poet and revolutionary Sándor Petöfi and about playwright and author Ferenc Molnár, after whom I name the fictitious Molnár Club in Birds of Passage. I still know a bit about them, and you may know of them, too.
In 1990 I was hearing a lot of talk in our Budapest social circle about the poet and playwright János Pilinszki, who had died about 10 years earlier and was still revered. He would definitely be on my fictional playwright Gábor’s mind.
And back then I knew about Gyula Krúdy, too; I’d even seen the acclaimed 1972 Zoltán Huszárik film Szindbád based on his work. I liked the idea that down-and-out Kalliopé – my favourite character in the novel – would think so longingly of the bone soup that figures in the film.
But I’d forgotten all about Pilinszki and Krúdy by the time I was rereading Birds of Passage this spring. Their names had become as foreign to me as they may be to you. I had to Google them to figure out why I’d included them in the novel, what they add to the characterization of Gábor and Kalliopé, and how I wanted to create a sense of the Budapest cultural milieu of the time.
I had no great hopes for Birds of Passage when I was writing it, and it had become too close to me for me to see it clearly when I finished it. I was thrilled when Karen Haughian of Signature Editions (then Nuage) wanted to publish it in 1993, and surprised when the review copies she sent out included one to the Times Literary Supplement.
And I did get lots of reviews, even as an unknown and unheralded writer.
The Globe and Mail was reviewing first novels in those days, CBC Radio discussed them on air, and publications like Books in Canada (now defunct) published thoughtful pieces unimaginable today — and paid the reviewers small but useful sums for doing so. I was the cover story in Hour magazine, also long-defunct, and I was interviewed by Shelagh Rogers.
Publishing a novel is nerve-wracking, and publicising a first novel is like having ball lightning in your kitchen. The work you have been obsessing over for years is out in the world – and being read by people you know and people you don’t know. They all have opinions of it, and some will tell you what they think, and who knows what they’ll say? Most will say little, if they say anything at all, and there’s no way of knowing if that’s even worse.
And then there’ll be the reviews – and far more people will read those than ever read your book.
An awful lot depends on reviews, which is the main reason for lamenting how few there now are.
I read the reviews of Birds of Passage with trepidation and astonishment.
The Globe’s was among the first:“Leith handles emotional crisis adroitly, without being clichéd. Her prose style is observant, quick and spare.” That was okay, pretty good, really.
Speaking on “The Arts Tonight” on CBC Radio, author Antanas Sileika praised the book in extravagant terms: “If you like Milan Kundera, if you like Vaclav Havel, you’re going to love this novel.”
Books in Canada described my novel as “remarkable” and published a long and thoughtful review article:
“Because Birds of Passage is a very sophisticated book, the title cuts many ways. The various birds that inhabit apartments, tunnels, mines, and nests enrich the story without intruding on it: suggestions of freedom and confinement, of beauty and fragility, rise naturally into the narrative. Moreover, because Gabor is a writer, Leith is able to comment playfully on her own creation. The novel’s ending seemed a touch contrived, but in a book of such varied delights this is a very small quibble. Leith has the gifts of a natural storyteller.”
The Times Literary Supplement took its time (its review appeared in 1994), but was well worth the wait:
“Hungary 1990 — with dissident lives redundant after the defeat of Communism, market prices making beggars of the population and foreign feminism knocking rudely at the door — is the setting for this excellent first novel. Birds of Passage explores the tenuous relationship between a Canadian couple and their Hungarian neighbours. Linda Leith is perceptive and never sentimental about the role Hungary plays in the lives of the Canadians, Alice and Daniel.
“Across the street from them, the playwright, Gabor, a romantic, who has mostly escaped reality by living the cloak-and-dagger existence of an underground political activist, cannot settle down to domestic responsibility; his apartment is full of sparrows trapped by the closed windows.
“Leith is good on the claustrophobic, old-fashioned feel of Central Europe, with its male heroes, its sacred places and works of art which artificially perpetuate a culture shut off from the international mainstream. Hungarian men in particular are so well adapted to the cage that when released they can barely survive. Alice, who has a strong character and appalling clothes sense, is impressive. Leith has that cool, precise way with the passions that makes one think of Alison Lurie.”
I had read only one book by Alison Lurie, whom The New York Times described as a “tart-voiced novelist of manners.” I didn’t see Birds of Passage as a novel of manners, but I was delighted with my allegedly “cool, precise way with the passions.”
TLS reviews were unsigned back then, and I did wish (and I still wish) I knew who had written this. Whoever it had clearly made the acquaintance of one or two Central European men.
I also wish I’d written to these and other reviewers to tell them how much I appreciated their comments on my book. I was a novice, and I didn’t know I could do that.
Getting a great review is one of the joys of becoming a writer – but then I got a letter from an outraged Hungarian émigrée who didn’t like my book at all.
This woman sang the praises of her homeland — and heartily wished that Birds of Passage had done the same. She deplored characters in my novel that she found unsavoury, including dear Kalliopé — and protested I’d sold Hungary short.
I didn’t agree then, and I don’t agree now, for a novel is not a travel brochure, and Alison Lurie is hardly the only novelist who can be tart-voiced. As Mavis Gallant once put it, “No writer calls a truce.”
But I am grateful to this woman for her letter. Hers was the response to Birds of Passage that did most to convince me I’d done my job as a novelist.
--
--
Writer, translator, publisher, founder of Blue Met, lindaleith.medium.com, LLP, www.lindaleithauthor.com
