Title: Budapest, Bread, and Hope
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
26
Share
“Is it Paris or is it communist Russia? Who knows?!” Colin Hanks
These days, thanks to lower wages and a lower cost of living — and studio heads’ need for more money — there’s a lot of Hollywood production in Hungary. On any given night, some celebrity or muckety-muck can be found sipping palinka at the Four Seasons Hotel bar or wandering along the Danube. I’m here because my husband is working on a television show, our apartment’s Apple TV still has Eddie Redmayne’s login info and I know what Colin Hanks said about Budapest because my friend ran into him here, he was nice, they chatted, he described this place perfectly.
The comparison to Paris is obvious: classic pre-war buildings on either side of a glorious river spanned by majestic bridges. Communism lingers in the depressing grey concrete buildings shoved between old elegant ones and the unsmiling faces seen on the street.
But when I heard this quote, my first thought wasn’t architecture or national character, it was bread. Budapest’s bread and pastries are — for real — better than bread and pastries in Paris.
I swear. But just in case my taste buds or memory had gone awry, I went to Paris to test my hypothesis. Any excuse to mow down more flour, sugar and butter than any…

Title: #98: The Grand Budapest Hotel [dir. Wes Anderson, 2014]
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Our two heroes, concierge extraordinaire Monsieur Gustav H (Ralph Finnes) and his lobby boy protégé Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori), sit across the table from each other in a moving railcar headed to the memorial of the tragically deceased Dowager Countess Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis (Tilda Swinton). The mysterious old woman, a close friend (and frequent lover) of M. Gustav, had feared her death was imminent just three months prior, though specifically what she knew remains unclear. In her wake, the vultures are coming, ready to pick apart her financial corpse and no leave aspect of her estate unclaimed. Gustav, however, comes as a dove wishing to pay respect to the woman and ensure that she is as beautiful in death as she was in during her last stay at the Grand Budapest Hotel in Zubrowka. But before they reach their destination the train comes to an abrupt stop in a barley field, invaded by Zig Zag Stormtroopers looking for undesirables which, it seems, includes Zero. It takes Gustav both his tenacity and his previous kindness to the mother of the Zig Zag commander to earn protection for the young refugee. A woman is dead, and Europe seems to be following.
In 1914, Gavrilo Princip’s bullets struck Austria-Hungary’s Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie. They would die together as their car sped away on the streets of Sarajevo, the first domino in a long chain to fall that would lead to The Great War, ending true monarchy in Europe in just four years’ time, and shattering the continent’s economy and stability in the process. The rise of fascism that followed, in hindsight, seems inevitable. By 1945, the Second World War would be fought on many of the same battlefields, an attempt to push back against the totalitarian evils of Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy, and while the Allied resistance would ultimately win it came at a grave cost — before the midpoint of the twentieth century, Eastern European culture as we knew it was destroyed, replaced with a brutalist architecture and new forms of totalitarianism in the form of Soviet expansion.
When Wes Anderson’s 2014 masterpiece The Grand Budapest Hotel begins, we are not with Gustav at the grand chateau atop the mountain, but in a cemetery after the aforementioned Soviet Union itself has fallen. A young girl has come to visit the grave of a renowned Author (only known as such, played by the great Tom Wilkinson). She greatly admires a book of his and starts to read at the gravesite, one that was written in 1985 about a time in 1968 when he himself visited the titular hotel after its character and history were stripped in favor of the aesthetic du jour in Eastern Europe. No longer does the exterior resemble the pink majesty on the film’s poster, nor does the interior suggest an opulence reserved for royalty. Even the film’s aspect ratio has changed, from a small letterbox to a widescreen vantage like many of the historical epics being made at the time, only serving to contrast the drab and dreary nature of the establishment. The closest thing to culture or opulence we can spot is a painting of a boy holding an apple at the concierge desk.
It is at the hotel that the Author, now portrayed by Jude Law, spies an older gentleman (F. Murray Abraham) sitting patiently for no one in the lobby. When the author inquires about him, all he is told is that the man is the owner of the hotel and that he only stays once or twice a year, and even then, refuses to stay anywhere but a small room with a cot. The two meet in the baths (covered with grimy tile rather than elegant marble) and agree to join each other for dinner. It is there, in a large and empty dining hall, that the old man decides to tell the story of his time as a young lobby boy named Zero, his mentorship under the tutelage of the incredible and indelible Gustav H, and how the hotel came to be in his name.
As we see his story we realize how truly great the Grand Budapest Hotel once was, with its raised balconies, elegant carpentry, vaulted staircases, and chandeliers galore. The clientele is comprised of the world’s upper crust, coming from far and wide to experience the best Zubrowka has to offer, and the staff make it their mission to ensure they get it. The film is now in the nearly-square Academy ratio (again, like the films of its time), turning the wide realism into a jewel box we can’t help but admire. But underneath the majesty is an obvious melancholy, that throughout this fictional tale of excitement and adventure, prison breaks and murder, we are also seeing what we lost when Europe set itself on fire.
Let’s forget, for a second, that the sovereign nation of Zubrowka and the Zig Zag forces are entirely fictional and, instead, recognize the real-world counterparts they represent — Eastern Europe and Nazi Germany, respectively. When most of us today think of the latter we, correctly, picture a fascist, totalitarian, and extremely oppressive regime responsible for the decimation and destruction of numerous minority communities throughout the continent, most notably Jews and Romani. When we think of the former, however, we usually picture a more run-down, war-torn part of the world replete with brutalist architecture, grey skies, and impoverished citizens (like the hotel of the ‘60s). It has been the butt of many jokes throughout Western pop culture, my personal favorite being the incredibly exaggerated Bratislava sequence in 2004’s Eurotrip. It is important to remember, though, that this idea we have of a large swath of Europe is only part of the story and a small one at that. The current state of Eastern Europe is a direct aftermath of two global wars, along with further Soviet occupation and smaller conflicts in places like Bosnia and, most recently, Ukraine. One of the great tragedies of our time, and the main one The Grand Budapest is grappling with, is how much of that region’s culture has been lost, bulldozed, and forgotten in the wake of conflagration.
World War I was a knotty, complicated conflict with no clear good or bad guys to pick from (though much of the allied West was keen to point the finger at Germany and their Kaiser, who they already hated anyway). With two bullets fired from a young man’s gun and the month of confusion that immediately followed, all of Europe’s longstanding treaties and agreements, the same ones that had prevented full-scale continental war throughout a perilous and tumultuous nineteenth century, drove every nation in the area into hell. Young men were enlisted on the promise of national pride only to be used as machine gun fodder in the unmoving trenches in Belgium. Others were sent to Arabia in an attempt to push back the already sickly Ottoman Empire not to liberate the locals but to create desert empires of their own. By the time America was dragged in to help the English and French secure victory from the face of otherwise sure stalemate, all of Europe’s true monarchies had fallen and every nation had, on some level, lost. It was supposed to be “the war to end all wars”, but the emotional crater it left was the perfect cauldron to breed hatred and resentment, and the inevitable power struggle commenced.
Smartly, Grand Budapest is primarily set in 1932, nearly smack dab in between the two world wars. The imagery in the costume and production design is most obviously that of the second, but I believe that much of the early story is actually referencing the first. In that war, despite the hellish destruction, there was a pretend air of dignity attached. When Gustav and Zero are first accosted near a barley field the decorum and history between the commander and the concierge allows for safe passage (presumably in both directions). But when they arrive at the estate it is immediately clear that something is amiss, and the staff is ushering our two heroes away for a private discussion.
What is taking place, as we will soon learn, is a quick reading of the dowager countess’s will, which leaves the bulk of her estate to her ungrateful children — all except the painting “Boy with Apple”, which has been bequeathed to a one M. Gustav H. Much like Europe in the wake of WWI, unhappy with whatever lot they were left with, so, too, is Céline’s son and chief heir, Dmitri (Adrian Brody). Not only is he furious that he wouldn’t receive the entire estate in full, but that even a sliver of it should go to a man far below his station (and, adding insult to injury, the man she was having a lurid affair with). The rest of the film is, essentially, the remnants of the old-world empires grasping at every ounce of power they can and refusing to allow anyone from a lower class to have even a sliver. All Gustav wants is the painting, and many will die in Dmitri’s attempt to get it back.
By compressing the larger time period into a short year, Anderson presents a crisscrossing subtext with numerous overlaps. In our world, the period between the two world wars allowed for the larger societal dissatisfaction to curdle into outright hatred and destructive nationalism. In the film, it happens all at once, with Dmitri using the increasingly oppressive Zig Zag corps to place Gustav in prison for a murder that the son himself almost certainly committed (Céline’s) — the ZZ is more than happy to play along to continue aligning itself with wealth and power. The allegory there is pretty simple as this is, effectively, what happened in Germany as soon as it was clear that the Nazi party was gaining insurmountable ground in the political sphere. Better to team up and consolidate rather than fight back.
What followed, tragically, was the Holocaust — a decade-long massacre across Europe that claimed the lives of an estimated 6 million Jews and millions of others based solely on their religion, ethnicity, political stances, or sexual orientation. Much of Eastern European culture, particularly Polish and Czech, was expressly suppressed and overtaken by the Aryan Reich — what was originally there was deemed too intellectual, too ephemeral, too Jewish. When we return to the hotel in the movie’s third act we see that nearly every shred of pink and rose and red, the ornate nature of the palatial estate we marveled at earlier on, is covered in black banners with ZZ logos. The total decimation of the structure has not yet taken place (the version of the hotel we see in widescreen), but the first attempt is apparent. Rather than tear down and rebuild in their own image, ZZ would rather cover up and pretend it was always theirs.
Working backward, it is no surprise that the monastery in the mountains provides little more than a detour, pretending to help Gustav and Zero find the one informant who can clear the concierge’s name (and, we will learn, knows about the contents of a secret will that has been hidden within the sought-after portrait). Instead, they are so ineffectual as to allow Dmitri’s bodyguard and hitman, J. G. Jopling (Willem Dafoe), to murder Madame D’s butler, Serge X (Mathieu Amalric), inside of a confessional. An irony, to be sure, but one also not without its real-world parallels like everything else.
The rise of fascism in Germany and Italy is a seminal tragedy borne in the wake of another, but we shouldn’t ignore the power structures that refused to stand in their way. And while the already rich and powerful certainly have gotten their due blame, a key group that gets largely forgotten in their culpability is the Catholic Church. The Vatican, and Pope Pius XII specifically, was largely silent during the Holocaust despite numerous pleas for help. I’ve heard it argued that there was only so much the Church could have publicly done, but I must disagree. Behind the scenes, Pius himself sheltered a small number of Jews and privately urged a few of his closest officials to do the same. But publicly, he remained neutral and refused to condemn the actions of Nazi Germany. He was more afraid of retaliation than doing what was right, despite the fact that the largely Catholic continent routinely looked to him for guidance. By outwardly staying silent it gave license to the general public to do the same. He allowed the assassins into the monastery.
A common thread throughout Grand Budapest is how it was truly the common man who maintained and tried to protect the precious culture and history that those in charge seemed more than willing to dismiss and destroy. When Gustav decides to secret “Boy with Apple” out of Madame D’s estate before anybody can stop him it is with the help of the staff, including Serge X and the maid Clotilde (Léa Seydoux), that the painting makes its way to the safe in the hotel (though it is Clotilde’s betrayal and Serge’s false testimony that lead Dmitri to Gustav — collaborators came from everywhere). To break Gustav and his new compatriots out of the comically large prison, it takes cooperation and coordination from everyone around him, including a fellow prisoner not in on the escape keeping quiet out of solidarity. The tools used are snuck in via Mendl’s fantastic baked goods, made with love by his assistant and Zero’s soon-to-be wife Agatha (Saoirse Ronan), and even the prison guards are too enamored with the craft and design to risk ruining the beauty to check for contraband. What’s more, the concierges across Europe are banded together in a secret society to ensure that nothing is lost that shouldn’t be.
So, too, did normal people carry the burden of protection of people and culture from the Nazis as their scourge spread across Europe. It wasn’t the bourgeois who hid Jews or assisted the allies in their attacks on German soldiers in France, but the everyday working class and those in bureaucratic positions with the power to do more than their jobs required. There are famous names among them, such as Oskar Schindler who spent a fortune protecting 1,100 Jews, and Raoul Wallenberg who risked his life (and lost it) smuggling over 7,000 more out of Europe, but many of the righteous were unknown and overlooked. These were people who had little to gain and so much to lose, and yet felt the need to act anyway. In addition to the lives that were saved, there are numerous artifacts, religious and secular, that only exist today because of the kindness regular men and women showed, great works of art that only survived due to their help.
Gustav H, in many ways, represents all of them in one. He is shown to be a solitary man content to live, alone, in the confines of a small closet nestled within the grand hotel’s chambers. He reads his men poetry during dinner every night, despite them paying little to no attention while they stuff their faces with delicious food (that he, himself, will not be eating). He values the painting not because of what it can make him financially (although he does recognize the practical nature of doing so before anyone can steal it back), but because of the beauty it contains — the painting will one day find its home behind his desk in the hotel and seemingly stay there until the establishment is demolished. He is also a man who wishes to comport with the elite (much like Schindler did), using his position to attend to the wealthy clientele (particularly the women), but he never truly becomes them even when the secret will names him to be the inheritor of the entire Grand Budapest Hotel, which Madam D is revealed to be the silent owner of prior to her death.
Of course, his most selfless act is his protection of Zero from certain death. Zero is a refugee from a different war-torn nation, a young man without a home or family to return to. It is clear from their encounter with the ZZ in the barley field that he is considered an undesirable, but Gustav refuses to allow anything to happen to the boy. He can say all he wants that it’s because he doesn’t want to replace such a perfect lobby boy, but we know he cares for those who need protection by his actions. Despite not having much to pass on himself, he makes Zero his sole heir — a gesture that Zero takes to heart and never forgets. The two become inseparable, and Gustav’s desire to shelter him will unfortunately lead to his demise. Near the end, the two are once again accosted on a train passing through the same barley field. The faux principles espoused during the First World War have since given way to true hatred and violence. There is no protecting Zero anymore, and Gustav is shot unceremoniously.
“We have lost some enthusiasm, it is true. We don’t go now in rose-colored spectacles to exhibitions, but we haven’t forgot when we did so.”
In June of 1830, a now-unknown author published the above in the essay “A Gossip About Art and Artists”, the earliest known example of any variation of the term “Rose Colored Glasses”. It harkens back to a time when many would where spectacles not to aid their vision, but to instead recolor the world around them in hues of pink and rose, to better hide blemishes and mistakes. A combination of two older turns of phrase, the 1700s use of the term “rosy” to denote cheerfulness and optimism, and the older still use of spectacles to represent one’s ability to discern the world around them. By bringing the two together, the author recognized that we once used rose-colored glasses to pretend we could see the world better with a different perspective, turning nightmares into beauty. The actual practice may be gone, but the irony in their writing indicates that the practice has become metaphorical.
For a director as keenly aware of his production design, the colors used in any Wes Anderson film cannot be viewed as accidental. Across his filmography, there is a pattern — darker and richer colors are readily prevalent, particularly browns, greens, and blues. There are always flashes of yellow and the occasional deep red, but rarely anything that one could deem “rosy”. The contrast he creates with harsh colors used to populate the measured and meticulous diorama of set design allows for an obvious subtext that beneath the layers of control and order there is a darkness and uncertainty that plagues all of us. The Grand Budapest begins with these same color palettes, the only notable red being the carpet strewn over the hotel lobby in 1968. But when we move backward to Gustav’s era, nearly every aspect of the hotel is pink, rosy, and lovely. Even the uniforms of the hotel staff are royal purple. The only spot that is not resplendent with the blushing hues is Gustav’s room, which is instead drab and light brown.
Anderson is telling a story, through the eyes of an old man, of a time long past and one that he views with great affection. The story, far more than any Wes has told before or since, is incredibly dark and violent. We are seeing a world attempting to hold on to its history and culture while the forces gaining ground are doing everything they can to strip it away, and because of the framing device (and our knowledge of actual history), we know that one day, it will. It’s no surprise that from Zero’s perspective, the time of his greatest adventure, fraught though it may be, is colored as rosy as the most beautiful flower he’s ever seen. Zero loves the hotel, he loves Gustav, and he loves what Zubrowka once was to a young, scared, orphaned boy searching for a new life and new home.
Zero also loves Agatha, though it is clear early on that she will be tragically lost before the Author makes his visit. When her image is first shown, Zero refuses to even discuss her further — it is too painful. When he, finally, begins to elaborate on their courtship it is with a grand smile and flowing tears that he does so. In his telling, the lights of Zubrowka revolve around her wonderful visage, a halo around a woman taken far too soon. We, the listeners, are like the Author wondering what tragedy would befall her — we even briefly believe that Jopling took her life, leading to an upsetting sense of relief when it is revealed his victim was instead Serge’s sister (why should we care any less about her?). In the end, her death is even more unceremonious than Gustav’s will be just one scene later. After the adventure is over Gustav presides over Zero and Agatha’s wedding, though instead of joy we get the matter-of-fact tale of how she died within two years.
“The Prussian grippe. An absurd little disease,” Zero tells us. “Today, we treat it in a single week; but in those days, many millions died.”
Recognizing the danger of looking at the past through rose-colored glasses is just as important as remembering the beauty that we lost. If Anderson was somehow making the argument that the world was a better place before the war, he undercuts it so brilliantly in moments just like this. We may be living in a time when so much of what made the world worth living in is gone, but it is also true that we don’t have to worry about disease in the same way — the things that killed millions without fail are now as survivable as a cold to most of us with the proper treatment and care (something we’ve seen since in compressed real-time with the COVID pandemic). Wars are still taking place across the globe, but many of us are privileged enough to live in places where that is not currently the case.
The question remains why Zero has chosen to maintain the hotel even in its dilapidated state, and why he chooses to return to a place that brings him so much pain regularly. The Author surmises that it must be his way of remembering the world his mentor, Gustav, cherished, one of class and culture. Zero, instead, dismisses this.
“You see, we shared a vocation, it wouldn’t have been necessary. No, the hotel I keep for Agatha. We were happy here, for a little while.” As for the world Gustav cherished, he continues, “To be frank, I think his world vanished long before he ever entered it. But I will say, he certainly sustained the illusion with marvelous grace.”
The Grand Budapest Hotel is a movie in a fictional place but in a real time, one when Europe wanted to pretend that, despite the devastation of The Great War, the era of prestige and bourgeois charm of the late 1800s was still intact and not, in fact, a dead man walking. People like Gustav H. lovingly acted as caretakers both in an attempt to restore this perceived greatness but also to remember it, in case it ever truly was lost. Gustav’s legacy is not the hotel he oversaw nor the wealthy women he consorted with, but the memories and ideas that he passed onto Zero. The same is true of us — we are the caretakers of the best of our time and our world. It is our responsibility to pass what we cherish onto future generations. But, it is vital that we do not forget the challenges and the problems that we collectively endured as well. Recalling our era with rose-colored glasses will only make it harder for the future to maintain what it has, what it cherishes. Only once we can enjoy the great things we have and learn from the mistakes surrounding them can we truly be the concierges to the next generation.
--
--

Title: Budapest and the Fine Art of Missing Everything
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

For those who love to travel, live for travel, and always have a story to tell.

Member-only story
--
3
Share
“Where are you guys from?”
The young man’s face was pockmarked with acne. His sandy blonde hair was swept back and held in place with a generous amount of some pungent product. On his chest, a bullet dangled from a long silver chain.
“Canada.”
“Oh, Canada? You know who I love who is from Canada? Musician. I give you a clue. He’s been famous since he was a little guy.”
“Um… Justin Bieber?”
The man scowled.
“No, man! Not Justin Bieber! Drake, man! Not Justin Bieber!”
Budapest is a long way from Canada, almost a quarter of the way around the world from our Vancouver home. But somehow, wherever we went in the Hungarian capital, Canada kept coming up.
It was a long ride. The highway roughly followed the path of the Danube, and we were grateful for the air conditioning. When we finally stepped out into the city’s central bus station, the heat hit us like a wall.
Budapest has been around forever, even if the city was only officially formed in the 19th century. Like all of this…
--
--
3
For those who love to travel, live for travel, and always have a story to tell.
Novelist. Essayist. Former entomologist. Now a full-time writer exploring travel, art, philosophy, psychology, and science. www.ryanfrawley.com

Title: Moving Home to Budapest
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I arrived in Budapest and was greeted by hugs and tears — some were my own and others were from my wife as she waited expectantly at the airport for me. Rachel and I have spent the first four months of our married life in the season of advent, marked by daily FaceTime video chats. For us, advent ended on December 22nd in Budapest Airport. We moved into the season of Marriage Together, finally.
In my couple weeks in Budapest, much of our time has been spent walking up and down Fillér Utca, the street that takes us up and down the enormous hill that we live on. In between treks up this hill we’ve celebrated Christmas, grocery shopped, watched movies, made lefse, gotten our hair cut, marched for peace, and learned to re-light the water heater in our apartment.
We have attended services at Budavári Evangélikus Templom, a Lutheran Church that is about a 25 minute walk from our apartment. This church is located inside the castle district of Buda. The church is a little bit off of the beaten path, but Rachel tells me that’s not uncommon for Lutheran churches in this area of the world.
Services last about 1.5 hours each, with sermons going about 30–45 minutes. The services have been in Hungarian, so it is quite hard to follow; however, one of the first songs we sang at the Christmas Eve service was “A Mighty Fortress is Our God” or “Erős Vár a mi Istenünk.” This phrase is an important one to Lutherans in Hungary, and it is traditionally said when shaking hands with the pastor after the service. Also, we found it quite amusing in the Christmas Eve service when the pastor giving the sermon swiped his iPad and a Star Wars image spoof appeared projected above him.
At another service, Bishop Dr. Tamás Fabiny, of the Northern Diocese of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Hungary, helped preside and give the sermon. Bishop Fabiny has been a strong Lutheran voice in Hungary about the church’s responsibility to help refugees. Rachel and Bishop Fabiny have already begun to work together on ways to further integrate the YAGM program with the Lutheran Church in Hungary.
In my mind, one of the most adventuresome things to do when experiencing a new country and culture is to get your haircut. To me, there’s a real vulnerability in trusting another person to shape part of your physical appearance — especially when you’re not able to communicate to them fully what it is you want done. Rachel and I both took the plunge one evening, and it turned out to be a fun experience. Plus, I think that our stylist did a nice job!
On New Years Day we were invited to an ecumenical peace march by Bishop Fabiny. Together with faith leaders from the Roman Catholic Church, Coptic Church, Scottish Presbyterian, and Lutheran Church we marched about 10 blocks to a Catholic Church near the city center. At the church, there was a brief service for peace, where prayers were recited and candles were lit for each country that is experiencing war within its geographical boundaries.
It’s wonderful to finally be with Rachel in Budapest, and begin to live into our lives together. We are so thankful to all the people that have supported us in the months and years leading up to now. We look forward to crossing paths again with those that have helped us get to this point, and we look forward to the trails that lead to new friendships and experiences in the future.
--
--

Title: Groundhopping in Budapest: MTK Budapest — Hidegkuti Nandor Stadion
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In a change of pace, this Groundhop adventure took me back to the Hidegkuti Nandor Stadion for the first time since September 2019 when I took in an NBII match between MTK Budapest and Nyiregyhaza Spartacus; a game most memorable for then Nyiregyhaza goalkeeper Jova Levente scoring from the penalty spot.
My return to the Hidegkuti Nandor Stadion after a two-year hiatus was not, however, to see MTK Budapest but instead to watch the Hungary v Scotland Women’s World Cup Qualifier.
Hidegkuti Nandor is a legend of the Hungarian game and famed member of the Arany Csapat who played for MTK Budapest, in their numerous guises, between 1946 and 1958. Hidegkuti is best known for his starring role in Hungary’s famous 6–3 victory over England at Wembley Stadium, where he scored a hat-trick; the game is immortalised in mural on Rumback Sebestyn U. in Budapest’s Jewish Quarter.
Hidegkuti was a talent ahead of his time helping to pioneer the deep lying forward role — a role that the likes of Denis Bergkamp would later find much success in — with his innovative and creative play helping him to over 260 career goals along with countless assists for his team-mates at both club and national level.
Upon his death in 2012 MTK Hungaria, as MTK were then known, renamed their stadium in honour of the club hero and when the original stadium was torn down and rebuilt in 2016 the new stadium maintained the name of Hidegkuti Nandor.
The stadium has a capacity of just over 5,300, however, it has one weird peculiarity about it — behind both goals are large concrete walls giving the stadium the air of a prison yard at times.
If truth be told, I had no idea that this game was even taking place until around midday on the day of the game when a message from a friend in New Zealand alerted me to the fixture. Despite the short notice, the evening’s plans were quickly changed to take in the rare occasion of a Scotland match.
For this one I would be joined by my wife — whose native Hungarian language skills would come in extremely handy — and our young daughter; I was on my best behaviour.
By error, which later turned out to be quite fortuitous, we arrived at the stadium about an hour and a half before kick-off; I hadn’t put two and two together that the kick-off time on the BBC Alba advert I’d been sent was the UK time and not the Budapest kick-off time. Sometimes I wonder about myself.
Arriving at the stadium to buy our tickets we noticed that the Penztar offices were shut. Step up my wife who found out from the security guards that we had to register and buy tickets on the MLSZ website. For those unaware, selecting your seats and purchasing tickets on the MLSZ website via mobile is possibly the most frustrating experience known to man.
After approximately 45 minutes of seats being added to the basket, dropping out the basket, and being re-added to the basket, we were finally able to purchase and download our matchday tickets for the reasonable price of 1,000 HUF each — circa £3.
Perhaps the takeaway lessons here are to make sure of the kick-off time and way to purchase tickets in advance of rocking up at the stadium.
Once in inside and pre-match refreshments purchased we made our way to our seats, my daughter enthralled by the floodlights and sight of girls out on the pitch where ‘men normally play’, and talking incessantly about everything she saw. It was great.
Anthem Time — The Hidegkuti Nandor fell silent for the National anthems. As Flower of Scotland echoed out over the tannoy system a lone Scottish voice, in amongst the couple of thousand Hungarians in attendance, began to belt out the Anthem with as much pride and gusto as he could manage; his daughter telling him with mild panic “Daddy, everyone’s looking at us”.
Yes, dear reader, that lone Scottish voice was mine.
From the off Scotland were dominant and maintained the upper hand for the majority of the game, the first in charge for new manager Pedro Martinez Losa.
After a bright opening, the breakthrough came in the 17th minute through Erin Cuthbert who scored from the rebound of her own missed penalty.
As the first half wore on complacency and slack passing crept into the Scottish game and Hungary began to grow in confidence but without really threatening Lee Alexander in the Scotland goal.
The second half picked up where the first ended with Scotland still the better side but prone to being their own worst enemy with some poor decision making at vital times giving Hungary hope of a way back into the game.
That all changed with the introductions of Lana Clelland and Martha Thomas just after the hour. The subs made an immediate impact with Clelland going close on a couple of occasions and causing the home defence problems before Thomas headed in a second for Scotland with a quarter of an hour to go.
Thomas’ goal effectively killed the game as a contest and, try as they did, Hungary failed to carve open the Scotland backline and find a route back into the game. In fact, it was Scotland who could and should have scored again with Claire Emslie missing a guilt edged chance towards the end.
It’s traditional in Hungary that the home side applaud the fans for coming out to see them, and at International level the men’s team are often serenaded by the Ultras giving a rousing post-match rendition of Himnusz, the Hungarian national anthem.
On Friday night, not only did the home players applaud the fans, but several of the Scotland team also came over to show appreciation of the (ahem) vocal minority of Scots in attendance. A small act that was greatly appreciated, especially by my daughter who had been blown away by the action on the pitch and the fact Scotland won, and hasn’t stopped about talking about the two players who ‘asked her’ for a picture; Lisa Robertson and Eartha Cummings, that small gesture meant the world to her (and me, if I’m being honest).
Next up for Scotland is a home game against the Faroe Islands on Tuesday — I’ll try to get the right kick-off time so I can tune in — and for Hungary, they host Spain, also on Tuesday and at the Hidegkuti Nandor Stadion.
Originally published at http://kevinmccluskie.wordpress.com on September 18, 2021.
--
--
Freelance football writer with a passion for Celtic FC, Hungary, and Groundhopping in Budapest

Title: What did I have to shed to take a dip in the thermal baths at Budapest!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I had done a fair amount of research on Budapest before I landed there, unlike my other random trip. This was a 13day long trip to East Europe and I had done all my bookings, research well in advance. I also got lucky with Budapest because a friends friend had lived there for three years and was immensely helpful in guiding me about the place and telling me about things I cannot miss in Budapest.
I have five days in Budapest and had fair amount of time to hand to cover all the things this friend had mentioned about in leisure. And trust me it wasn’t a point A to Point B, cover all the tourist points kind of a plan. She and I had common interests and she guided me on things that I would enjoy the most. Old and rustic pubs with live music for instance, a spa is always what I love to indulge in, you could call it a festish if you like.
There are so many experiences from Budapest that I would like to share about but what always stands out for me is something that changes something inside me. It could be anything from a conversation with a fellow traveller to an authentic meal. In Budapest it had to be the thermal bath experience.
I was told there are natural thermal baths and spas across the city and one can literally spend the day in one of those. Based on my friends recommendation, I decided to go to the one of the most popular one. While this is an experience I was waiting for, there was a lot running in my mind. I had asked none of them to my friend and the internet gave adequate information but for some reason I wasn’t trusting everything. As Indian’s we are not so familiar with public bath’s unless you are taking a dip in the holy rivers with all your clothes on. I had things running in my head and what did I have to shed to enjoy the experience fully?
Fortunately or unfortunately for me I just had to shed my inhibitions and walk into this beautiful place equipped with my swim suit. I got to Szechenyi Baths around three in the afternoon, it was fairly crowded and there was a small queue in front of the ticket counter and I was fourth or fifth in line, waiting to get my ticket and brimming with anticipation. When I got to the counter there was a man behind the counter and I asked if I could get a ticket for couple of hours, he answered politely and said the passes are for full day and I could use any of the baths I like. Now that is again something I discovered, I assumed there was only one large thermal bath. And I had not carried my own towel or flip flops so I could rent them at the counter as well and they would return the money on your way out when you return the towel and flip flop back.
Then I walked down to a narrow corridor after my tickets was punched to the women’s changing room and to get myself a locker. The fear of being nude in a public place is something I was not sure of and I was grateful that I could be in my swim suit. I mostly saw couples coming together or families or group of friends, I do not remember seeing another single traveller looking around lost and thrilled as I was.
As I made my way up to the baths finally I was freezing in my swimsuit, the temperature must have been around 8 degrees or lesser but the breeze was cold. In from of me were these three huge bath areas where filled with people, I could hardly wait to jump in, there were lockers by the pool side for people to keep their valuables and phones. I could not miss taking a few selfies and then locked my phone safely and left the towel at one of the chairs and walked right into the water. Oh man, so warm and relaxing, it was a bit too crowded for my liking by I found my spot and just chilled there soaking in the water for sometime before looking around and figuring what next. then I saw a fun whirlpool in the middle. I saw groups of people losing control and getting dragged into the whirlpool and having a lot of fun but again my minds talk started to converse. Everyone you see there are either couples or families or groups of friends having a blast, what would you to there alone. I though for a couple of minutes, wished I had my friends along but jumped right in. Let nothing stop you from living your life to the fullest a voice said inside me, I assumed it to be my mum.
Then it was time to experience the other pools and check the temperature difference and just experience everything that there was to experience. There was close to 12 smaller pools, which were indoor, less crowded and each one had different temperature and were in different sizes. Though I must admit that the vibe outdoors was way better. I believe there are all nigh parties that happens in these baths but I am not an all night party person at all, so that idea was not too exciting for me.
I had spent over three hours jumping from one pool to the other and now was starting to feel a bit tired and hungry. So, I bid farewell to the water and got straight into the shower and changing room. I would highly recommend the thermal baths in Budapest. But do not go there in a rush go post lunch and spend at least 3 hours. I would surely travel back to Budapest and dip in the water shedding a few more inhibitions and doubts of the mind. But till then the memories stays alive within.
Tips:
Highly recommend the full day pass at Szechenyi Thermal bath.
The ticket cost is about 22 Euros.
Carry you own towel and flip flops.
Spend 3 to 4 hours at least.
--
--

Title: Player recruitment suggestions for MTK Budapest — and the thought process behind them.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In this exercise I will try to recommend players for MTK Budapest. To suggest specific players we have to create player profiles. These profiles are important because every football club (like regular businesses) wants to maximize their return on investment. In sports, return is not only measured financially. Sporting results are usually higher in the hierarchy of the football clubs’ goals. To create player profiles we must know the tasks that the players are instructed to do. The closer the specific player’s profile is to the desired profile (usually called fit), the better the system works. These instructions are based on the coaching philosophy. Coaching philosophy obviously should be clear for every decision maker at the club. Coaching philosophy and club philosophy should also match, because both parties work for the same goal. Another important aspect is club identity and tradition, which is based on club history, club community and other environmental factors. If these 3 factors are synchronized (coaching philosophy, club philosophy, club identity and tradition) then it is easy to document tasks and therefore create player profiles. After this non-club specific entry let’s get into it.
MTK Budapest is undeniably one of the most important clubs (not only football) in Hungary. They won the second most (23x) Hungarian championships, which is quite impressive. But their effect on Hungarian football is even more impressive than that. To shorten your reading experience I will list some of the most important words that come to my mind about MTK Budapest. Tradition, culture, openness, innovation, talent management, intellectuality, community. These values could be easily seen on the pitch. MTK’s traditional football is arguably the blueprint for modern teams. High possession, lots of short passes, patience and near perfect organization. This should be the starting point of every decision at the club.
The club has one of the best youth system installed in Hungary. They founded the first football academy in Hungary in 2001. It is a key point in MTK’s current strategy to promote youth players to the first team, therefore it is crucial to have succession planning in mind when we try to recruit players. Pathways for talented individuals to the first team should be clear. Although my recruitment model is able to value relevant youth players (U16 and older), for this exercise I am not gonna use it. Upon request I can value the youth players of MTK and set up 3–5 year succession planning.
Dávid Horváth is one of the most talented coaches in Hungarian football. It is rare that a 38-year old coach is given trust in the first division. Firstly let’s see how he describes his own philosophy:
“We want to dominate in ball possession, create big chances, we don’t want to win with only 1 goal scored in the long term.”
“ I’m trying to make my own way. I don’t want to name anyone, from every great coach I try to take those elements that I like. Our coaching courses have followed a lot of directions, that is undeniable, when I studied the German style was emphasized, which is great If take a look on world football, German managers dominate, actually Jürgen Klopp and Thomas Tuchel were the coaches in the FA cup final. But I look up to the Italian coaches as well, Carlo Ancelotti doing fantastic things leading Real Madrid. I read a lot, I try to follow the international trends. At the same time when I got here, I took a deep dive in the club history, I try to follow the traditions laid by Jimmy Hogan and Márton Bukovi. I know for a fact that the legendary manager, József Garami followed the Dutch school.”
“The high intensity football that we showed in the last 4 rounds…is my ideal football. I think with this we can follow the world trends.”
index.hu
“The kind of playing style I try to instill is dependent on the club I work for. MTK has the identity, the club philosophy, even the playing style, here you have to be an MTK-style coach, and that football is — high possession, modern game, creating quantitative and qualitative superiority mixed with enough flexibility — is close to my heart, It is not hard to adapt.”
bunteto.com
Let’see how Dávid Horváth performed and whether he could show his philosophy. He managed 26 games in NB2 in the 2022/23 season. A traditional way too evaluate managerial performance is to use the point per match metric. It is certainly a good starting point, but this metric does not account for two important aspects. Home field advantage and opponent strength. Luckily my model include both of these elements providing a clearer picture than the traditional PPM. Here is the output document.
Although he had great resources, he did not disappoint results wise. It is clear that it was a good decision to appoint him as a manager. Stylistically he followed the club identity and traditions. Low number of crosses in chance creation is pleasing to see if you are a decision maker at MTK.
The defensive side is not as steady as the offensive, but still good for a 86 score out of 100. Probably a bit more aggressive approach would benefit MTK Budapest as they let the opponent keep the ball for longer periods. This coaching profile is another great addition to the tradition and club philosophy to create player profiles. Now we know what we are looking for.
I’m not going to analyze every player one by one, because this piece would be waaaay too long. I don’t really know, which formation will be the primary option. Some say 3–5–2 will be the one, but I would go with the 3–4–3. Maximizing the potential of Mátyás Kovács should be a primary goal for this season. In my opinion 3–5–2 does not suit him. The depth chart is based on a 3–4–3, because I think they will change to that soon. But these are just numbers and there is more depth to formations than this format.
Obviously there is much more nuance to rating players then grouping them into 3 categories, but it gives us a starting point. It is very important to note that I categorized players based on how I imagine their role in a team in the 4th — 6th range, which is not an unrealistic expectation based on wage expenses.
Sorted positions are: GK, central CB, LCB, LWB, CM, LW, CF
Positions that may need upgrading: RCB, RWB, RW
In this position MTK Budapest has the numbers, but I’m not sure there is enough quality. Kaka Godwords has a lot to improve to even reach NB2 level. Bence Várkonyi had a loan spell last season, he played for Kozármisleny FC in the spring. He is an aggressive defender, who performs well in defensive duels and has the recovery pace to cover large areas. When Várkonyi played, the defense of Kozármisleny was much better. For me the problems are on the ball with him. He is not a great passer. He rarely attempts progressive or forward passes and does not really asks for the ball, which is weird for an MTK Budapest alumni. He is still a good player, but did not pop off the screen. That is why I consider him as a quality rotation option in NB1 or a good starter in NB2.
I thought about moving Gergő Kocsis into the starter quality, so he is definitely on the fringes for me. He had a great season in NB2, he is very good on the ball, aggressive in duels (bit too much) and a versatile player. The only “problem” I have with him, is that Kocsis is 29 years old and only once in his professional career edged the 50% mark. What does the 50% mark mean? It means that the player played in 50% or more of the available minutes. It is a good measure to decide who is a starter and who’s not. That is why I grouped him as a quality rotation piece.
Benedek Varju is another player, where I was unsure where to place him. He is 22 years old, but has over 100 matches for MTK Budapest. For me he is best suited to play in the RCB position in a 3-man defense. Last season he played the most minutes at the right-back position. He was aggressive and performed well in defensive duels. He is great in the air, compared to other fullbacks. He is good in build-up play, takes good care of the ball. His progressive play and chance creation is also great, but well below the elite level. The reason why I’m not sure he is a clear starter is that he is often caught out of position, he definitely has to improve this part of his game. According to transfermarkt his contract will expire in 2024, although I expect MTK to extend his contract (I would probably do it, too).
Viktor Gey like Varju, is also a player who can play as a full-back/wing-back and centre-back. He is a new arrival from Kisvárda. He reached 2000+ minutes in NB1 the last 3 seasons, but his impact score is only 10 out of 100 in my model, rating him well below league average. It is hard to project future impact, it is even more difficult when a player changes teams. But I would have gone with a different choice.
We’ve covered the current options, now it is time to describe what we need.
I think these characteristics are important to be a great RCB in Dávid Horváth’s system.
Felix Bacher is a versatile, 22-year old Austrian centre-back. He is comfortable in a 3-man defense, and in a 4-man defense too. Can be deployed as a central CB, a right-sided CB or as right-back. He has a good frame, fast enough, no problem with physical capabilities. Extremely comfortable with the ball. Teammates trust him. Progressive passes and progressive runs are both part of his game. He has to adopt his style to MTK. Pass selection must tilt towards safety a bit more. Although Bacher is 1,9 m tall, he is below average in the air, which is an issue. All in all, I rate Bacher very highly. He was part of the Austrian Bundesliga Team of The Year, which is very impressive from a 9th placed WSG Tirol team. He is definitely good enough to play for MTK Budapest and this is probably the last time, when he can be attainable.
Another interesting name is Saba Khvadagiani. He is 20 years old and plays for Dinamo Tbilisi. He is well suited to play in a 3-man defense. He is very aggressive, he likes to “chase” his man and step out of the defensive line frequently. He has the speed and agility to play in a high line. Khvadagiani is a ball-playing centre-back, an elite ball progressor using both carries and passes. He is used to high possession and highly efficient in build-up play. He already debuted in the Georgian National Team and his reputation is growing by the day. He is a Georgian champion, and has experience in European Qualifiers as well. I would highly recommend him for MTK Budapest.
I think both of these players would significantly raise the talent level at MTK and have high resale value potential in them.
We’ve already covered the two main options Viktor Gey and Varju Benedek I don’t think they are the best options to be starting wing-backs. Ádám Miknyóczki played wing-back last season, but he is definitely a winger. This position is surely one I would upgrade.
Some of the needed characteristics are obviously same as for the centre-backs, but there are some post-specific requirements too.
The first name is Erik Kusnyír, whose contract expires in the summer of 2024, according to transfermarkt.com. He is one of my favorite players in the Hungarian NB1. I expect him to debut in the Hungarian National Team soon.
Kusnyír would be a fantastic addition for MTK, he fits the profile needed and possess high quality. I would highly recommend him.
Another player, who could be an option is Dan Sirbu of FCV Farul Constanta. He was a regular player of the Romanian champions. Sirbu is a versatile player, who can play as a RB, RWB, DM and CB also.
Sirbu is definitely a more attacking-minded player, than Kusnyír. I don’t know if the Romanian could be an affordable option for MTK, I guess it depends on the contract situation. Personally I would pick Kusnyír, because he fits the profile better, and for now a better player.
This position has the depth, but may need 1 quality signing. As I mentioned this is Ádám Miknyóczky’s main position, but he could not establish himself in NB2, unlikely to see him succeed in NB1. A loan would be the best option for him personally. I thought Nikolas Spalek will be a bigger boom in NB2, but he barely edged the 200 minutes mark. Most likely to start is Zoltán Stieber. Stieber delivered great numbers, but my model did not like him in NB2, which is unlikely to change one division higher. He is still a very good offensive player, but his defensive contribution is not enough for this level. There is a player, who haven’t played a lot at RW last season, whom I would certainly try to instill into the team. His name is Ákos Zuigeber. The well-rounded attacker always had great potential (still do), but injuries slowed down his development. Last season he mostly played as a LW, but he can play across the front line.
My first option would be to move him to the right side. But if MTK wants to solve this problem with another choice, here is what I would do.
I expect the wing-backs to provide width → Inside forward type, attacks the box, scores goals
Patient build-up → Can create against set defenses
High-possession style → Has the opportunities to try and create, has self-confidence to express himself
Creation not reliant on crosses → Creative both as a passer and receiver
One player, who fits this profile is Balázs Vogyicska. NB1 teams should have been all over him considering his age and talent.
Vogyicska is the player of Ferencvárosi TC. I don’t think he will play for them this season. It would be a shame if he is loaned to Soroksár SC in NB2. I would definitely recommend him for MTK Budapest.
I think both Zuigeber and Vogyicska would be a very good option for MTK.
Let’s see how MTK Budapest looks after our attempt to strengthen the side.
This side has the defensive quality to achieve the expectations. My model estimates that there are only 2 players out of this 11, who has a negative impact on the defensive side.
The offensive quality is probably even more starring. With the same of players (2) who are below average on offense per my model. We have players, who are comfortable on the ball. Mátyás Kovács and Ákos Zuigeber are interchangable in the half spaces. Every player fits well in the system.
In my opinion we strengthened the squad of MTK Budapest significantly at least in theory. This team would be good enough to contend for European places in NB1. Most of the players have significant value and could enter the market after a successful season, which fits well into the philosophy of MTK.
In this exercise I used transfermarkt and wyscout data. To value the coach and players I used my own holistic model, which accounts for quality of teammates and strength of opponents. If you have any questions or suggestions or just want to talk about football please let me know.
--

Title: Walking across the Chain Bridge By Night
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Celebrating Stories of Hope, Happiness, and Heart.

Member-only story
--
27
Share
I have stood on many parts of the banks of this great river and looked down the Danube. But none stays with me like this moment in Budapest.
We had finished our visit to Buda Castle and stopped for dinner by sunset on the banks of the Danube. We were beginning our walk back home because we wanted to cross the Danube under the stars. It did not disappoint us.
The Chain Bridge is beautiful at twilight. From the moment the sun transitions from harsh brightness to golden yellow, the Chain Bridge passes through many seasons. Each is different and lingers, even if it lasts only a few minutes.
But all this fades away before the night. As the lights go out one by one, the Chain Bridge is transformed into a magnificent apparition over the water. It sits like a tiara above the Danube.
It does not surprise me to remember that when it was inaugurated in 1848, it was hailed as a work of engineering and among the largest such bridges in the world. Today, the world may have raised other more complex structures, but anyone who walks…
--
--
27
Celebrating Stories of Hope, Happiness, and Heart.
Passionate content creator. Traveller. Author of "Being, Becoming, Being", "I'll Do It My Way: The Incredible Journey of Aamir Khan", "Ginger Soda Lemon Pop".

Title: Why Does Budapest Have An American President in Liberty Square?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

MPP friends writing about life, love, and everything else in between together.

Member-only story
--
13
Share
I was following our tour guide through Budapest’s Liberty Square when he stopped the group and pointed to a larger-than-life bronze statue. “Do you know who this is?”
We shuffled closer, and I gasped. “Ronald Reagan? You have a statue of Ronald Reagan in your capitol?”
My next question echoed what many of us were thinking. “Why?”
The tour guide beamed. “Hungarians believe Ronald Reagan had a lot to do with the fall of Communism in our country. His famous words, ‘Take down that wall,’ started the whole thing rolling.”
The guide continued, “There are many who believe his economic policies led to the downfall of the Soviet Union. The people wanted to show their appreciation for your former president’s efforts in ending the Cold War.”
As I spent more time in Budapest, I noticed a recurring theme. The Hungarians felt oppressed and stripped of their rights when the Soviet Union controlled their country, and feelings…

Title: The Films of Wes Anderson: The Grand Budapest Hotel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The (Counter)Cultural One-Stop for Nonfiction on Medium… incorporating categories for: ‘Art’, ‘Culture’, ‘Equality’, ‘Photography’, ‘Film’, ‘Mental Health’, ‘Music’ and ‘Literature’.

Member-only story
--
Share
I was quite worried about coming back to The Grand Budapest Hotel. I watched it in late 2014, around the time of its release, when I was first starting to take cinema more seriously. At the time, it completely alienated me. That being said, I would’ve been 12 then… not exactly in Anderson’s target (or even considered) audience.
I returned to the film in 2020, when I had to watch it for one of my first year classes at university. I… still didn’t like it, but at least it made me laugh a few times in the process.
Considering that I have, up to this point, enjoyed every Anderson film to a certain extent, I was curious to see if my opinion on The Grand Budapest Hotel might finally change, making a radical, gradual shift across nine years from frustration to love.
My opinion did not change, though.
--

Title: The Budapest Guild
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I stepped forward and found myself surrounded by several men. Their faces were serious and their eyes were watching me with unshielded curiosity.
I generally thought my family was somehow odd. Every year, as a general rule, we left on a few most colorful getaways, abandoning the commonplace everyday practice of our regular routines. It wasn’t so much that we were rich or had some mysterious fortune buried; we just had a talent for tracking down the most dark and exciting objections. Yet, it was only after we visited Budapest that I started to think something was wrong.
The city was a mix of old-world appeal and dynamic innovation, its roads overflowing with history and culture. We showed up at our leased condo, a curious little spot settled among the cobblestone roads of Buda, ignoring the glory of the Danube Waterway. It was the ideal setting for one more of our yearly experiences.
The night after our appearance, I chose to investigate the city all alone, drawn by the persona of Budapest’s complex roads. As I wandered through the architecturally significant area of the Palace Slope, I coincidentally found a little bookshop. Charmed, I pushed open the creaky entryway and wound up encompassed by racks loaded up with dusty old books, maps, and blurred photos.
An old man standing behind the overloaded counter was looking at me through the thick lenses of his glasses. He appeared to be pretty much as old as the books he protected. “Searching for something particularly amazing, youthful one?” he scratched.
“Simply perusing”, I answered. “But, I’d be intrigued assuming you have some books about Budapest’s secret history.”
His eyes shimmered with a disrupting glimmer. “Oh, unlike the others. Most vacationers come here for knickknacks and keepsakes, however, you look for a real thing.”
I raised an eyebrow, inquisitive. “A real thing?”
The old man inclined nearer, his voice scarcely above a murmur. “Budapest holds privileged insights, my boy. Privileged insights that a few families have protected for ages.”
My heart animated as I paid attention to the elderly person’s secretive words. “What sort of mysteries?”
He looked around to make sure no other person was tuning in before proceeding, “Professional assassins, my dear. This city has been home to an old and mysterious guild of professional assassins for quite a long time.”
I was unable to accept what I was hearing. It must be a fanciful story turned by a whimsical elderly person. “Professional assassins? Here in Budapest? That is absurd.”
He reached under the counter and gave me a well-used calfskin-bound book. Its pages were yellowed with age, and its title was just “The Budapest Guild.” I flipped through the pages, my suspicion winding down with each word. I was so confused by the story that I didn’t realize that the book was written in Hungarian. And that I was reading it with no problem.
The book spoke about the Budapest Guild, whose roots extend back to the Middle Ages.
As per the book, individuals from the guild worked in the shadows, executing clandestine missions for strong and cryptic clients. They were experts in camouflage, penetration, and trickiness, leaving no hint of their presence. In any case, the most stunning disclosure was on the way — the organization was reputed to be comprised of select, honorable families who passed down their knowledge and skills from one generation to the next.
I got back to our condo, my psyche hustling about the Budapest Guild. I couldn’t resist the opportunity to contemplate whether my family was in some way or another associated with it. Their often getaways to intriguing areas unexpectedly took on a vile contort.
That evening, as we plunked down to supper sitting above the city’s gleaming lights, I wanted to concentrate on my family with freshly discovered doubt. Their chuckling appeared to be all in all too practiced, their discussions excessively enigmatic. Might it be said that they were simply unpredictable voyagers, or was there more to them than met the eye?
As I dove further into the privileged insights of Budapest, I understood that my mission for reality could uncover beyond anything I expected. I was going to find that some family getaways were destructive businesses and that the Budapest Guild’s shadowy association had ringlets that came farther than I at any point envisioned.
Amid the charming roads of Budapest, my journey for truth was slowly unfolding secret and interest. The finding of the Budapest Guild had shaken my entire life, and with days passing, I was getting more hungry to reveal the whole story. And my role in it. Luckily, the antiquated book was helpful in my quest. Its yellowed pages helped me to uncover the Guild’s main seat.
So one night, while my family ate in our leased loft, I got away to investigate the city’s privileged insights all alone. The moon hung low in the night sky, creating long shaded areas on the cobblestone roads of Buda. It was during these nighttime hours that Budapest uncovered its most profound secrets.
I meandered through the complex back streets of Palace Slope, my expectations becoming stronger with every step I took. As I wandered further into the evening, I coincidentally found a faintly lit back street that coaxed me forward.
It was in this dark back street that I experienced a gathering of shadowy figures, their countenances clouded by the shroud of haziness. My heart hustled as I understood they were talking in quiet tones, their words a melodic rhythm of the Hungarian language. I stood frozen, concealed in the shadows, and tuned in.
Suddenly, one voice transcended the others — a voice I knew quite well. It was my dad’s, his tone firm and commanding. He ordered me to come closer and join the group.
“Your opportunity has arrived,” he said. His words rang with seriousness. “It’s your time to become familiar with our inheritance.”
I stepped forward and found myself surrounded by several men. Their faces were serious and their eyes were watching me with unshielded curiosity.
“Welcome to the Guild young man”, one of them said. Later, I learned that he was the Grand Master of the Guild and Master of the school I was about to join.
My father came over, gave me a quick hug, and said: “Make our family proud.” After that, he turned and walked down the street. I watched him until he disappeared into the dark shadows.
Then I turned to my new teachers. They simply turned and stepped toward the dead end of the street. They stopped briefly, just long enough to open a door that had not been seen until then. I stepped through them without hesitation, into my new life.
--
--
Writer of speculative and literary fiction. I explore the surreal beneath the surface of everyday life—fiction, fantasy, memory, myth, grief, and the unknown.

Title: Week 3: Grand Budapest Hostel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Traveling from Europe to Asia. Will he make it? Find out next week.

--
Listen
Share
What up, it’s ya boy Yung Wes Anderson back again with another blog post. I know I’m a bit late, it’s been hard synthesizing everything that went down in Budapest. Luckily, there’s a thunderstorm raging outside my window, so I’ve finally got some time to piece together my past week in what’s been my favorite city so far.
Budapest is a gorgeous, walk-able city that reminded me a lot of San Francisco without the expensive price tag. The city is actually a combination of two : Buda and Pest, divided by the Danube river that runs through the middle. A recent influx in tourism is causing a massive spike in development and, contrary to Prague, Budapest felt geared to host tourists. There’s an extensive hostel network that’s deeply intertwined with the city and its offerings, allowing you to purchase tickets for many of the main attractions at the reception desk of wherever you’re staying. Stories of people extending their stay multiple times were commonplace. I was definitely tempted.
I arrived in the afternoon with Kiah, the Australian traveler I met in Vienna. We had booked the same hostel, Sziget City (named after Budapest’s annual musical festival), for its cheap price and non-party hostel status. I was still getting over the traveler’s cold I picked up in Prague and needed a quiet place to recover while I coughed and sneezed my way through a box of tissue paper. I was naive to critique Prague’s party scene before seeing Budapest’s, which took the concept to the next level.
Sziget City is an old, re-purposed apartment complex with a quiet courtyard overshadowed by a large cherry tree. It’s also five doors down from Retox, the nexus of a six hostel network where massive drinking events like the Jager Train (300 shots of Jagermeister being made simultaneously) or the AlchOlymips (six intense drinking “sports”) take place nightly. Sziget City provided the best of both worlds, allowing me to tap into either atmosphere whenever if I felt like it.
I’d make my social debut the following night at Retox for karaoke night, but not for too long. I stared in disbelief with a guy from New York as people made out on the dance floor to an awful rendition of the Backstreet Boy’s “I Want It That Way”. We talked a bit about the global pervasiveness of Western pop culture, which would follow me everywhere I went throughout the week. My bus driver was playing Leona Lewis. The vegetarian burger stand was blasting Arctic Monkeys. The sandwich shop was playing Kamaiyah (ayyy).
I slowly eased myself into being more active. And by eased, I mean the opposite. I went out dancing the following evening. The DJ was spinning absolute bangers from Missy Elliot to Migos. I found a dance partner from D.C. who was studying abroad in Berlin and vacationing in Budapest. We danced until we were drenched in sweat, exchanged contact info, and called it a night.
The next day I went with Kiah to the Szechenyi Spa house, deep in the Pest side of the city. Budapest has a natural geothermal network running beneath it, so you’ll find hot-springs scattered throughout the city. Szechenyi is one of the largest in Europe, a dandelion rectangle enclosing three turquoise pools. I felt like I was in a Wes Anderson film, except the grandiose locations he portrays are usually long past their heyday with a few stragglers desperately, nostalgically grasping for the past. Szechenyi is very much in its prime. Like animals at a waterhole, humans waded around, some on the backs of others, sitting on the steps, beneath the fountain head, eyes closed, breathing deeply. We explored the interior after lounging in and out of the pools outside. More spas, more saunas of different shapes, depths, and temperatures. We concluded our stay at the bath house with an hour-long Thai massage that opened up my shoulders and legs and left me sore for the next two days.
Later that evening I attended one of the famous boat parties along the river between Buda and Pest. All of the main government buildings were illuminated on the river bank and their reflections danced on the river’s surface (see cover photo above). I met up with Grace, my dance partner from the night before, and we chatted about growing up mixed and our family dynamics (she had 14 au pairs growing up). She introduced me to two of her friends who were staying at my hostel, Marco and Isabelle. They had all met at NYU and their travels and holidays happened to coincide. It was an all-you-can-drink event so people were going to town on the booze, but alcohol is so cheap out here that there’s no way anyone could beat the bar and live to tell the tale. I did a decent job pacing myself, but when the ferry abruptly docked, I took two more cups of wine for the road and put myself into solidly drunken territory. We all had separately rough endings to our night.
The next morning, I went on a free walking tour (which I highly recommend to anyone exploring a new city) with Damon, a new roommate with a great attitude from New Zealand. I met up with Grace and her friends from NYU and we slowly made our way around town. We saw St. Stephens Cathedral, based off the first christian king of Hungary. They have his 500 year old hand inside and they follow it around during one of the hottest days of the year, annually. We crossed the river to the Buda side and checked out the government palaces before ending up in front of another yet another old church with yet another stunning view that overlooked all of Pest.
The NYU students and I stopped by a small, 200 year old coffee shop before making our way across the river for dinner. We went to an open mic night hosted by the hostels and Isabelle and Marco did a live rendition of some Kanye lyrics in spoken word fashion. We hung out upstairs afterwards and debated the ethics of music consumption before heading towards Szimpla, a collection of bars and dance floors that inhabit the ruins of an old, abandoned building. We found ourselves sharing shisha amidst the street art, graffiti, and re-purposed sculptures. We danced to Central American music until 3 in the morning before parting ways with Grace, who’d be returning to Berlin that morning.
I said my goodbyes to Kiah the next afternoon before checking out the House of Terror with Damon. What was once a KGB/Nazi torture facility has now been transformed into an exhibition/memorial about soviet and Nazi activity in Hungary before, during, and after World War II. The exhibition started at the top floor and slowly made its way to the torture dungeons in the cellar. A large tank sat on a platform in the center of the atrium, semi-submerged in six inches of still, black water, with just a razor’s-width of liquid seeping ominously down the sides. No photos allowed :(
I met up with Marco and Isabelle in the evening, tried some local cuisine, and explored a few of the ruins bars again. On the way out, a college-aged woman was cursing out a tall, gruff Hungarian man for catcalling one of her friends. She and her friends were clearly drunk and the guy threatened to hit her if she kept saying “fuck you” to his face. We intervened and created some distance between the two groups, but the man suddenly sprinted down the street and slapped the girl hard on the side of her face from behind. The girl ran off crying with her friends. He started walking after us, telling me to turn around and face him, saying I’d be a bitch if I didn’t, and finally backing away in the opposite direction after it was clear we weren’t going to engage with him.
We walked the group back to their hostel while the woman who had been assaulted sobbed about how men are horrible (true), how she wants to go back home to Florida (fair), how she’s a nice girl who volunteers and doesn’t deserve this (uh, ok), how she didn’t want anyone to touch her (despite the fact that she and her friend were both very drunk and crossing the busiest street in Budapest at a red light. I had to physically move them in order to dodge oncoming traffic like a game of Frogger). One of her friends kept insisting on going back to fight the guy, leaving the group, and requiring us to run after her. Another was hitting on Marco as her friend cried nearby. We had a lot of mixed emotions about the whole ordeal, and were equal parts relieved and exhausted by the time we got them home.
I spent my last day in Budapest saying farewell to all of the amazing people I’d met throughout the week. I took one last stroll through the city with Isabelle before throwing my backpack on and departing. It was the most raw and bittersweet I’ve felt so far. In just six short days, I’d shared so many conversations with guests and hostel staff in the courtyard that they started to feel like family. Budapest’s street had become so familiar to me I could walk them without a map. I can see how people end up here indefinitely. But it was getting colder, which meant it was time for me to get going, I’m running south from the winter every few days like some god damn Game of Thrones character.
I’m in Croatia now. A guard with a silver pistol checked my passport at the border and was crazy enough to let me in. I’m entering week four of my travels and feeling more adjusted, though there are still days where I wake up and forget which country I’m in. I’m happy I have five more months ahead of me. The sadness I feel leaving new friends in a new city will soon be replaced by the happiness of meeting new friends in a new city, but the process is emotionally exhausting. I guess that just comes with the territory.
Well! You’ve made it to the end, thanks for reading. I hope it was worth your time. Stay tuned for some saucy shots from the Balkans next week!
_George
--
--
Traveling from Europe to Asia. Will he make it? Find out next week.
